Document_Content: urn:contentItem:49KJ-JVY0-01S8-G3VY-00000-00<published>1988-09-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>FLOWERING ASTER A CUT ABOVE THE REST IN SUMMER</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>CAULFIELD H</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">COURIER LIVING SAT replace pars as marked on page proof Flowering aster a cut above the rest in summer M ANY gardeners grow flowering annuals so they can have blooms for indoor decor. With spring displays ending, it is time to think about planting seedlings for early summer flowering. One of the first to go in should be asters because they must be brought to flower before the start of the wet season, which induces many fungus complaints. Asters have very attractive flowers with long stems and a delightful color range, which can include several shades of blue. Asters do not tolerate over-wet soils so garden beds must be free-draining. Because asters are a member of the daisy family, they should be grown in an exposed position with unrestricted sunlight. Red spider mites and aphids are the most troublesome insect pests, but systemic pesticides such as Lebaycid, Omethoate and Rogor will keep them under control if sprayed at three-weekly intervals. For people who do not want to use a pesticide, frequent use of garlic spray can be effective. Spray with Carbaryl if tiny caterpillars skeletonise the leaves and small grubs damage the flowers. Fungus diseases cause most damage to asters, especially when the weather is humid. Spray with the fungicide Mancozeb once a fortnight, starting in the early stages of growth. Celosia, with its warm colors, is a useful cut flower. It relishes hot weather and will move quickly now that the hours of daylight and temperature are increasing.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>I have learned from long experience that celosia seedlings transplant more readily when small with only two sets of leaves and no more than three. Leggy seedlings are inclinded to run straight to flower without any worthwhile growth. The red forest fire and golden triumph are pleasing varieties, but the tall-growing pampas plume mixture will provide a range of pastel colors seldom found in summer annuals. Celosia must be grown quickly or stems will not be long enough to cut. A side dressing of sulphate of ammonia about a month after planting will force growth. Another excellent cut flower is the African marigold, which produces flowers in yellow and orange shades. The jubilee mixture, with long stems and full double blooms, is ideal to cut. Discontinue overhead watering when flowering starts because the blooms are inclined to rot if they are continually soaked and the weight of water on the petals might cause the flowers to bend and break the stem. Despite their stiff appearance, several strains of zinnia are excellent for cutting and they have a long vase life. But only mature flowers must be picked and the petals must reach a papery state or the blooms will droop and break the stems just behind the flowers. Like most summer flowering annuals, zinnia should be grown 30cm apart in a sunny site and only in free-draining soil. Spray with Mancozeb in humid conditions because leaf spot fungus disease and mildew are likely to be troublesome in such an atmosphere. Zinnia is also best transplanted when small and the largest plants should be selected. The happy talk varieties are very suitable _ a mixture of the giant quilled petal strain with many pastel colors. Showman, a large dahlia flower mixture with strong colors, is bushy with flowers on vigorous stems. The small round-flowered pom pom mixture is very attractive with most of the blooms in soft colors. The stems are very long and the bushes very productive. Zinnia requires only a moderately-enriched soil. If the nutrient level is high the corp produces a lot of foliage to the detriment of the flowers. A few dahlias will produce abundant cut flowers. They can be grown in the foreground of a shrubbery or be given a bed of their own. Seedlings of bedding types such as hi dolly, which produces double and semi-double flowers in bright colors on long stems, are easily available. Also available in a popular seed packet range is the dwarf Cinderella, which is suitable for small vase arrangements. If you prefer pom pom and miniature cactus or decorative dahlias, buy packs of tubers to obtain plants with a recognised per- formance. A well-enriched soil is a must for dahlias and a supporting stake is necessary for the tall strains. Tie them with nylon stockings because they stretch as the stems expand. To prolong the life of cut flowers, place them in a bucket of water as soon as possible after they are picked. Dahlia stems should be dipped in hot water.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC OF SKETCH OF urn:contentItem:5PJW-TXT1-JCM0-61VW-00000-00California Burning2009-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisForeign Correspondent10:33 PM AESTABCCalifornia Burning

NEWS REPORT: The fire started near here where Air 7HD first spotted the fire at Five Acres.

FIRE CHIEF: Today what happened is what I call the perfect storm of fuels, weather and topography coming together.

WOMAN: [press conference] The Station fire was the result of an act of arson.

CIVILIAN WOMAN: It took a turn, it took a huge turn and it's time to go.

CIVILIAN MAN: It's not good [looking at burning hills behind him]. It's pretty scary, especially once it gets over the ridge.

ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER: [Press conference] You know we have a lot of fires all over the State of California - fires, fires, fires.

BRISSENDEN: Fighting fire in the hills and mountains around Hollywood is a big, almost cinematic operation, and like any big budget production, an army of cast and crew are up before dawn taking their direction.

It's a daunting logistical exercise. They're trying to outsmart and eventually conquer a wildly unpredictable and extremely dangerous enemy. This is no special effects monster, this is the real deal, what we call a bush fire and what's known here as a wildfire or a forest fire. And this wildfire, like so many these days in California, is big.

PATRICK TITUS: [Holding map] We've anchored flanks. We've anchored in over here in a good safe place and we're bringing this line around so we're pinching that fire down.

BRIAN SAVAGE: [Division Supervisor] For 12 years I've been on teams but I've been doing fires for 25 and you know this fire for instance was pretty dynamic, but 4,000 people assigned to a single fire in the United States, you don't see that very much. I've never seen a fire with 4,000 people assigned.

BRISSENDEN: So far this year California has had more than five thousand forest fires close to towns and cities. This one, called the Station Fire, has morphed into a mega fire. From fire fighters and law enforcement officers, to caterers and cleaning staff, nearly 500 engines, 14 helicopters, 64 bulldozers and fixed wing planes - including two DC 10's and for the first time a 747 capable of dropping 70 thousand litres of retardant in one go. When it's closing in on homes and lives, the response to a mega fire is equal force and here there won't be much change out of 50 million dollars.

Like much of southeast Australia, California has been in drought now for many years. The fire season here used to be three to four months. It's now an almost year round state of alert and many here are starting to believe that the change could be permanent. So the question is, should we stop trying to assume we can contain fire, and rather find better ways to deal with this new reality?

STEPHEN PYNE: Houses are still burning down. The place is flooded. We're spending tens of millions of dollars. We're flying Boeing 747's with retardant now in mountains. I mean this is how nutty this is getting. The fire guys don't have a choice. They're told you've got to take action. We need to show we're responding. That is simply a broken system. Well you know the situation about how we try to defend houses here is absurd. You know I could legally defend this place with an AK 47 and a bazooka if I chose, but apparently not with a garden hose, I'll be evacuated.

BRISSENDEN: In arid Arizona, far from the Station blaze, fire historian Stephen Pyne is sounding the alarm on America's fire-fighting strategy and the new peril of the suburban sprawl.

STEPHEN PYNE: I regard a lot of these as our sub-prime landscapes. This is the environmental flip side to Wall Street's conflagration. We shouldn't have built it on a lot of funny money and fraud going into it. There's no reason to build these things there and they're burning down just as the economy melted down.

BRISSENDEN: Stephen Pyne is one of the world's foremost authorities on the culture of fire. In California broadly, and Los Angeles specifically, unchecked development and bad fire management have collided with global warming and the result according to this expert, is very grim indeed.

STEPHEN PYNE: The whole literature of Los Angeles is about Los Angeles in apocalyptic meltdown. I'm not sure for fire there's a lot they can do. I don't think they can go back to the fundamentals and rebuild it.

BRISSENDEN: It's hard to know where the sprawl of Los Angeles ends. It certainly appears seamless all the way here to this neighbourhood, but this is Orange County, south of L.A.

This summer, Orange County fire officers have been visiting homeowners on site and giving their houses fire safety ratings. Many of them fall badly short.

Many of the houses in this neighbourhood wouldn't last long if and probably when, a forest fire sweeps up out of the surrounding bushland. That's why the local strategy called 'Ready Set Go' is so important.

(CLIP FROM 'Ready Set Go' VIDEO)

'Ready Set Go' is modelled on Australia's 'Stay and Defend or Leave Early Policy' and was adapted here by this man, Mike Ferdigh.

Mike Ferdigh was working with Victorian Fire authorities when the Black Saturday infernos erupted and knows the Australian strategy has been heavily scrutinised ever since.

MIKE FERDIGH: [Emergency Planning Co-Ordinator] I think it can work real well. I talked to several people and there was one lady in Marysville.... I'm probably going to insult her, I'm going to guess she was in her 70's.... and her house survived. So if a house is defendable I think it can work.

BRISSENDEN: But the reality of mega fires, makes it more difficult.

MIKE FERDIGH: I think the hardest part which was obviously the same in Australia, and the same thing here, is how do you prepare a home owner when that fire comes.

BRISSENDEN: And how do you?

MIKE FERDIGH: I don't think we can. I've been doing this for 30 years and I'm still amazed. So how can you take someone that goes to work every day, does a great job at their daily job, has air conditioning in their house and sits in a fairly nice environment and put them in a smoky environment where they can't see a foot and they want to throw up because of the smoke, and it's hot - I don't think there's any way you really can prepare someone for that.

TAM SCHUMANN: [Local TV reporter, describing fire] It was very, very dark. It was pitch black and I thought two things, I thought this is what living in war must be like or what hell must be like.

ED SCHUMANN: Fireman and some neighbours kind of made a fire line and everybody was just passing these bottles of water.

BRISSENDEN: He's a senior attorney and she's a judge but when last year's so-called freeway fire stormed up to the Orange County home of Ed and Tam Schumann deciding to stay or go had them scratching their heads before it was almost too late.

ED SCHUMANN: We thought we were pretty safe and we have a really nice buffer zone between us and any open land and either the wind shifted or the fire just found more fuel in our direction and it started coming up back over the hills, back here behind us and we got everybody out and took off.

TAM SCHUMANN: And when we fled the streets on either side were already aflame. The flames were just high and shooting and it was pitch black and embers were falling through.

ED SCHUMANN: This is Tam's riding arena. Last year this would have all been completely cleared so there's nothing that would have burned on this whole hillside. So we felt safe you know? That should have been a really good buffer.

BRISSENDEN: Their experience demonstrates why 'Ready Set Go' is such a difficult call. They thought they were insulated against fire and now as the Station fire blazes well out of range and north of them, the Schumann's are still very uncomfortable.

TAM SCHUMANN: We were really surprised at our reaction. Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome really, really exists. Both Ed and I were shocked at our reaction to that, to seeing this new batch of fires.

ED SCHUMANN: Yeah it kind of makes you relive it again. You see the hillside burning and you kind of, you think God it can happen again.

PATRICK TITUS: [Battalion Chief] You know this is my 30-something years doing this. When I was younger, on the hand crews and the hotshots and stuff, a big fire was 15,000 acres and now it's so common that a fire is you know 100,000 plus acres. We had a fire in the Las Padres earlier that was 90 something thousand acres.... so you know it's not that those didn't happen when I was young but they were very, very rare. Now they've become very commonplace now.

BRISSENDEN: The Station fire was an act of arson that within a day tore through 25,000 acres and doubled in size every day for the first four days. It's become the largest wildfire in Los Angeles' County history. And that's before the deadly seasonal winds have arrived, the dry desert Santa Anna's.

BRIAN SAVAGE: [Division supervisor] If we had a Santa Anna wind condition set up and we have a current fire burning like we do, we're going to get pounded. That fire is going to spread. It will go to the foothills and we will be fighting a fire fifty miles away and trying to save homes where we can.

BRISSENDEN: The specialist crews in American fire fighting can sound like they've been named by a Hollywood producer. These are the hotshot crews and by day they're hard at it 'cutting line' forging defensive firebreaks along the ridgeline. It's tough, demanding work. With lumbering aircraft continuing to bomb the blaze, it can look like a war. In fact, the hotshot crews are modelled on small organised units from the World War II battlefield. And then there's the US fire fighting paratrooper, the smoke jumper.

JIM RAUDENBUSH: They started in about 1940 and it was just a way to get fire fighters to inaccessible fires and.... they decided to try parachuting, and that's when it got going. They've been around for almost sixty years now.

BRISSENDEN: These very specialised operators are based in Boise Idaho and from here they can be deployed at short notice anywhere across the country.

JIM RAUDENBUSH: We carry two days worth of food and water and if we need additional food and water we can be resupplied. You never know what you're doing from day to day. You can be sitting here in Boise one day and wake up in Alaska the next on a fire out in the middle of nowhere.

BRISSENDEN: Boise is fire-fighting central. At the national command centre enormous warehouses hold every piece of fire fighting kit imaginable. It can be rushed to fire crews as they call for it or as management at headquarters sees fit. At the Centre's coordinating bunker they can be dealing with dozens of fires across the country at any one time.

It's a supply and coordination centre but it's also gathering data and developing a clearer picture of the fire threat in the United States. From his national vantage point here, Rick Ochoa, one of the country's leading fire related weather specialists, is seeing a tinderbox getting drier.

RICK OCHOA: [Weather analyst] You know we have much drier fuels, much hotter temperatures and so on. So the weather and the climate and the fuels and fire is changing. Our jobs are also becoming more challenging in the fact that we have to look at more and more areas and events that in the past you know we had some wind, we had some humidity, we didn't think we'd see that much fire potential or fire behaviour, we're seeing a lot more of it now because the fuels are so much different.

BRISSENDEN: From computer screens in Idaho to fire fronts in California, the picture is the same. Global warming is proving to be an alarming accelerant.

RICK OCHOA: I think it's a permanent change. I think this is here to stay. We're seeing here in the States and Australia, longer fire seasons, hotter fire seasons, it's just because we're dealing with a much warmer globe.

MIKE FERDIGH: I believe you're in a twelve year drought, we're in a four/five year drought so we're just starting the same path that you guys are maybe ten years ahead of us. So if the drought conditions, if you wanted to throw in global warming, what that's doing to the environment and the drought conditions we have here presently in Southern California, it has the potential to be another bad fire season.

NEWS REPORT: Arnold Schwarzenegger served the breakfast to fire-fighters today at the Lake View Terrace Command Post. He assured them that state money would be there to fight the fires. He told me there's enough in reserve to keep the money flowing to fire-fighters.

ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER: Public safety is the number one priority so yes you have to be frugal, yes you have to look at every dollar but we will have the dollars available to fight these fires and we will go all out.

BRISSENDEN: The Californian economy was in freefall before the global financial crisis made things even worse. An increasingly demanding fire season, more and more mega fires, has a huge financial dimension and fire historian Stephen Pyne wonders if the state can in fact deal with its fiery future.

STEPHEN PYNE: That cycle, spending more money, evacuating more people.... this can't continue. This is just insane and it doesn't solve the problem. The problem comes as with our financial system by taking a systemic view and reorganising it. We've made this mess and it's a big deep mess. It's going to take a long time to disentangle it, but we can begin. There are a number of things, we'll start small, we'll begin putting it together again.

BRISSENDEN: Some of those small changes are being implemented in the big houses along San Diego's ridge tops. They're a long way from the subprime fuelled suburban expansion on the LA fringe but the fire danger here is just as alarming. Nearly 10,000 homes have been lost to wildfires here in the past 40 years.

CLIFF HUNTER: [Fire marshal] Our preferred method is to evacuate and evacuate early but there may be some time constraints depending on the fire and the wind conditions which stop you from doing that. It's very difficult once it gets to a certain point from a safety perspective, to get in and try to fight it.

We're in a community called the Cielo and it's a sheltered place community. It's one of six in the Rancho Santa Fe fire protection district and our goal is that if you live in a sheltered place community, you would not have to evacuate if a wild land fire came through. That means if a fire were to come through the community, you would be safer to stay in your home, close your windows, close your doors and try not to evacuate.

BRISSENDEN: The houses here have all been designed to conform to the local Rancho Santa Fe Fire Protection code. It's a much stricter regulatory environment and certainly more expensive than elsewhere in California, but the man behind it all, local Fire Chief Cliff Hunter says the lessons learnt here can be used more widely.

CLIFF HUNTER: You can do this in a regular home owner situation. You can still look at the vents, you can still look at the roofs..... we can still look at landscaping and we would hopefully look at the infrastructure, which are the roadways and water supply and telephone and power and all those things. So yes I believe it is 100% achievable in another community.

BRISSENDEN: All over California regulators are slowly getting tough and homeowners are getting the message that if they want to live with nature, they must adapt.

ED SCHUMANN: This is what's left. We sorted through the last of this today and found what we could.

BRISSENDEN: Tam and Ed Schumann learnt the hard way. Their home was not fire safe. For them the cost of complying with tougher building regulations isn't even an issue if it means their new home will survive another fire.

TAM SCHUMANN: I was not going to let this fire get me down. I was going to.... it was almost like I was going to shake my fist and say, I am not getting driven out by this. I'm going to rebuild and my life is going to go on.

ED SCHUMANN: We've had to compromise and make some changes but we are building the house we want. The city has changed a lot of the fire codes with the way things are rebuilt..... so personally I think we're pretty safe.

BRISSENDEN: How do you think you will feel when you move back to the new house when it's built? What are you going to do, anything special?

TAM SCHUMANN: Throw a huge party.

ED SCHUMANN: And don't call it a house warming. We've had the house warming party, now we're going to have the house cooling party.

BRISSENDEN: When the smoke clears from this fire, as happened in Australia after Victoria's Black Saturday tragedy, questions will be asked about building safer homes, about homeowner's responsibility and about the fire fighting efforts as well.

PATRICK TITUS: My crystal ball's worn out. I don't know. I don't know but things have changed and I think the fire service, not just in California but nationwide in the United States, I think we're changing with it a little bit. I think our leadership and a lot of leadership are really coming to terms with what a whole different way of thinking about how we approach the fires.

BRISSENDEN: Controlling fire, living with it and adapting to a rapidly changing fire environment has become one of the big challenges of our time and it seems we all still have a lot to learn.

STEPHAN PYNE: There's a big disconnect and fire is being separated from the way we manage the land. We've forgotten what has been such a brilliant defining characteristic for us. I mean that's what we do. We're the fire creatures. You know other animals knock over trees and dig holes in the ground.... we do fire - and that has always been our unique signature.

urn:contentItem:4P0W-XC40-TXN5-T2B8-00000-00Ordinary people ... extraordinary task2002-01-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19Ordinary people ... extraordinary taskTHE WEEK OPINIONPhilippa Murray

IT'S the jaffas and canaries we have to thank for helping us over some of the major disasters in our lives.

Out of their distinctive orange and yellow livery, the volunteer men and women from the State Emergency Services and the Rural Fire Service who arrive promptly to fight floods, fires and other emergencies blend unnoticed into our communities.

Their leviathan efforts have saved large tracts of NSW from resembling a pretzel forest in the last two weeks and never has their contribution been so appreciated.

The fact there has been no loss of life despite the State being gripped by blazes on multiple fronts says much about their work and their organisation.

Not that their lives are all about sirens, flashing lights and heroic acts. For all the headlines about their remarkable feats in controlling fires and assisting victims, they are just ordinary men and women who have downed tools at home or work and joined the fight.

A large part of their duties involves training and control measures. While two months of summer might provide the adrenalin rush for the firies, the rest of the year, more often than not, requires commitment and just plain hard work.

The waiting game is almost as nerve wracking as the action as I discovered at the SES headquarters in my northern country town this week. The summer stillness, excluding the constant drone of those summer sentinels, the cicadas, was disturbed only when a two-way radio crackled.

Reports of fires burning in the Hunter and further west in the Pilliga scrub were flowing in. Crews were being changed and the possibility of sourcing more firefighters from outside the area was being investigated.

Weather reports a little more detailed than we are accustomed to with the grass curing factor, wind speed and direction, humidity, fire danger and fire rating were pinned near a large wall map, overlaid with plastic with fire scenes coloured in

blue marker pen.

Fire control officer Graham Murrell, whose beat takes in 5100 square kms, points to a large fire burning behind control lines 130km away. Now 63, he's been fighting fires since he was a youngster down on the south coast and, while his time nowadays is spent administering fire fighting efforts, he says there is no such thing as `a quiet time'.

While there may be no major fire in his patch, he is concerned about the proximity of this large forest fire and plans for another two crews to join existing trucks this weekend.

He says the absence of fatalities among fire fighters and citizens this summer is a credit to the streamlined organisation, training and preparation of the Rural Fire Service. Backburning and control burning and vastly-improved weather forecasts have all contributed to the comparatively moderate loss of forest and property.

The contrast with fire fighting `techniques' of 20 years ago in rural areas tells the story. Farmers and willing (but not always able) volunteers would arrive at a fire scene ready to pitch in. Often inadequately clad and driving clapped out or unregistered vehicles, they usually brought a supply of wet bags and brimming enthusiasm.

But the `rabble response' often meant would-be firefighters didn't even know their brigade captain. As sons of the soil, they would think they knew best and conflict would inevitably rise among the ranks.

Nowadays, these well-meaning types are sent home from a fire scene. The attitude of `we'll just turn up' is no longer acceptable. Liability and insurance are influencing factors but efficient command and control have instead taken over.

Scenes of the fires which threatened Sydney's northern suburbs in recent days yielded plenty of `told yer so' comments in the bush.

Most country folk are ready to leap into the argument over controlled burning in our national parks they believe there simply isn't enough. The sight of Lane Cove National Park ablaze elicited plenty of comment about how it was a disaster waiting to happen. The same judgement went for those houses built on the urban bush fringe.

TV footage of one resident, dressed in shorts and T-shirt, on the roof of a house with a garden hose drew derision but it was the picture of a well-meaning Turramurra citizen waving the hose over bushes near the house that moved one firefighter to remark on the utter waste of water.

One diehard I know suggested that the best approach for city parks would be to introduce a drag line, a kind of ultra heavy duty chain used to clear virgin scrub, to make a 300-metre border around them all.

Control burning in the lead-up to summer is also fraught with problems, as evidenced by the tragedy in Sydney's northernmost reaches last year.

Fire control authorities also point to the national parks' lack of resources both financial and material to implement effective control measures. Before a prescribed hazard reduction burn can begin, volunteers must be marshalled along with equipment and suitable measurements of fuel, moisture, wind, temperature, and humidity.

In urban areas, smoke `lodging' (or where the smoke settles) is a major determinant in any proposed control burn. This is without the inevitable objections from elements of the environmental lobby who regard the exercise as `destructive'.

Fire control officers are required to observe a `scorch height' where flames should be no higher than 10 metres, depending on the amount of fuel on the forest floor. But there is always the risk that no firefighter can control that a burn might make it into the crowns of trees.

Amid the tedium and the obstacles, volunteer firefighters are a dedicated bunch. These normally forthright and confident people pause for thought when asked their motivation. Self esteem, satisfaction in helping others and doing a job quietly are some of the replies.

THANKS: The boys in orange and yellow to the rescue once again.

urn:contentItem:4RJT-6160-TX5J-V171-00000-00Hums along nicely thanks2008-01-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisCARSGUIDEPg. 3Hums along nicely thanksMark Hinchliffe

AL GORE will hate you, children will love you, teenagers will envy you and old people will simply be amazed when you drive by in a Hummer H3.

People point and stare, frown and laugh, give a thumbs-up and, in one case in San Francisco, they even spit at the car.

The H3 is certainly a divisive vehicle. Get used to being looked at and judgment passed over you and your vehicle.

Hummer began with the US Army Humvee in the 1991 Gulf War, then gradually became gentrified as people like Arnold Schwarzenegger began buying the civilian H2.

The H3 is the smallest, most civilised and least confronting Hummer yet.

However, it is hardly on Gore's must-buy list with a weight of 2.2 tonnes, a petrol appetite of 13.7 litres every 100km and CO2 emissions of 327g every kilometre.

Over the two weeks and more than 600km I drove the base model manual, my carbon footprint was enormous. In emissions alone, the H3 spewed almost 200kg of CO2 into the atmosphere.

I now owe the planet one small eucalypt plantation.

Owners should be aware that about every 6000-7000km, it will generate its own weight in CO2. But the vehicle can't be written off for environmental reasons.

If you need a vehicle that will cover almost any terrain in comfort, then the H3 has a legitimate job to do and it does it well.

However, if you just want one to pose and/or to deliver the children to All Holiness Very Cross Snotty Nosed Convent, then hang your head in shame.

I have driven the H3 on two continents in all sorts of terrain over the past six months.

In the US I drove it in LA parking lots and on LA freeways (often one and the same), the high mountain passes of Yosemite National Park, the steep hills of San Francisco and the deserts around Las Vegas.

On the Australian launch in the hills surrounding the Yarra Valley wine district, it mastered deep-rutted red soil, overflowing bog holes, sloppy claypans, steep boulder-strewn hills and forest fire trails.

There remained two types of terrain to be conquered: Brisbane potholes and soft sand.

Well, I can tell you that the H3 feels stable and quiet on highways, wallows through corners with a fair amount of body roll and gets jiggly over Brisbane potholes with its off-road-oriented rear leaf springs.

However, plans to take it on to the beach were severely thwarted by the recent no-name cyclone. Instead, it ploughed through some wet sand tracks around Cooloola where it performed admirably.

Soft, dry sand should be no problem. After all, with the right tyre pressure and plenty of momentum most 4WDs run through sand.

Steering is typically American -- vague.

Also, typically American, there is wheel adjustment for height only, not reach, so with a high floor and low seat, it is almost impossible to get comfortable unless you are a Sumatran orangutan.

The American vehicle is built in right-hand drive in South Africa. However, the designers have not done a great job in the left-to-right conversion process.

The heavy rear door is still hinged on the left which means you have to venture out toward passing traffic to load the vehicle.

And the foot-operated parking brake in the American version is replaced by an ancient umbrella-stick handbrake in our RHD model.

These went out with Hawaiian shirts and it's easy to see why. They are impossible to release with a ham fist.

You have to learn the brake's mechanical subtleties then execute a precise series of movements -- pull the button, then turn the handle, release the brake about halfway then wiggle it a bit more to get it all the way in. Don't forget to hold your tongue in the right position, too. Rush it or try to muscle the handbrake and it just won't release.

Handbrake aside, the interior is slightly better than the US version with a classy brushed aluminium centre stack and quality trim.

Yet there are no audio controls on the steering wheel, no auxiliary input for an iPod and there is only one control stalk which services the blinkers, lights, cruise control and wiper/washers. It is cumbersome, but you get used to it.

While door dust-proofing looks underdone, it leaked little on dusty tracks.

The seats are comfortable and look far enough apart to easily fit five adults.

However, because of the high floor your feet sit out in front so there isn't as much room as you would think.

The rear middle seat also has a pull-out drinks container which makes the seat firm and uncomfortable for long stints.

And there is not much room in the back for cargo, again because of the high floor.

But that high floor means plenty of clearance and this is where the H3 excels as over rutted sand and dirt tracks there are no unnerving scraping sounds.

While the floor is high, the roof is low and the windows very narrow.

This creates a claustrophobic feeling in the back and horizontal tunnel vision in the front.

There is also almost no rear vision through the slitty back window with a full-size alloy spare wheel covering a portion of the view.

With no rear parking sensors, it is advisable to be vigilant of children and small animals when backing out of your garage.

Strangely, the flat-fronted Besser-block styling which the engineers admit has not been designed for aerodynamics has little wind or road noise at any speed.

Bodywork is a mixture of metal and plastic.

In silver and black, it looks fine, but in the hero yellow colour, it is easy to see which panels are metal and which are plastic (mainly the fenders) because the colours don't quite match.

The reason for the plastic panels is to keep weight down, reduce scratching from brushes with scrub such as lantana and they are cheaper to replace.

Under the bonnet is a raucous 3.7-litre five-cylinder Vortec petrol engine specially designed to fit the H3. It quietens down at highway speed, but it is a little underdone for the 2.2 tonne vehicle. More appropriate diesel and V8 models are coming in 2009.

It is mated to a five-speed manual which has a truck-like throw without being notchy or vague.

A four-speed auto is available for an extra $2000, but it is slow and hunts around, as well as being even less economical.

The H3 sits on 16 x 7.5 inch alloy wheels with 75 per cent high-profile tyres which are good for ride quality, noise and over rocky terrain, but not much chop for twisty tarmac.

Standard features in the H3 are cruise control, electro-chromatic rearview mirror with eight point compass, power windows, fog lights and halogen headlamps, remote entry with panic alarm, single in-dash CD, cloth seats and 60/40 split rear seats.

VALUE * *

urn:contentItem:57MW-63W1-JD34-V4PB-00000-00Close-up on a star2013-02-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisLIFE & STYLEArts & EntertainmentPg. 14Close-up on a starCINEMA - ACTINGPHILIPPA HAWKER

"I NEVER stop," Jeanne Moreau says on the phone from Paris, in her deep, rich, husky voice. At 85, she is still a busy, energetic figure, a legend of cinema who is not interested in resting on her formidable reputation. She is also a theatre performer, a feature and stage director, a writer and producer, who reels off a list of her projects for this year - films, stage shows and commitments at festivals and at a film school. There are plans, she tells me, to bring a theatre production to Australia next year.

For more than half a century there has been something distinctive, enigmatic and forceful about her presence and her impact on screen. Patti Smith, in an ecstatic piece published in 1977, captured her mixture of introspection and sensuality, stating: "If I turned out like Jeanne Moreau when I grow up, I couldn't ask for anything more. She's so self-contained. She could start a forest fire." In February, the Australian Centre for the Moving Image has a spotlight on Moreau, screening eight of her films from the 1950s and 1960s. The first, from 1958, is Ascenseur Pour L'Echafaud (Elevator to the Gallows). The last, from 1968 - and the only one in colour - is Francois Truffaut's The Bride Wore Black.

There's an earthiness, an elegance and a fierce intelligence in these performances, a constant embrace of contradictions. The camera sometimes dwells on her back, her walk, the line of her body, but most of all it lingers on her singular, memorable face, somehow both expressive and impassive, her distinctive, down-turned mouth, her high forehead. In an interview about a recent film she made with director Francois Ozon, Moreau spoke of that play of oppositions, of being two people when she acted. "There's the one monitoring the distance between me and the camera . . . And there is the one driven by this inner fire, this delicious fear."

Moreau was born in Paris in 1928. Her father was a restaurateur, her mother a dancer. Theirs was a tempestuous relationship, and it brought contrasting influences to bear on her. "My mother was English - she was born in Blackpool - my grandmother was Irish and my father was from the centre of France. I grew up speaking both French and English," she says. "My mother was very lonely. My father's family was very distant with her because she was a foreigner. So English was our language together, and my father hated it when we spoke English because he couldn't understand."

Growing up with two languages "was very rich for me", she says. "It opened me to the world, to literature. To Asian writers, who were translated into English before they were translated into French - and, of course, to American literature." Literature has always been an important part of her life, and many of her closest friends have been writers.

As a child, she recalls, "I loved to study, I had weak health and I read a lot. I wanted to be a ballet dancer, but I gave up that because of the books and plays I read." Wanting to be an actress grew out of a visit to the theatre with some close friends to see Jean Anouilh's modern version of the classic Greek tragedy Antigone, first performed in 1944.

The play's title character made a strong impression on her. "When I heard that girl say 'no' to everything, I said, 'That's for me'."

Moreau studied theatre at the Paris Conservatoire. She spent four years with the Comedie Francaise, then went to the Theatre National Populaire. She had minor roles in several films, beginning in 1949, but it was on stage where she first made her name.

A much-acclaimed performance in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof, directed by Peter Brook, had caught the attention of aspiring filmmaker Louis Malle. He offered Moreau a part in his first film, an adaptation of a crime novel. Her agent advised against it; she took the role and she and the agent parted ways.

Moreau was not typical of many of the actresses who inspired the directors of the new wave, which was about to break in French cinema and have an impact around the world. She was an experienced performer established in a more traditional context, on stage and screen. But she was remade, in a sense, at that time, becoming an incarnation of what Ginette Vincendeau, in her study of French cinema of the period, calls, "the ideology of the new wave: authenticity, modernity and sensuality".

Elevator to the Gallows is the story of a perfect murder that goes wrong in every imaginable way. It's a cool thriller; a mixture of tension and slow, inexorable build. Our first glimpse of Moreau is in a close-up as she speaks on the phone to her lover: it's a raw, yearning image. (Years later, a still would appear on a France Telecom phone card.)

For much of the film, Moreau is essentially alone, wandering the streets of Paris by night, illuminated only by the lights of the city, accompanied by a cool Miles Davis score, wondering what has happened to the plan she and her lover have hatched. It was considered risky, at the time, to be depicted without flattering lighting or obvious make-up, but it established the vividness, the vulnerability, the sheer impact of Moreau's face on screen.

Malle then cast her in Les Amants (The Lovers). She plays a well-heeled provincial wife and mother who leads a materially comfortable existence, at an emotional distance from her husband. She goes regularly to Paris to meet her lover, but she's bored and a little frustrated, even with this handsome, polo-playing suitor in her thrall. Then, suddenly, her life is turned around, disrupted by a new experience of desire.

The film was a box-office hit and the

subject of scandal, most of all for what was regarded as its daring depiction of female pleasure. Much of the controversy concerned a sex scene in which the camera focused on Moreau's ecstatic face.

Following Les Amants, Moreau took a break from the movies, briefly. She had thought, she says, she was simply acting, doing her job - she wasn't ready for what flowed from it. "Now, everybody is a star, people from television, young boys or girls who are on a quiz - but at that time to be a star was something. After the huge success of Les Amants, it frightened me. Because I didn't expect that, when I saw my name all over the place, and I had become a star." To protect herself, she says, she went back to the theatre, but was drawn back to films by the quality of what she was being offered.

Moreau had met young aspiring director Francois Truffaut while at the Cannes film festival with Elevator to the Gallows. At the time, he was an influential, fearless critic who had not yet made his first feature. "I gave him my phone number and we would meet regularly at the same restaurant every week to eat together, and he gave me a copy of Jules et Jim", a screenplay he hoped to make with her.

Truffaut adapted Jules et Jim, his third feature, from a semi-autobiographical novel by Henri-Pierre Roche, about two men in love with the same woman, the perpetually elusive Catherine. She is reckless, impulsive, impossible to pin down, capable of assuming almost any role, female or male.

According to Truffaut, Moreau's "qualities as an actress and a woman made Catherine real before our eyes, made her plausible, crazy, possessive, passionate but, above all, adorable, i.e. worthy of our adoration".

Moreau recalls Jules et Jim as "a very joyful shoot", even though it was made on a shoestring. "At one point we had no money," she says, "but luckily I had made films before, so I became co-producer. And I gave money. There was none left. We did the film with no sound; the only time we had a sound technician was the day we did the song", a famous scene in which she sings a simple, haunting number called Le Tourbillon de la Vie, which became a hit.

Alongside Luis Bunuel's Diary of a Chambermaid, Michelangelo Antonioni's La Notte and Truffaut's The Bride Wore Black - an obvious inspiration, decades later, for Quentin Tarantino's Kill Bill - the ACMI season includes several films that are less widely known.

There is Roger Vadim's slick, modern take on the 18th-century novel Dangerous Liaisons, set in Parisian salons and on alpine ski slopes. In this version, the figures of Valmont (Gerard Philipe) and Madame de Merteuil (Moreau) are already together as a couple, manipulative and knowing, scheming to amuse each other.

It was one of the last films made by Philipe, a star from an earlier generation of French actors, who died a few months later, of cancer, aged 37.

And there's Jacques Demy's second feature, Bay of Angels, a noirish, high-stakes romance of compulsion. Moreau, in Cardin and a cloud of platinum-blonde hair, plays a woman addicted to gambling. She attracts the attention of a sober young bank clerk, who has seen her thrown out of a casino in his home town; he runs into her later, in Nice, during his own cautious exploration of the world of chance.

She's a woman on the edge who, when she has run out of luck, knows how to live extravagantly, but it's gambling she really exists for and she is resigned to the inevitability of loss. It's an unnervingly poignant portrayal of obsession, of a woman who says matter-of-factly she has a young son, but feels that she has probably gambled him away.

Moreau talks about other films of the time that meant a lot to her: Joseph Losey's Eva, Tony Richardson's Mademoiselle - the film that inspired Patti Smith - and she speaks of the four movies she made with Orson Welles, who famously called her "the greatest actress in the world".

She has retained a commitment to working with auteurs, and with emerging directors. "I'm doing another film with a young director, Sandrine Veysset, who will be in Cannes this year. It is called Jeanne dans Tous Ses Etats, and it's a series of stories where I am the main character meeting different people, [played by] Gerard Depardieu, Charles Aznavour and Isabelle Huppert, for example."

In March there is film called La Duchesse de Varsovie, directed by Joseph Morder, in which she plays a concentration camp survivor who has never spoken about her past, and Andy Gillet is the grandson with whom she exchanges secrets. Later in the year she will be at Angers Film Festival, where she has been going for years, and she has a film school at which she teaches every summer.

Recently, she worked on a theatre production dedicated to the playwright Jean Genet, who was a close friend. She is preparing another show about Genet, which will be at the Avignon festival in July, and there is a chance she will bring it to Australia next year.

Moreau is happy to talk about films from the '50s and '60s. It was a time, she says, "when I met exceptional people - they were famous, but famous because of their craft". Yet she's a person who always prefers to look forward, she says, because people learn through literature and through art, through working relationships and friendships. And people continue to learn throughout your life, she adds, describing a recent film, A Lady in Paris, in which she played an elderly Estonian. She was introduced to a culture she knew nothing of, but needed to understand in order to embody the character.

"As I see it, is that at the beginning a young actress relies on her personal knowledge and her personal needs; but afterwards you discover other people, you discover the world."

"Focus on Jeanne Moreau is at ACMI from February 14 to 26, acmi.net.au

urn:contentItem:5560-23C1-F0J6-J3GW-00000-00ELDERS FACES MAZE IN UNRAVELLING RADA DEBTS1988-01-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisINVESTMENTPg. 13ELDERS FACES MAZE IN UNRAVELLING RADA DEBTSIAN McILWRAITH

Elders IXL Ltd, having damped down the Fletcher Challenge-created forest fire threatening its complex move to control NZ Forest Products Ltd, is now dealing with a smaller conflagration over the financial dealings of Rada Corporation Ltd and its associates.

Rada, and its listed subsidiary Prorada Properties, were both suspended on Friday following a newspaper article detailing lending between the two, and involving NZFP.

However, it is understood that Rada's new chief executive, Mr Mike Feeney, has already sent a letter of reply to the NZ Stock Exchange setting out the position of Prorada, which is expected to result in the suspension being lifted later today.

Whether the exchange follows suit with Rada is a different question and may revolve around what information Elders, which is now in control at Rada, puts to the stock exchange.

The Rada developments followed an otherwise successful day for Elders'executive chairman, Mr John Elliott, Elders Resources' chief executive, Mr Geoffrey Lord, and their team of "firefighters".

After two days of negotiation with Fletcher's chief executive, Mr Hugh Fletcher, Elders and NZFP struck deals which will mean tomorrow's extraordinary meeting of NZFP shareholders is likely to be a non-event.

Mr Fletcher requisitioned the meeting in mid-December after NZFP bought Rada's share of their joint venture owning 15 per cent of North Broken Hill Holdings, a deal which Fletcher saw as diminishing the value of its 20 per cent stake in NZFP.

Fletcher submitted seven resolutions to be considered at the meeting, although NZFP is understood to have agreed only to the sixth being put. This called for an extraordinary meeting of NZFP shareholders, and independent valuations, before the finalising of the North BH share deal.

While the extraordinary meeting posed little threat to the agreed merger of NZFP and Elders Resources, legal action begun by Fletcher last week had the potential of disrupting NZFP's takeover of Elders Resources.

Fletcher has now agreed to sell its total holding in NZFP into a joint venture with Elders IXL, the details of which were still being worked out by lawyers over the weekend.

As a result, Fletcher takes a $32 million holding cost loss on selling its 89.7 million shares for $4.25. That is in addition to an earlier loss of $23 million through its purchase of NZFP shares from the AMP Society.

Mr Fletcher described it as an "economic loss", adding that funding details for the joint venture to buy the shares still had to be finalised.

Because the shares are already committed to the joint venture, it is doubtful whether Fletcher will be able to exercise its voting rights on the scrip at tomorrow's extraordinary meeting.

As compensation for its loss of leverage at NZFP, which Fletcher bid for earlier in 1987 but was blocked by the NZ Commerce Commission, NZFP has agreed to sell its Panelcorp business unit to Fletcher for $79 million and for the two companies to rationalise their forest holdings.

The net result of the deal, which involves 15 per cent of NZFP's total forestry estate, is a 20,000 ha gain in planted forestry to Fletcher, bringing its total freehold and leasehold areas up to 140,000 ha, and a transfer to NZFP of $144 million in "financial assets".

These assets apparently take the form of short-term debt securities which NZFP will be able to use.

Meanwhile, Elders is in effect carrying out a non-official receivership of Rada, untangling its debts and matching them against the somewhat diminished value of its investments, before drawing up a refinancing package.

It has been argued that Rada should have been suspended long ago when the extent of its financial difficulties first became known. The company is holding negative shareholders funds, which is why Elders found it easy to relieve Rada's larger shareholders of their stakes at nominal prices and under option agreements.

The problem is that Rada, having grown out of NZFP, has several thousand small shareholders in common with NZFP, all of whom have watched the value of their stake collapse since the sharemarket slide in October.

Elders still needs NZ Commerce Commission and Overseas Investment Commission approvals to officially take control of Rada. However, it would be a brave government authority which refused Elders, because the likelihood is that if it walked away there may be no-one else prepared to refinance the company, leaving thousands of shareholders-cum-voters unimpressed with the Government's performance.

Greenies</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BEVILACQUA SIMON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">They look harmless but these Tassie radicals are ready to start a desperate guerilla campaign Train hijackers Kevin Foley and Bernadette McKenna share a quiet drink near their home in the peaceful environment of Jackey's Marsh</p><p nitf:lede="true">Flashback to last Monday, when green radicals held up a freight train</p><p nitf:lede="true">By SIMON BEVILACQUA THE gaunt, almost waif-like figure of Kevin Foley crouched over a portable typewriter by a campfire in the Tasmanian scrub did not strike terror into the heart.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Sipping a home-brew, putting words to paper by his Jackey's Marsh campfire last week, Foley looked quite harmless, perhaps even timid.</p><p nitf:lede="true">So did his neighbour, Bernadette McKenna as she shared one of his rich brown brews.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But these were the "eco-terrorists".</p><p>They were among the band of 35 radical conservationists who on Monday adopted guerilla tactics and jumped a log train on its way from Launceston to Bell Bay.</p><p>They held the 20-carriage TasRail train at ransom for four hours they demanded media attention and an end to the destruction of the state's forest.</p><p>They called the hold-up an "action".</p><p>More "actions" were in the pipeline, they threatened.</p><p>Others in the Tasmanian community saw it differently, they called the hold up "terrorism".</p><p>The militant greenies were trouble-makers who put forest workers', and their own, lives at risk by fooling with terrorism, it was said.</p><p>Some, including a federal MP, reckoned police should stop dilly-dallying and put a stop to them stamp out the forest fire before it blows out of control.</p><p>Foley and McKenna said they were prepared to be arrested if that meant jail, so be it.</p><p>The demands the renegade train-jumpers made the issues Foley and McKenna got together around the campfire last week to type out for interstate publication were nothing new.</p><p>The people of Tasmania were being told lies by businessmen and large companies, they said.</p><p>The state's forests were being ruined.</p><p>They would put up with it no longer.</p><p>They saw themselves as witnesses of an environmental rape only they were not the sort to stand back and watch as the forest industry did the dirty deed.</p><p>They would not turn their backs.</p><p>"We butt in and do something about it," Foley said.</p><p>It sounded like the same story that divided the state back in the 1980s during the debate over hydro-electric dams.</p><p>For the past 2 years, with the Greens holding the balance of power in state politics, radical conservationists have kept fairly quiet.</p><p>But with the return of a Liberal government this month, and with former premier Robin Gray back as a minister, the radicals are seething.</p><p>Born and raised in south-east Queensland, Foley had already fought Robin Gray and the Liberals.</p><p>He first came to Tasmania before the Gordon-below-Franklin dam dispute and did his bit to help.</p><p>He had been involved in "actions" all over the nation.</p><p>About two years ago, he shifted to Jackey's Marsh, near the northern town of Deloraine, where he lives in a shack prone "to let a little water in when it rains".</p><p>"I came here to live in a beautiful environment, clean air, clean water," he said.</p><p>"But all I see is the carnage of dead animals on the road, all I see is the total destruction of the environment, "And I, like some others, have decided to jump a train or two." Last alligned with a extremist band called the Nomadic Action Group, he now acts as a concerned individual.</p><p>So, said McKenna, did she.</p><p>A qualified teacher, born east of Melbourne, she too had lived at Jackey's Marsh for the past two years and had been involved in actions in South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania.</p><p>Both said they were in phone contact with enough like-minded radicals to stage another train job if it was deemed necessary.</p><p>The band, however, was not a "formal group".</p><p>The idea of a train hold-up had been bandied about for ages. It was fortunate, but purely coincidental, Foley said, that a large number of people were gathered together for the annual Jackey's Marsh Forest Festival the week before.</p><p>Things went from there.</p><p>"A lot of people fantasised about holding up a log train, it was only a matter of time before someone did it," Foley said.</p><p>"We chose it because it had never been done before and it was so visually spectacular." "And that's not the end of it."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>1)Train hijackers Kevin Foley and Bernadette McKenna 2)green radicalsheld up a freight urn:contentItem:49NV-F260-01S8-H4FW-00000-00<published>1995-09-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Wagner runs rings around stage wizardry</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>VAL VALLIS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE music of Richard Wagner and the splendid voice of Marilyn Zschau emerged triumphantly in Seattle Opera's Ring cycle but the production's "audacities" are not entirely dramatic or effective.The cycle, which opened last month, was first seen in this incarnation in 1986, although the epic has been in the company's repertoire since 1975. It yields to a brand new version in 2001.The deceptively modest Opera House - part of a centre that includes separate ballet and live drama theatres - has a seating capacity of 3015. Lined predominantly with timber, the auditorium's acoustics are superb.Top ticket prices averaged between $US90-$US100 ($120-$133) a seat for the four nights, slightly more for singles. The season's three cycles were virtually sold out. They are now given in German, copiously surtitled.Conductor Hermann Michael, presiding over an augmented 107-player-strong Seattle Symphony, revealed his mastery of the work's lyrical aspects. Indeed, on all musical levels this account of the Ring was most satisfying. But the production, directed by Francois Rochaix with sets and costumes by designer Robert Israel, caused much critical consternation and division.When Patrice Chereau revolutionised the Ring cycle at Bayreuth in 1976 (possibly inspired by the George Bernard Shaw essays on Wagner), he had a central historical focus and locale in mind in his 19th-century updating.This Seattle updating didn't reveal any centrality at all despite copious program notes about it. A few examples. The three unwatery Rhine maidens looked like rejects from the back row of a Folies Bergere routine.</p><p>For their definitely last appearance (to drown Hagen at the end of Gotterdammerung) each trailed her personal length of blue cloth - her private stretch of the Rhine, I presume - to enmesh him.Their bum-freezer costumes, plus their horizontal striped stockings could have had some nautical symbolism that this fisherman's son of a critic failed to interpret. Siegfried, in his first entry of his namesake opera, sported the luxury of a live, genuine bear cub as his playmate.The fire-girt rock that Wotan conceded to Brunnhilde's plea at the end of Die Walkure Act III, by the time it was required for her awakening by Siegfried in the next opera, had grown into a handsome mausoleum, in which she later busied herself setting up a comfy honeymoon house for herself and her lover.Indeed, it made quite a different woman of her, too. Marilyn Zschau, so well known to Australian audiences, made a satisfactory, sometimes splendid Brunnhilde in Die Walkure and later in Gotterdammerung - more sheer voice than I remembered from her in Vienna and Sydney in other roles. For Act III of Siegfried, an even slenderer and vocally rapturous Nadie Secunde was awakened by Siegfried's kiss for the glorious duet that culminates the opera. The substitution worked well enough, but a whiff of "just why?" intruded and pervaded.The production let us down, too, at the end of Das Rheingold with the ascent of the gods into Valhalla. The Wotan entourage had to climb a huge ladder up into the surtitle zone, where they stood on a kind of forest fire look-out platform. It was an undignified ascent, particularly for his wife, Fricka, attired in some variant of Lady Bracknell's wardrobe.Where the Seattle Ring scored a major visual triumph was in having its Valkyrie maidens confidently airborne on life-size steeds, and not a single collision on their airy amble, if at a more cautious pace than the barbaric rhythm suggested by Wagner's music for the Ride! Another production mystery that the program promised us was the dragon. It turned out to look for all the world like a city council back-loader, with its frontal scoop full of genuine raging flames. Manned by three or four blackclad stage hands, it was effective enough but like so many other sets and props, once used, it left the stage cluttered up with a lot of irrelevant mess.Still, the final burn-up of practically everything - Brunnhilde, horse and Valhalla was a magnificent piece of theatre wizardry. Erda, the great Earth Mother, in her bedsit comfy chair, looked as though she was waiting for a "telly" to be turned on, instead of foretelling the end of the dynasty of the gods.The scene was redeemed from its deliberately prosaic staging by the thrilling mezzo of Nancy Maultby. She and Joyce Castle, the Waltraute, were the deserved recipients of prolonged applause for their awesome sound.Outstanding in the male casting were Monte Pederson, as Wotan, a bassbaritone equally capable of the authority of the role and the compassion required for the long farewell to Brunnhilde in Walkure Act III; Gordon Hawkins and particularly called on at short notice for the role of Siegfried - Wolfgang Fassler, a young tenor from Hamburg. Julian Patrick's Alberich is a fine study. (It should be. He has been in the 10 presentations of this Ring since it began in 1986.) Finally, for all this production's excitements and audacities, I am still left with the conviction that the more orthodox San Francisco cycle that I covered for The Australian five years ago caught more of Wagner's vision of the rise and fall of the dynasty of the gods.It will be interesting to see what the State Opera of South Australia comes up with in 1998.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier THE BOYDS

A Family Biography

By Brenda Niall

Melbourne University Press, 514pp, $49.95

Every family has a story, but few in modern times can compare with the Boyds, whose ancestors arrived in Melbourne more than a decade before Victoria became an independent colony in 1851.

Such has been their contribution to the cultural life of Australia for more than a century-and-a-half, one sifts through this biography by Brenda Niall to find, perversely perhaps, signs of some renegade spirit who found the responsibility of being a Boyd too much to bear. But in vain. Through all the personas, even those who strayed into the more disturbing shadows of being human, runs a core of certitude about their place in the family's evolution.

By sheer contrast, genealogy can be inconsequential to the destiny of an individual. When the writer Albert Camus was killed in a car accident in 1960, an incomplete manuscript of his last novel was retrieved from the wreckage. Eventually published more than three decades later, it is a thinly disguised autobiography in which Camus describes the search for his father, killed during World War I when the writer was three months old. Anonymity threatened to engulf this component of his being, "an impalpable memory the light ash of a butterfly wing incinerated in a forest fire". Genealogy for the writer did not exist. It had no need.

Anonymity was not a problem for Niall in her beautifully constructed account. Set at its beginning against convicts, free settlers, fortune seekers and dislocated souls that make up the early, non-indigenous story of Australia, she did not, like Camus, have to confront absentia. Her difficulty was the opposite. She needed to prune a virile tree of eloquent achievers patriarchs, matriarchs, painters, potters, sculptor, architect, writers and musicians.

Still she had to create a structure that would not threaten to collapse under its own detail. She remembered a conversation with the distinguished American biographer Leon Edel during his visit to Australia in 1976. Edel was resolving an approach to his forthcoming study of the Bloomsbury group by building his themes around the Bloomsbury "house" itself. Given the ongoing importance with the Boyd family of attaching their collective identity to places and properties, Niall found her ideal solution. She travels with her text through a sequence of houses: from The Grange in Berwick to Yarra Glen outside Melbourne, climaxing with the Shoalhaven properties purchased by Arthur during the 1970s.

Interwoven with this structure are the descendants of four basic branches of the family from their earliest appearance in Australia. There is John Mills, a labourer from Gloucestershire who was convicted of larceny and transported to Van Diemen's Land in 1827, after which he prospered from property purchases in Melbourne and the establishment of its first brewery.

Then comes Sir William a Beckett, who arrived in Sydney with his family in 1837 and moved to Melbourne to become its first Chief Justice in 1851. The third is Dr Robert Martin, a medical practitioner and squatter who came to Melbourne with his family in 1839. And the fourth is Captain John Theodore Boyd, who arrived in Van Diemen's Land in 1845 on military duty supervising a consignment of convicts from London.

Descendants of these four families are linked through marriage and the houses in which they lived. From this warp and weft certain characters emerge with luminosity. Two of the most extraordinary were women without whose presence the integrity and combustion of the Boyd dynasty would have not existed.

John Mills's daughter Emma inherited her father's substantial wealth. She had witnessed tough times. Among privileged society she bore the stigma of a convict father; one who made his fortune as a brewer and hotelier. Yet she carefully deployed that fortune so that all in the family were taken care of. She was the guardian spirit who kept them together for half a century; a woman of fierce compassion towards the poor and needy.

The second was Emma's daughter, Emma Minnie, who married Arthur Merric Boyd. She inherited her mother's humanitarian concerns and intensified them through an alliance with Christian fundamentalism. This had not a little to do with the channelling of artistic energy in her children, in particular towards the moral thrust of her grandsons, Arthur and David, as they explored themes of love and death, violence and justice in their paintings

Both these women, mother and daughter, set in place in their descendants a hard-wired instinct to find strong, talented partners to look after the pragmatic side of the creative life, if not as active participants. Niall guides us through the splendid tapestry of triumphs and tragedies, places and characters, crisply, like a fine novelist from the urgency of young love, when in 1857 Captain Boyd eloped with Lucy Martin, to the obliteration of Penleigh in a car

accident in 1923 to the bizarre hospital death of beloved architect Robin at the age of 51. And Arthur's inspired presentation of Bundanon and Riversdale to the people of Australia in 1992.

Finally, she leaves us to dwell on the essence of the Boyd story symbolised by the full circle between Bundanon and The Grange, both constructed in 1866, concluding with a tribute to the driving conscience for generations to follow: "The diaries are a reminder of Emma's legacies to her descendants: not just the convict fortune, which the years eroded, but the lasting inheritance of her love of Europe, her delight in creativity, her habit of giving, and her attachment to the Australian bush

where her first and best loved house was built."

Wealth and success in the Boyd family never guaranteed a life free of spiritual anxiety. Their great social legacy has been an indelible purpose of responsibility towards family, towards a consolidation of heritage and towards humanist ideals and community.

This has been paralleled, however, by a certain ambiguity of belonging which would seem to contradict the Boyd obsession with embracing family legacy within a singular sense of place. Most of the Boyds have felt that a part of them belonged elsewhere than Australia, dividing their time and hearts between hemispheres. Niall leaves this question for us to unravel. It is a tribute to her narrative skill, however, that all the personalities she has explored whatever their frailties and strengths, whatever their dreams, noble or misguided combine to elicit love and respect for a family whose like we shall never

see again.

urn:contentItem:4P85-1CT0-TXN5-R3DS-00000-00New wave of fires feared1998-02-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESInternational NewsPg. 21New wave of fires feared* INDONESIA AsiaLOUISE WILLIAMS Herald Correspondent in Jakarta

Indonesia may be facing a new haze and forest-fire disaster following the outbreak of fresh blazes in the tinder-dry forests of Kalimantan this week and warnings from experts that the El Nin~o effect will peak again over the next few months.

Flights were delayed by smoke haze in East Kalimantan this week for the first time since rains eased the region-wide haze crisis in mid-November. And an Australian forestry expert warned that past El Nin~o patterns showed that a second round of fires usually followed inadequate monsoon rains.

Mr Neil Byron, the deputy director of the Indonesia-based Centre for International Forestry Research, said a study of the past 200 years of forest fires and El Nin~o patterns in Indonesia indicated that a second, more severe phase preceded the ending

of the 12-month El Nin~o cycle.

Indonesia's Assistant Minister for the Environment, Mr Sugandhy Apandi, said: "We can assume, from the meteorological information we are receiving, the drought is continuing. The source of the new fires is the negligence of people clearing land and we are afraid because of the El Nin~o effect we will face a new disaster."

Mr Sugandhy said that despite recent rains in Java, both Kalimantan and northern Sumatra - which lie above the equator - had received little rainfall, and the severe economic crisis might encourage the over-utilisation of natural resources and the use of fire as a cheap method of clearing land.

A new phase of the drought - the most severe to hit Indonesia in 50 years - would also have serious implications for food supplies because most agricultural crops are expected to be harvested late and in reduced volumes, while the economic crisis is

forcing millions of people out of work.

The massive fires which raged from July to November last year, spreading smoke haze as far south as Darwin and north to the Thai border, were mainly caused by land clearing for the expansion of palm oil and timber estates and the burning off of debris from logging concessions.

Mr Sugandhy said the new fires this week were deliberately lit for land clearing. Satellite images provided to the Indonesian Environment Ministry show 40 fires burning along a nine-kilometres front inside the Bukit Soeharto preservation area and several smaller fires near rural villages.

Mr Byron said: "The next three to four months are an absolute time bomb. During the 1982-83 El Nin~o year, three-quarters of the fire damage was done between January and April, and these were the biggest fires ever recorded on Earth."

During 1982-83, fires destroyed 3.7 million hectares of forest on Kalimantan. The fires last year destroyed an estimated 1.2 million hectares of tropical forest.

"Whenever there is an El Nin~o you get a dry period which extends into October, then you get some rain which is 30 to 40 per cent of normal falls and then the drought comes back between January and April," Mr Byron said. "We know from Portuguese explorers' logs that there have been El Nin~os in this region for at least 500 years because there are references to haze from peat swamps, but the difference now is large-scale logging and plantation development."

He said land which had been damaged by logging was eight to 10 times more likely to burn than virgin tropical forest, and that fire was widely used for land clearing in Indonesia because it was about a quarter of the cost of any other method.

In the 1960s, 82 per cent of Indonesia's land cover was virgin tropical forest. Recent estimates put forest cover at 53 per cent, including plantations of timber, palm oil and rubber. Between 800,000 and 1.2 million hectares of forest is cleared annually in Indonesia, raising serious concerns about environmental damage as water-shed areas disappear and wet-season rains cause massive erosion of top soil in the run-off into rivers and the sea.

"We are still traumatised by what happened several months ago and I am very worried about lung diseases caused by the smoke," said Wiwin, a teacher in Samarinda, near the new fire zone.

Another resident, Didi, a hotel employee, said: "It hasn't rained in two months and I'm worried about the chance of the recurrence of the fires. I am still relaxed, but I have taken the oxygen mask out of the closet just in case."

The Australian Bureau of Meteorology (BOM) said the El Nin~o effect appeared to be declining over Australia, with increased rainfall in the north.

"There are indications that the declining phase has commenced," said Mr Terry Hart, the acting head of the BOM's National Climate Change Centre. "We saw a sharp drop in the Southern Oscillation Index from December to January, but looking back through the records it is apparent that such a drop is often followed by a rising trend in the following months."

Mr Byron said the impact of the next "spike" in the El Nin~o effect depended entirely on how people behaved on the ground and whether they heeded warnings not to burn to clear land. "The Indonesian Government should be on red alert. What is making us very nervous is wheth-er or not the economic crisis will encourage people to try to expand land-clearing activities."
