urn:contentItem:457Y-MJC0-0197-5395-00000-00<published>1997-10-27T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FULLPAGE, FEATURES; Pg. 11</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Eternal contradictions stifle the tigers </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>CHRISTOPHER LINGLE and TERESA WYSZOMIERSKI</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Asia's economic powerhouses were built on faulty foundations and now the cracks are becoming obvious</p><p nitf:lede="true">   WHEN Ronald Reagan referred to the Soviet regime as the "evil empire", few realised that he had identified the cause for its inevitable demise. In other words, a system with fatal internal contradictions cannot endure. While this is not to suggest that South-East Asia is inherently evil, the financial and environmental crises that are overwhelming the region call for a critical examination of so-called "Asian democracy" that purportedly made economic success possible for the tigers in the first place.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Asian democracy distinguishes itself from its Western counterpart because it accommodates values that are supposedly peculiar to the Asian character.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Purportedly these include thrift, a strong work ethic, respect for authority as an extension of filial piety, emphasis on family cohesiveness, "face-saving" and the subordination of individual rights to communal welfare.</p><p> At first glance, it's hard to imagine how these values could become a recipe for economic disaster. After all, each of them has found expression in the West, albeit to varying degrees, and has contributed to economic success in North America and Europe. Why, then, have these values produced such different economic results in the Asian and Western democratic context?</p><p> The short answer is that the SouthEast Asian mix has given rise to a political system that is unable to efficiently allocate economic resources by stifling the self-adjusting mechanisms of their economies.</p><p> Take thrift and a strong work ethic, for example. The mobilisation of vast pools of cheap, unskilled labor combined with a high rate of saving in most of East Asia are generally identified as important factors in the region's economic success.</p><p>However, this cultural propensity to save was amplified by government-imposed forced saving. This involved a combination of high payroll taxes and an emphasis on producing goods for export rather than for domestic consumption.</p><p>An export-led strategy could work as long as demand in the advanced economies remained buoyant, but failed as sales in North America and Europe dropped and inter-regional demand was unable to pick up the slack.</p><p> Furthermore, most governments neglected to reinvest revenues into education so that workers with upgraded skills could produce more competitive, value-added products. Instead, SouthEast Asia's governments spent the money, in numerous instances, on various useless construction projects and, more recently, on futile interventions in the foreign currency markets.</p><p> As in South-East Asia, Western political institutions feature hierarchical structures that are designed to facilitate efficient decision-making. However, many Asian governments have deftly exploited their citizens' Confucian sense of filial piety into an unquestioning respect for authority.</p><p> Without a credible system of checks and balances, politicians and government bureaucrats become entrenched as they are not accountable for their actions until a crisis erupts. Even then, accountability may prove elusive. As every diplomat knows, saving face is a dignified way to correct an offender while avoiding confrontation. However, this same approach can be subverted into a political dodge for avoiding responsibility.</p><p>  A  PRIME example is the approach South-East Asia's leaders took toward Indonesia's ongoing forest fire emergency. Instead of pressuring President Suharto to mitigate pollution damage to the region, they circled the wagons and uttered hardly any criticism of their autocratic brother until it became clear that an overwhelming groundswell of popular outrage demanded a denunciation.</p><p> Both East and West see the maintenance of strong family and personal ties as a stabilising influence on society. The opposite is true when familial relations become nepotism and when personal connections, or guanxi, metastasise into graft and corruption.</p><p> Many East Asian policy-makers intervened in the development of domestic capital markets so as to favour local banks. Heavy regulation led to a stunted bond market. This allowed the regimes to direct lending towards preferred areas for development and facilitated the provision of privileged loan access to political supporters. Losses from bad debts have dealt a severe and lasting blow to most of South-East Asia's financial system.</p><p> Perhaps the most uniquely Asian value is giving priority to the welfare of the community over that of the individual. This altruistic notion of society above self was translated into "prosperity first, rights later" by regional leaders and used as a justification for restricting citizens' civil liberties.</p><p> This precluded the development of an institutional framework capable of supporting sustained economic growth.</p><p>Restrictions on political speech went hand-in-hand with a lack of financial transparency on the part of business and government, with predictably disastrous results for investors and voters alike.</p><p> Concentrating power in paternalistic autocrats may have seemed like an expeditious way to set and execute economic priorities, but this lack of separation between the executive and judicial branches of government stunted the development of a credible rule of law in many Asian democracies.</p><p> Will South-East Asia's tigers survive the financial crisis? The inherent resilience of the Asian character will see that they do. Will the Asian democratic model endure? Probably not, as long as it remains a euphemism for autocracy.</p><p>Based on the schizophrenic notion that markets can be free while politics is not, Asian democracy is destined to fail.</p><p> Co-written by attorney Teresa Wyszomierski. Christopher Lingle is visiting associate professor of economics at Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, Ohio, and wrote The Rise and Decline of the Asian Century (1997).</p><p>Christopher Lingle  Asia analyst</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P85-12R0-TXN5-R2X9-00000-00Soeharto faces IMF ultimatum1997-10-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 1Soeharto faces IMF ultimatumLOUISE WILLIAMS in Jakarta and JENNIFER HEWETT in Washington

President Soeharto faces increased International Monetary Fund pressure to set aside national pride and family business considerations to prevent corporate defaults triggering an economic free-fall in Indonesia.

Analysts said yesterday that the Jakarta Government would be seeking strategies from the IMF for bailing out some of the country's corporate empires from crippling US dollar debt repayments following the dramatic devaluation of the rupiah.

A World Bank official in Indonesia, Mr Dennis de Tray, said "quite a large team" of top level IMF officials would begin arriving in waves over the weekend and be active by Monday. They would focus on rebuilding the foreign exchange market and restoring economic confidence.

The IMF is expected to increase pressure for the scrapping of Indonesia's controversial national car project, which granted exclusively tax and tariff concessions to President Soeharto's son, Hutomo "Tommy" Mandela Putra, as well as the expensive national program to develop an Indonesian jet, controlled by the powerful Minister for Technology and close presidential ally, Dr Jusuf Habibe.

Monopolies on staple products such as rice and flour are also likely to be challenged and analysts said the overcrowded and under-performing banking sector must face a shake-out which will see closures and mergers.

Details of the IMF assistance effort have not yet been announced. It contributed $US3.9 billion ($A5.41 billion) to a $US17.2 billion international bail-out for Thailand and analysts in Singapore say a loan to Indonesia could be $US4 billion to $US6 billion. Construction sites across Jakarta have fallen silent this week as major developers, facing substantial short-term debts, have suspended work. Australian companies are reporting the non-payment of bills by many Indonesian customers.

According to the Central Bank, Indonesia's private sector had $US55 billion of outstanding foreign debt at the end of last year, almost two-thirds of which was short-term and due to be repayed within the next three months.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, said in Washington yesterday that Australian will give careful consideration to any formal request for assistance from Indonesia.

"We do have confidence in the fundamental economic situation in South-East Asia," he said.

"There are obviously some specific difficulties at the moment, but we do believe these will be overcome in time."

Figures for September show a 70 per cent decline in imports, dropping from the usual $2.5 billion to $750 million because of the plunge in the value of the rupiah, the official Antara news agency reported yesterday.

The agency quoted Amiruddin Saud, chairman of the All Indonesia Association of Importers, as saying the fall came about as many manufacturers cut back on purchases of raw materials and intermediate goods.

Although manufacturers had maintained stocks for present needs, prolonged weakness in the rupiah would hurt the manufacturing sector.

"If the Government does not immediately overcome the monetary crisis, it will not be unlikely that in the long run it will threaten domestic industries, particularly textiles," he was quoted as saying.

Economists said the IMF's assistance was essential to avoid the disastrous social and political consequences of widespread lay-offs when Indonesia is facing crop reductions due to the drought, the continuing forest fire crisis, and heightened political volatility ahead of next year's presidential elections.

Growth forecasts have already been revised down and price increases have been mooted for politically sensitive food items, and for kerosene and petrol.

Both the stock and money markets reacted modestly to the IMF announcement with the rupiah moving from 3,640 to the US dollar to 3,565 and the stock market gaining just under 1 per cent as foreign and Indonesian players waited for more details.

The IMF managing director, Mr Michael Camdessus, said: "The IMF strongly supports the approach that has been followed by Indonesia, which sees this as an occasion to strengthen its economic policies even if fundamentals are basically sound."

An economist, Mr Christianto Wibisono, said in Jakarta: "Indonesia now has to be mentally ready to face the consequences and put itself on a strict diet. There's no use in pursuing nationalist policies like the car and the plane if they cost too much.

"If the corporates go bankrupt lots of people will lose their jobs, there will be political turbulence and social riots. So our position is one of whether or not we want to survive. We have no choice."

Japan's Finance Minister, Mr Hiroshi Mitusuka, said yesterday that he was liaising closely with the IMF and the World Bank on any plan that may be drawn up, but so far Japan had not been asked to provide assistance.

Japan's banks have invested $US38 billion in Indonesia since 1967 and for more than a decade Japan has been Indonesia's biggest foreign aid donor, handing over around $US900 million a year.

The English-language Jakarta Post said in its editorial yesterday: "The IMF could insist on thorough economic reforms that Indonesia has needed all along, but the Government has not been willing or able to implement. It may be a bitter pill, but if that is what is needed to cure our economic ills, then so be it."

An economist said Indonesia's new middle class would be hard hit by high interest rates which have pushed home mortgage rates to over 30 per cent, and would be likely to become increasingly critical of Government corruption and favouritism.

urn:contentItem:44X5-PJN0-0045-53PS-00000-00<published>2002-01-14T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A;</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Our urban forest is worthy of admiration</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JOHN LAYTON'S observations of Canberra's trees ('Our tree mix is pretty right', Letters, 7 January) has, hopefully, encouraged Canberrans to look around and admire the city's excellent urban forest and perhaps praise the succession of landscapers whose foresight has brought this about.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Our forest unifies this widespread city even though close inspection shows suburbs have their own tree characters that culminate from decisions dating back to Canberra's beginnings. This diversity is the result of many influences, including the progressive introduction of new species; the deletion of others that have proved to be less than desirable; maintenance costs; and the changing popularity of species, which, like fashions, waxes and wanes over time.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A tree planted today with a useful life of 80 to 100 years may be in and out of favour with future generations. Belconnen is a good example. It was largely established to native eucalypts at a time of a major surge in public interest in native plants and the decline of many exotic trees following the drought of the late 1960s.</p><p>Barrie Smillie ('Elms and planes kinder than gums', Letters, 31 December) now suggests that these same eucalypts are filthy, ugly, incapable of producing useful shade and too expensive to maintain. Some residents like the attractive bark types and the irregular silhouettes of eucalypts as much as others appreciate the autumn colours of the exotic deciduous trees. Further, research at the ANU School of Resources, Environment and Society suggests that the cost of maintaining eucalypts and exotics may be the same over their 80-year life spans, although the timing of these costs will differ.</p><p>The people of Canberra have to plan the types of trees they want both now and for the 80 years of future forest they are committing themselves and their children to look at and maintain.</p><p>(Drs) JOHN BANKS and CRIS BRACK Forestry, School of Resources, Environment and Society, ANU<br/> <br/>Maples better in case of fire</p><p>TONY BARTLETT, director of ACT Forests, says (Letters, 10 January) that the burnt pine trees near Yarramundi Reach must be cleared because the pines will die due to the fire damage. Doesn't it therefore make sense, in this area of national significance that is mostly useful for recreation rather than forestry, to plant trees that are not very susceptible to catching fire?</p><p>Deciduous trees are usually much less susceptible to fire due to moister leaves, less dead wood, and less oily sap. Fires hardest to control will occur in pine and eucalypt, especially forestry pine, with branches and remains of the last harvest still on the forest floor.</p><p>In America it is frequent to recommend planting such trees as maples as being much easier to defend against fire. While a maple can be damaged by fire it is much less likely to catch fire in the first place and such a fire is much easier to put out.</p><p>And what would be more attractive than a grove of Canadian red maples on the shore of the lake?</p><p>CHRIS BITMEAD Kambah<br/> <br/>Experience in plantations vital</p><p>MR TONY BARTLETT, director of ACT Forests, waxes lyrical in satisfaction that the forestry fire-fighting workforce actually increased from 21 to 26 this year (CT, 10 January, p.1). Big deal; it is worth noting that this number is only half of what it was some 10 years. Forestry back then led the field in the ACT with bushfire management, experience and suppression capability.</p><p>Bushfire fighting in pine plantations is extremely hazardous, and experience, in particular a knowledge of the layout of the plantations and of pine-forest-fire behaviour, is essential; only those working full-time in the pine forests can achieve that expertise.</p><p>No matter how dedicated, trained and efficient firefighters may be (and our volunteers and urban brigade firefighters certainly are) we can never replace that plantation expertise so vital for safe and effective pine-forest wild-fire suppression.</p><p>VAL JEFFERY Tharwa<br/> <br/>Unfair blaming is not productive</p><p>I AGREE with Mr Val Jeffery ('Best interests of community', Letters, 9 January)that the Conservation Council and all other representatives on the Bush Fire Council have always worked constructively, productively and with respect for all views expressed around the table. This was the case for the 1995 Task Force, which reviewed ACT bushfire-fuel management practices, on which both Mr Jeffery and the Conservation Council were represented. The Task Force rightly considered the protection of life and property and environmental and conservation issues.</p><p>After fiery debate, the Task Force made 24 recommendations about fuel management, resulting in the 1998 ACT Bushfire Fuel Management Plan, which was subject to community consultation.</p><p>Mr Jeffery knows that if he has concerns about a perceived lack of strategic fuel management, as required under the Fuel Management Plan, the ACT fuel-management committee would like to hear about it.</p><p>The Conservation Council becomes concerned when unsubstantiated accusations are made against 'greenies', government and bureaucrats for hindering or not undertaking fuel management. This is not consistent with Mr Jeffery's claim of 'a productive relationship of mutual respect', and it is certainly not in the 'best interests of the community' for community leaders like Mr Jeffery to randomly and unfairly point the bone at other sectors.</p><p>GEOFF BUTLER Conservation Council of the SE Region & Canberra<br/> <br/>NSW first to have a 'national park'</p><p>THE EXTENSIVE fires at the Royal National Park, the third big burn in just over a decade, raise concerns about 'a crisis in fire-management' (Simon Grose, CT, 9 January, p.11). Grose repeats a common misconception, that Yellowstone, in the United States, was the world's first national park, and Australia's Royal was the second. Yellowstone was not the first, even in the USA. Yosemite National Park was created eight years earlier, in 1864, but neither Yellowstone nor Yosemite used the term 'national park' in their legislation.</p><p>The world's first legislation for a national park was passed by NSW on 31 March 1879, dedicating the National Park at Sydney (made Royal in 1955). It is time to grab our history back. The Royal National Park is the world's oldest legislated park, and its complex fire ecology, aggravated by proximity to a major city, deserves sophisticated fire research that acknowledges and integrates understandings about both the people of Sydney and their park.</p><p>The 'separatist' national parks ideal of the 1970s is not what we need. Only a conservation biology that embraces the whole landscape will help us understand the regular and irregular patterns of fire through this heathland.</p><p>Let's not describe it as 'destroyed'. We know it is not, but if we want to maximise biodiversity we need to research its history, both national and local.</p><p>LIBBY ROBIN O'Connor Editor's note: Simon Grose's information came from World Book Encyclopaedia, which says Yosemite was established in 1894.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4DRF-23P0-0045-52BK-00000-00<published>2004-11-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A;</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Saving Asia's gentle giants THE ENVIRONMENT</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>The Canberra Times</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">T HE VOICE on the other end of the telephone is calm and measured, until asked to describe what actuallyhappens when forests in Borneo are illegally cleared to establish oil palm plantations.There is a pause, an audible intake of breath."I can describe this, but I warn you, it is very hard for me to stay objective," Dr Willie Smits, founder and executive director of the Borneo Orangutan Survival Foundationsays.His voice rises in anger as he explains how a large tract of forest is cleared by fire - "the cheapest way of clearing", forcing the wildlife to flee and crowd into the remaining patches of jungle for safety."Then the gangs move in, they start pushing over the trees and the killing spree begins. They kill the adult orangutans and they take the babies for the pet trade. "We confiscated one adult from some hunters that had a bullet lodged 2mm from her heart."Some of the orangutans have had their hands and arms cut off, or their heads smashed in."When you come across that sort of damage, when you have looked into the eyes of an orangutan and see the beam of intelligence there, just like human eyes - well, it's hard not to hate the guys who do these dreadful things."You struggle not to become a fanatic and to look at the bigger picture. It takes all your training as a scientist to stay objective because that's what you must do.</p><p>But, it's hard at times, very hard."Dr Smits politely asks if it is possible to "remind people in Australia to check any products containing oil palm to see where it is grown". Check margarine, shampoo, soaps and cosmetics, he says."Ring the companies and ask where they obtain the palm oil. They should not support the illegal clearing of orangutan habitat."After finding a badly burned orangutan in the wake of an illegal forest fire, Dr Smits, who was then working as a forest ecologist in Indonesia, founded the Borneo OrangutanSurvival Foundation (BOS) in 1991. With well-known primate scientist, Dr Jane Goodall as its patron, BOS has become the world's largest not-for-profit primate conservation organisation.Based in Indonesia, the organisation protects, rescues and rehabilitates orangutans,as well as training researchers and employing local families in its numerous conservation projects."It is not the local people who are behind the destruction of the forests and wildlife. It is the big guys, with big money from corruption usually backing them," Dr Smits says.While conservation has become a safely distanced policy game (with meetings, conferences, position papers) for many environment groups, Dr Smits is literally right at the front of one of the world's most intensely fought and highly dangerous conservation battles.In the fight to save orangutans from poachers, illegal logging, massive forest fires and the illegal pet trade, he is constantly risking his life.He has taken on corrupt officials in the Indonesian army and police forces, governmentbureaucrats prepared to bend rules for lucrative bribes, rich movie stars and influential members of Asia's business community."Yes, it can be dangerous. I have had hundreds of death threats and, recently, I had to move my family again," he says."You are dealing with people with guns who get very aggressive when you come to take the orangutan babies away from them. The situation can be very tense and ugly."He has received numerous international awards (and a knighthood from the Netherlands)for his conservation work and is currently pioneering the use of satellite technology to save orangutan habitat."We are able to monitor for illegal logging in Indonesia's forests. The old system of ground checks is too slow, and forest conservation management data is often exaggerated."In central Kalimantan, BOS manages 330,000ha of forest which is home to 3000 wild orangutans."We are also looking after 600 orangutan babies at our centre, but for me, this is not a mark of our success. That so many orphaned orangutans exist, is proof that we are failing in our fight to stop the illegal pet trade. More must be done." Borneo, home to the world's rapidly diminishing orangutan population, has lost 80 per cent of its rainforest in the past two decades. Less than 50,000 orangutans survive in the wild, but with an estimated annual mortality rate of over 6000 a year, some experts are predicting the orangutan will become extinct in the wild within the next 10 years.A typical example of illegal trade surfaced two months ago in Thailand. A raid on a Bangkok zoo and amusement park uncovered more than 100 orangutans, used for zoo displays and to stage Thai boxing matches for visitors.The zoo initially told police its orangutanshad been bred in captivity from 14 adults purchased before 1992, when the orangutan trade was banned.Scientists were called in to conduct DNA tests on hair and saliva, to determine if the orangutans were bred from zoo stock or smuggled in from Indonesia. The zoo subsequently admitted most the orangutans were illegally obtained.But, facing charges for breaching the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES), to which Thailand is a signatory, almost half the zoo's orangutans mysteriously went missing.Zoo officials claimed the animals had died, but police later discovered the missingorangutans hidden in the Safari World's quarantine quarters."People want orangutan babies as a status symbol or for amusement. It is a sick trade and one which is fed by corruption in high places. There are about $1 billion worth of animals smuggled out of Indonesia every year. That sort of money will tell you that it is not poor village people driving this trade," Dr Smits says.As well as running BOS, he lectures in forest ecology at Indonesian universities and established the Wanariset forestry research station on Borneo. The institute has developed reforestation techniques that have been adopted by the Indonesian government.He is currently working on a land management model - a "debt for nature" swap to acquire land to be used both as a nature refuge and for voluntary carbon offset agreements."When you look into the eyes of an orangutan, you can see emotion. They are so much like us, with so much of our DNA that it is scary."The young are dependent on their mothers for seven years, so when they are ripped away from the mothers you can imagine the fear, the panic and the loss," he says."This is not just an emotive appeal. If we lose the orangutan - if we let this happen through the fires, the illegal clearing for oil palm and the pet trade - we will also lose something of our humanity."Dr Smits is visiting Australia to promote International Orangutan Awareness Week and will give a free public lecture at ANU's School of Botany and Zoology at 1pm this Wednesday. For more information on BOS see <url normalizedValue="http://www.orangutans.com.au">www.orangutans.com.au</url></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4M3T-05S0-TX52-J26S-00000-00MEGA BUSHFIRES2006-10-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 33MEGA BUSHFIRESBIGGER, HOTTER, FASTER AND COMING...DANNY BUTTLER

All the conditions are in place: dry fuel, dry air and parched ground. Add some hot weather and we face firefighters' greatest fear -- the megafire. DANNY BUTTLER reports

MEGAFIRES -- they are bigger, hotter, faster and like nothing Australia has ever seen.

On the cusp of what could be the worst Victorian fire season in history, the megafire phenomenon is worrying even the most grizzled fire-fighting veterans.

First identified in the US, these massive infernos scorched 3.6 million hectares during the American summer last year.

Continued Page 34

From Page 33

Megafires are a series of large wildfires that merge into a monstrous blaze authorities are helpless to control.

With global warming leaving our bushland in a similarly vulnerable position to the US, fire crews in Victoria are gearing up for the fight of their lives.

Conditions this season are even worse than before the Ash Wednesday inferno of 1983 -- up to five times worse.

Kevin O'Loughlin from the Bushfire Co-operative Research Centre says if Australia follows the US trend, we could experience Ash Wednesday-style fires or even worse on a regular basis.

''What the Americans are saying is that these really major fires seem to be happening more regularly,'' he says.

''Something like seven out of 10 of the worst fires in their history have happened in the last 10 years.

''What was regarded as the extreme is now the normal and we are going to have to adjust.''

And O'Loughlin is not alone in claiming a single spark could ignite a catastrophe in Victoria.

THE Department of Sustainability and Environment's chief fire officer, Ewan Waller, has been battling fires for 32 years, but he's never seen anything like the present conditions.

''We are really concerned -- we are probably coming into the worst season I have ever faced,'' he says.

''Because it's been 10 years (of drought) . . . even 1982-83 was a short burst of very dry weather, only one or two years, but the underlying dryness now is so much more severe.''

The Country Fire Authority's chief officer, Russell Rees, says climate change has made the days of a ''good'' fire season a thing of the past.

''For me, the notion of an easy year is basically a distant memory,'' he says.

Rees says the root of the problem can be found a few centimetres below the ground where soil moisture is at all-time lows.

''Over the last 10 years the cumulative deficit of moisture means the soil moisture is very low, therefore our fuel dries off very rapidly,'' he says.

''But it also means our heavier fuels -- branches, logs et cetera -- are all very dry. So you get two things happening -- our general fire fuels, like grass, leaves and twigs, are very dry, and secondly, the logs and branches are also dry so the fire intensity is increasing.

Continued Page 35

''So fires are becoming more intense and therefore more difficult to control.''

Climate change is being blamed for the unprecedented conditions both here and in the US.

Massive fires have also scorched Europe in recent times.

The CSIRO has predicted extreme forest fire conditions in Victoria could increase by up to 25 per cent over the next decade. By 2050, fire risk in southeast Australia could rise by up to 70 per cent.

This is on top of Victoria already ranking with California and southern Europe as the most bushfire-vulnerable areas in the world.

THE changing weather patterns not only make fires more intense, but prevent vital fuel reduction burns in autumn.

''There's definitely something that is making forest fires harder to control,'' the DSE's Ewan Waller says.

''What we are finding is, like last year, we didn't get the autumn break to dampen down the fuels so we could burn more safely.

''We only got about half the days we normally would,'' he says.

It's recipe for disaster.''

The changing conditions have forced a major rethink, as fire crews realise traditional firefighting techniques don't work on megafires.

Water tankers, aerial bombardment and backburning can be useless once these fires take hold.

Calling the CFA or even Elvis the huge water-bombing helicopter might not help. Praying for rain could be the best bet.

''Last year was one of (America's) worst years ever -- nine million acres -- a lot of those were megafires; once they get a roll on they are very hard to control,'' Waller says.

''It's like what happened in the alpine fires: we just have to pull back and protect homes and private assets until things die down and we have another go.''

The sight of blackened firefighters spraying water on a raging fire front will be seen less as fires become more intense.

''The way to attack those sort of fires is to come from behind. You flank them -- you can't get in front of them because it is too dangerous,'' he says.

''Until they abate for some reason -- the wind dies or you might get a shower of rain or the fuel type changes -- then you can get around in front of them.''

Eucalypt forests bursting with flammable oil and difficult wind conditions make our part of the world a dangerous place to live.

But the CFA reckons the call-out sirens would be a lot quieter if it wasn't for one factor -- people.

''I always say there are three main causes of fire -- men, women and children,'' the CFA's Russell Rees says.

''You can have extremely bad weather, extremely dry fuel and no ignitions -- so you don't have fires.

''So we plead with people to avoid the circumstances which cause fires in the first place.''

While firebugs continue to be a major cause of concern, most bushfires are lit by accident, carelessness or a combination of the two.

''A campfire, working with materials that generate heat, a spark from a grinder, a welder or even a trailer with overheated bearings,'' he says. ''You have someone mowing long, dry grass on a stinking hot day. Is that really essential?''

But people being people, not too many CFA volunteers will be expecting a smoke-free summer.

And adding to their woes is a growing concern in many areas about a lack of fire crews.

CHANGING demographics in the bush means there are far fewer people in many regions and other areas are being populated by older treechangers from the city.

''There are parts of the state where it is becoming hard to get volunteers,'' Rees says.

''Our pressure points for volunteers are in rural areas and where there is now significant treechangers and seachangers.

''People are retiring into those areas and availability is often from people in their 50s and beyond.

''The normal person who would be a community member and volunteer is being pushed out by affluent treechangers and seachangers who impact on the ability of a community to sustain an essential fire brigade.''

If the megafires do scorch Victoria, our already dire water shortage could hit crisis point.

Burning catchments are a disaster for water supplies, with fire residue polluting water on a massive scale.

''Imagine you had one of those fires in the water catchment of a major city,'' O'Louglin says.

''We know from the Canberra fires that the water supply there was ruined for about 18 months.

''If it burns through the catchment you have ash and dust and then if it rains it washes ash and mud into the reservoirs.

''That was the experience of the 1939 fires; it affected the water supply for decades.''

Despite the doomsday talk, fire authorities are anxious not to cause panic among the people they are charged with keeping safe.

O'Loughlin says widespread controlled burns are the best alternative to letting nature run its course.

''The option of doing nothing is not an option,'' he says.

''We're not talking about things that are 30 years away . . . and the potential consequences for our natural resource management could be catastrophic.''

urn:contentItem:4P0N-K0N0-TXN5-S27W-00000-00How bushfire report got it wrong: the QC's verdict2004-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3How bushfire report got it wrong: the QC's verdictSteve Waldon, Melissa Marino

It was never going to be pretty, but when Athol Hodgson and David Packham stopped blinking at the desolation before them, they realised they were looking at a catastrophe.

In the tombstoned rows of burnt cypress pine they figured they were seeing a landscape forever altered by a bushfire so intense that there are no seeds left from which saplings can spring.

With 90 years' experience in bushfire research and forest management between them, the men were still dismayed by the scene last week at Willis, near the Victorian border with NSW.

They have visited this spot every six months since the bushfires in January 2003 that razed 1.3 million hectares of land, much of it in the state's north-east, and other than some native grasses and a few hardy white box, the scene remains bleak. "It's heartbreaking - like looking at death," Mr Hodgson said.

He and Mr Packham are among the many who believe the bushfires need not have burned so long and with such ferocity. So they joined the Stretton Group, a committee of affected farmers and experts in forestry and fire management formed late last year in response to the official Victorian Government inquiry into the devastating fires.

Their lobbying has now received the imprimatur of Melbourne Queen's Counsel Allan Myers, who has condemned the inquiry by Emergency Services commissioner Bruce Esplin.

In an assessment for which he was not paid, Mr Myers concludes that a coronial inquiry or royal commission on the fires would have been appropriate, and would still be justified.

The Stretton Group intends to use Mr Myers' review to pressure Attorney-General Rob Hulls to order a coronial inquiry. Failing that, they regard Mr Myers' opinion as the basis for an application to the Supreme Court.

Mr Myers, the new president of the National Gallery of Victoria's trustees, has described the inquiry and subsequent report as seriously deficient, "amounting to an abdication of responsibility to fulfil properly its terms of reference".

The prominent QC was engaged by the Stretton Group to offer a professional assessment of the report and executive summary of the Esplin inquiry.

The group is named after the royal commissioner who examined the 1939 and 1944 bushfires. It was brought together by Liberal MP Stewart McArthur.

They are not satisfied with the State Government's response to the bushfires, which burned 1.12 million hectares in north-east Victoria and Gippsland, and 181,400 hectares in the Big Desert - the biggest fires since Black Friday 1939.

In his review, Mr Myers casts doubt on the independence of the Esplin inquiry, stating that Mr Esplin "was not, and did not appear to be, independent in relation to the matters inquired into".

Another serious criticism is that the Esplin report could make recommendations on the future of fuel-reduction burning - "possibly the most sensitive area of the Esplin inquiry" - but failed to do so.

Mr Esplin last night rejected Mr Myers' conclusions, saying his report's recommendations had "totally changed the way the business of fire suppression is conducted in Victoria".

Other critical conclusions drawn by Mr Myers include:

- The Esplin inquiry's terms of reference were deficient, too vague, generalised, unfocused, but also too narrow.

- The report of the inquiry was also vague and "failed to address important environmental and economic consequences of the fires, including the effects (on) water catchments".

- Doubts about the validity of evidence to the inquiry because it was not tested by cross-examination and was not protected from potential defamation action.

- His view that the report invites "grave misgivings about the manner in which it is written". It makes "few specific findings or recommendations upon the most crucial issues and contains a great deal of peripheral and irrelevant material".

In a section of his review devoted to evidence that opportunities to control or extinguish the fires were not taken, Mr Myers notes that the inquiry records such criticisms of the firefighting efforts, but no specific recommendations about improving firefighting strategy, or how "local knowledge should be used or indeed any other matter that touches on the widespread criticism of the way in which the 2003 fires were fought".

Reviewing the inquiry's treatment of criticism of the relationships between paid firefighters, volunteers and landowners, Mr Myers says the one recommendation "is so generalised as to be worthless. It completely ignores the evidence of serious deficiencies in the organisation of the permanent fire-fighting bodies." Mr Myers is overseas. A spokeswoman said he was unlikely to comment publicly.

Mr Esplin defended the report, saying it made 148 recommendations after a six-month inquiry.

"The evidence I gathered while travelling throughout regional Victoria was given to me in a very free and frank manner," he said. "It was given directly to me from the local communities, landholders, CFA volunteers and staff, as well as employees of government departments."

A Government spokesman said Mr Esplin had produced a comprehensive report and it had allocated $168 million in this year's state budget to boost fire-fighting capabilities and implement Esplin recommendations. That included substantially increasing fuel reduction-burning and measures.

Last year, the community consultancy the Eureka Project released a report that criticised the performance of public sector agencies during the fires.

A director of the Eureka Project, Tony Cutcliffe, said A Case of Burning Neglect was written "out of concern that the Esplin inquiry as proposed by the Government would have neither the necessary power, nor the incentive, to get to the bottom of Victoria's biggest bushfire".

Mr Cutcliffe, who is also a member of the Stretton Group, said Mr Myers' verdict vindicated those concerns.

He said the decision to approach Mr Myers was based on his reputation as a leading barrister and because he owned a property in the Western District and would be acquainted with Victoria's bushfire potential.

WHAT IS THE STRETTON GROUP?

STEWART McARTHUR

Liberal MP for Corangamite since 1984. Member of the House of Representatives select committee inquiry into 2003 bushfires.

ATHOL HODGSON

Fifty years' experience in fire management and forest fire research. Former Victorian forests commissioner, board member of CFA and graduate from National Advanced Fire Behaviour School, Arizona.

SIMON PATON

Sixth-generation farmer from Callaghans Creek, Mitta Mitta. Spokesman for north-eastern communities affected by bushfires. Campaigner for involvement of rural communities in environment management.

DAVID PACKHAM

Forty years in bushfire research with CSIRO, Monash University and Australian Emergency Management Institute, specialising in fire behaviour and forensic examination.

BILL MIDDLETON

Fifty years' experience in forest management and rural vegetation. Has served on committees concerned with wildlife research and landscape conservation.

TONY CUTCLIFFE

Director of community liaison group and consultancy, The Eureka Project. Former member of premier's infrastructure planning council.

PETER ATTIWILL

Tertiary qualifications in science and forestry. Principal fellow in botany at University of Melbourne. Forty years researching eucalypt ecology, soils, bushfires and ecosystem recovery.
