urn:contentItem:5HCY-SKG1-F031-X42W-00000-00Was modern science born in ancient Greece?2015-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisScience Show5:03 PM AESTWas modern science born in ancient Greece?

Robyn Williams: Today The Science Show is on fire. And we meet once more those ancient Greeks.

This week the Prime Minister visited Indonesia, and one topic he may have discussed behind closed doors is fire, because Indonesia is burning, catastrophically, and this is once more choking neighbouring countries. Brendan May chairs Robertsbridge, which works extensively on deforestation in our region.

Brendan May:Indonesia's forest fires are a catastrophe, not just regionally but globally. Over 8,000 square miles of forest and peatland have been burnt to a crisp. That's an area 12 times bigger than Sydney and 30 times bigger than Indonesia's smog suffering neighbour Singapore. And with the losses of forest and peat come other calamities; a devastating wipe-out of habitat and already endangered wildlife, a humanitarian disaster with half a million people suffering from respiratory complaints and 19 dead, and a simply staggering increase in greenhouse gas emissions, rivalling the annual total emissions of many industrialised countries.

And right now the world is focused on the COP21 climate talks in Paris, designed for the first time to deliver legally binding limits, country by country, on emissions in order to avoid global average temperatures rising more than a further two degrees. Arguably, recent events in Indonesia have already made a significant contribution to disabling this process. It is INDC's (a clumsy UN acronym for Intended Nationally Determined Contributions) call for a 26% emissions reduction by 2020 and a conditional 41% by 2030, assuming international support. This is all using 2010 as a business-as-usual baseline.

Forestry, including fires, has contributed 60% of the country's total emissions over the last decade. Indonesia is also rich in coal and is developing new coal-fired power stations to meet increasing energy demand, and much of that coal of course lies beneath forest cover. And the most readily available source of biofuel feedstock (another growth area) is from, guess where, forestry. So whichever way you look at it, forestry is the elephant in the room.

But we need to look very carefully at the causes of these devastating fires and the resulting pollution. Unique to Indonesia is the fact that much of the country's forest sits on colossally deep peatland which, when it's cleared and drained, burns for a very, very long time if ignited. Once alight, peat emits all the CO2 it has stored over the millennia that it took to create.

That peatland has been drained in the first place does lie at the door of the big forestry businesses in Indonesia, largely palm oil and pulp plantation concession owners. But some of the biggest players have undergone a radical transformation and imposed zero deforestation policies across huge swathes of the landscape, and they've stopped developing on peatland. That has been one of the most positive news stories to come out of the environment movement in recent years.

The most sophisticated measures being taken by companies in Indonesia include the retirement of plantations on peat, complex management regimes to secure the forested and peatland landscapes, and to restore and conserve sufficient areas to address their legacies of destruction. All this is unprecedented progress. These companies now rely entirely on the plantations that already exist, so it's clearly not in their interests to set fire to their own raw material supply. Blaming fires on very large companies may be headline grabbing, but it's missing the point and it's wildly inaccurate. In fact the companies themselves are deploying thousands of firefighters to protect their assets.

The causal truth is very complex. It starts with the uncomfortable fact that there is very little clear definition over who actually owns what land. Commercial concessions in Indonesia often overlap with each other, and indigenous communities claim (often but not always legitimately) that they have a historic right to the use of traditionally held lands. Corruption and lawbreaking are endemic, policing is weak, and illegal encroachment is widespread.

Forest fire is an organised criminal industry. Much has been written and spoken about this. Fingers have been pointed, accusations hurled around the ether. But what the world needs to do now is to focus not simply on the cause and effect of forest fire but the cure. My own feeling is that this cure has three core elements. First, and most obviously, political. The current President of Indonesia, Joko Widodo, or Jokowi as he is popularly known, is the first President not to emerge from the country's ruling elite or military, and as such he heads a government with a populist leaning agenda. But he also has to wrestle with a legacy of deeply entrenched self-interest, widespread corruption, particularly at regional and local level, and a historically unhealthy link between business and politics. His is an extremely difficult balancing act. And to be fair, he has taken some action, not least returning early from a visit to America to deal with the crisis. The President has ordered a moratorium on new licences to develop peatland, and he has ordered officials to prosecute those who clear land by burning.

But his own populism can work against him too. He is considering an electoral promise to redistribute some 9 million hectares of land to farmers, raising their average landholding from 0.8 to 2 hectares. Coupled with that, not all forest fires are started illegally. Whilst enforcement may be feeble and it's illegal for companies to start fires for clearance, there are instances where small holders can do so. It is the cheapest way of clearing land. Put the two together and you can guess the result.

What Jokowi needs is not sanctimonious words from the rest of the world's political leadership, he needs help. First he needs the Paris climate talks to deliver tangible solutions that could be translated into practical policy back home, so that Indonesia can carry back the legitimacy to enact a legal framework that enables compliance with the agreements coming out of Paris. Permanent and well policed bans on any natural forest and peatland clearance of any sort by anyone, for example.

Second, he needs the support of politically derived institutions, US aid for example. And in particular the Norwegians who through their gigantic sovereign wealth finance can fund many of the compensatory initiatives that are needed to enable smallholder farmers to earn a living without burning forests, and which can also help in the hugely complex and expensive task of blocking canals, rewetting peatlands and reforestation. And of course countries like Australia, which sadly has had much experience of forest fires of its own.

The second part of the cure is commercial, and I should declare an interest here, I have worked with very large Indonesian businesses on zero deforestation initiatives for some years, and I know what challenges they face. And by the way, none of them are perfect. But I also know that with will and investment and leadership, it can be done. So the outside world of business needs to sit up and take more notice of those companies that can genuinely prove they have eliminated deforestation in their supply chains and have taken real steps to dealing with their legacy through conservation and restoration and who are making the right investments in communities across their concessions that help them avoid the need to clear land to make a living.

And this outside world of business needs also to move faster and further in making its own supply chain fully responsible. There are some shining lights here, ones you might not even expect, like Nestlé and Ferrero chocolate. But there are some real laggards. Why is PepsiCo being coy about deforestation? Why is Kraft Heinz equally flaccid on the subject? What kind of message does this timid approach from some consumer goods companies send?

The third cure lies in the hands of the environmental campaigning NGOs. With some notable exception, it seems to me that they are remarkably dysfunctional. Many of them have fallen into the trap of thinking that if they lose the object of their protest, then they have no raison d'être, so they continue to protest, even if the evidence is clear that they have won, and they should be supporting companies who are progressive and trying to change. There will always be other targets.

In the end of course the fires will go out, and at last some rain has arrived, but too often, once the haze clears, attention drifts elsewhere too. This time perhaps it will be different because of the sheer scale of the disaster. We must hope so, for Indonesia's sake and the world's future.

Robyn Williams: Brendan May chairs Robertsbridge, based in England. And as you heard, it does lots of work in Indonesia.

Here's a strange question; would mega-fauna help with fire?

Chris Doughty: So we are at Oxford's famous Natural History Museum, and we're looking at a number of old skeletons of animals that are arranged going from small animals to large animals, and this is interesting because this is more or less the distribution of animals that used to exist on the planet, and it no longer exists because we've lost most of the large animals. So right now we can see...

Robyn Williams: The common pig.

Chris Doughty: The common pig, that's right, and that's pretty much one of the biggest animals, so the biggest animal in the South American is the tapir. It's probably about twice the size of a common pig, about 300 kilograms is the upper limit, and that's actually the biggest endemic herbivore in South America. But if you go back 10,000 years ago, when humans first arrived in South America there would have been about 15 animals that were greater than 1,000 kilograms, and so that must of had an impact on forests, ecosystem services, not just South America but everywhere, Australia, North America. Those three places were probably hit the hardest by this extinction event that happened 10,000 years ago.

Robyn Williams: All those huge animals eating so much, trampling so much, and then they weren't there anymore. Have you been able to study what the consequence was of that change?

Chris Doughty: Yes, we can go about this a couple of ways, we can look at the fossil record, but we could also look at what do big animals do in places like Africa where they still exist. So Africa is the one place that didn't experience this big extinction event, so you could basically take elephants and all other big animals out of these ecosystems. And immediately the first consequence is you always see a big increase in tree growth. Then we could look at continental comparisons. So if we could for instance compare South America, that used to have all these big animals, what we can predict that savannas in South America probably had a lot more tree cover in savanna areas than Africa. You get about 26% less tree cover in the savannas.

However, it's interesting, in the forest ecosystems it's almost the opposite effect. In Africa you see much bigger trees than in equivalent tropical jungle in the Amazon. And we think it possibly may be because forest elephants are basically removing a lot of the understory, and that gives more nutrients and water for the big trees to grow bigger. So one of the big questions is if you put all these big animals back in the ecosystems, would there be more carbon stored in the biosphere or less?

Robyn Williams: Tell me, do you know how much...this is a ridiculous question isn't it...how much does an elephant eat? How much does a giraffe eat?

Chris Doughty: I don't know but I could predict that much, in fact I could predict how much an extinct animal that is the equivalent size to a giraffe and elephant would eat. So right now we are looking at basically all these skeletons that go from small to big, and I could predict more or less just if I know the weight how much all of these would eat. So the other prediction we make is that with big animals you get much better distribution of nutrients.

Robyn Williams: Big animals help you mean?

Chris Doughty: That's right, big animals help a lot.

Robyn Williams: I suppose big animals crap more.

Chris Doughty: Exactly, but it's not just that, they move more. So the important thing for big animals is they can take a mouthful of grass that has lots of nutrients, and it's going to stay in their body for a much longer time, and because they are big animals they move much further.

Robyn Williams: We just happen to be, by some amazing coincidence, not just looking at these huge skeletons but we are next to a display called Mammals of Australia, and they are all quite small. We used to have diprotodons, those vast rhinoceros or hippopotamus-sized creatures, chomping their way across the landscape. But we've only got, as you can see, the little ones, the wallabies, and there's the koala and there's the echidna and there's the wombat. Fairly small stuff!

Chris Doughty: That's right, yes, so Australia also had an extremely severe extinction event. But it's interesting that Australia never really had the big creatures. And elephants and their relatives seemed to really play a role, they are really ecosystem engineers. They are kind of the dominant ones when it comes to how they control the amount of trees and savannas. So elephants are really important from that standpoint. You see a big impact on vegetation coverage, you see a big change in the amount of fire...

Robyn Williams: That's right, in fact somebody suggested we import elephants, let them loose in various parts of the Australian landscape, that would reduce the understory and the extremely flammable material that we've got. The big season coming up is going to be a huge worry. Nothing has happened just yet to bring in elephants. Would you like to see it happen in Australia?

Chris Doughty: I'd like, on an experimental basis, to see what effect they might have. But a lot of people are talking about this. We're talking about trying to put elephants back in other places, back in South America where they were until 10,000 years ago, how would this affect these ecosystems? So Australia is a bit of a different case, but it's tricky, I can see why people would have difficulty with that.

The other side of it, let's take South America as an example again, a lot of our favourite fruits, like avocado, chocolate, there are some that theorise that they actually coevolved with these mega-fauna, with the gomphotheres, which is an elephant-like animal that had lived in these areas in the past. There is still debate about that. The other side of this question is now that these animals went extinct, who is moving the seeds of these trees that formally coevolved with them?

So if you think about the size of a seed of an avocado, that's a very big seed. And seeds want to be eaten by animals, so they want to be dispersed, so most trees, the fruit is basically an enticing element to get an animal to swallow the seed and move it far away from the parent. And so when you think about an avocado, what animal could possibly swallow a seed that big? Avocado evolved around Mexico area, in the Americas, and there's no animals that could currently swallow that...well, there's a horse, but horses actually evolved in North America and were killed off 10,000 years ago and then they came back with Europeans later on. Of course avocado and chocolate are different because now we are their dispersers. And we can basically thank these extinct mega-fauna for those.

Robyn Williams: It's lucky that we don't have to swallow the entire avocado and then eliminate the seed.

Chris Doughty: That's right, no, I wouldn't want to swallow an avocado seed.

Robyn Williams: Chris Doughty is at Oriel College in Oxford and the department of geography there.

And it was David Bowman who came up with the idea of bringing elephants to Australia, a charming idea, I would have thought. David is Professor of Environmental Change Biology at the University of Tasmania, but I found him at the Royal Society in London.

David Bowman: I was being provocative, but what we're trying to get people to think about is if we are going to stabilise the fire problems we've got globally and in particular Australia where we've disrupted ecological systems, introduced new grasses, introduced new animals, shut down traditions of Indigenous landscape burning, what we've effectively done is we've pulled apart a food web that created particular fire regimes, particular ways of burning landscape and particular patterns of burning. And one way of re-stabilising these systems is to reimagine the problem not as a series of parts, a problem of feral animals, a problem of weeds, a problem of fire, but to see them as all integrated, and so that we would be using the management of animals to manage fire.

Robyn Williams: Well, is this what you've been telling the people at this august establishment, the Royal Society in London?

David Bowman: Yes, absolutely. What I was doing was saying, well, we can imagine landscape fire in a food web, and in a sense we are elevating fire. So it's not saying that fire is a living thing, but it's acknowledging that fire has properties of living things, it interacts with living things, and think of the words we use about fire, we talk about fire having a behaviour, we talk about feeding fires, we talk about the way fire can move, it has an ecological niche. So in a sense you just put all of those things together of people talking about fire as a global herbivore, why don't we imagine fire in a food web as an integral part of an ecological system.

Robyn Williams: But that means you can't do terribly much about it. Fire is so destructive.

David Bowman: Yes, but you see this is where the fresh thinking comes in, that in a place like Hobart it would be possible if we could get over the idea of manipulating landscapes, to switch areas, say around Hobart where I live, from being very flammable eucalyptus forest, you could actually have little glades in those eucalypt forests which are maintained by marsupials. Marsupials create lawns, it's a common feature of a lot of herbivorous animals, that they can affect the herbaceous ground layer and they can create actual lawns. That's what a lawn is, it's ultimately something that animals created. We use lawnmowers but you can get animals to create lawns, and lawns are relatively inflammable. So you could create mosaics, you can change the way landscapes work, and I think that the idea of total war on fire, more and more kit attacking fire isn't going to work. The Americans are quietly going broke, we are talking billions now being spent in fire seasons. As climate change is biting, the fire seasons are getting epic. And we have to completely reimagine this. And I think that the outcome is going to be reimagining fire in a food web.

Robyn Williams: How many years ago was it when that huge fire consumed Hobart and almost brought the city to a standstill?

David Bowman: Yes, 1967, and it's a real worry that there have been a couple of generations...we now have politicians in Tasmania who really have no understanding...children are not even born for 1967. We know those ecosystems are pent up. I like to imagine Mount Wellington as an organic volcano. It's pent-up. And when you get the correct fire weather, these rogue days, like Dunalley, which just come really hard and they can drive fires and extreme fire behaviour in a couple of hours, incredible destruction, what we have to do is create fireproof communities. We have total war on drugs, total war on things, well, often it ends up that it's making peace with this thing, and what we've got to do with fire is it's a rapprochement, we've got to understand fire as being inside a food web in an ecosystem and get into some sort of reciprocity. We will give fire certain things, and in return fire will give us certain things.

But if we just want to quell fire, attack fire, what will end up happening, as we are seeing particularly in the US is you just get these things called mega-fires which shut everything down. There are not enough bombers, there are not enough people to put these things out, they become utterly uncontrollable. So we are going to be reimagining our landscapes, like it or not. And I'm hoping that we do it in an artistic and creative way, a landscape design way, because of the anger, which will go with the destruction and the loss of life, people will break out the chainsaws and the bulldozers and we will have great big raw firebreaks and there will be a real horrible ecological apartheid.

And of course what I'm really saying in the end, if you pull it down to the bare essentials, is that we are becoming more like Aborigines, we are going to be using fire in a more creative way to create a habitat that works for us, exactly what Aboriginal people did. Aboriginal people created these amazing landscapes which were biodiverse, productive in terms of food, but also safe.

When the Europeans turned up, they weren't running on the beach saying 'get us out of here, this is a dangerous place', they were completely comfortable about living in one of the most flammable environments on Earth because they had mastered it, they had worked out how to make a peace with fire, they were accommodating this ecological force, and that's what I think is really a mind shift, that it's not something that we can take fire away, it's actually learning to live with fire in an ecological way with some reciprocities and some give and take.

Robyn Williams: The ever provocative David Bowman at the Royal Society in London. He is professor at the University of Tasmania in Hobart.

Finally on fire, a device being perfected at the department of engineering, Edith Cowen University in Perth.

I'm looking at something that could come out of Doctor Who. It's got a plate of silicon chips, it looks like, solar sensitive cells in the middle, and four arms coming up, almost like tentacles. What is it?

Iftekhar Ahmad: This model we have chemical sensors and also infrared sensors, and also we have a solar panel to make it energy efficient. And inside the box we have microcontroller-based communication systems. It uses radio waves for communicating to other nodes or to the gateway.

Robyn Williams: And it's looking to see whether there is a fire in the vicinity. What is it picking up from the fire? The chemicals or what?

Iftekhar Ahmad: Yes, if there is a fire certainly there will be some chemicals which will go up. So once it crosses the threshold, the system detects this and then it generates an alarm.

Robyn Williams: I imagine you've put this somewhere in the bush or somewhere near a farm, and then when it detects something it sends you a signal. How?

Iftekhar Ahmad: It uses radio frequency. So it can talk to another node or it can talk to the gateway and the gateway can upload the data to the cloud or it can send a text message to a mobile phone or any web server.

Robyn Williams: So having detected the fire it sends you the message that somewhere in Western Australia you've got a fire beginning. What do you do about that next?

Iftekhar Ahmad: Let's say if you are in a farmland and it's unoccupied, if there is an alarm then you know what's happening at your property so you can take actions. We also can feed this device with other automated systems which can turn on the sprinklers...

Robyn Williams: Just like in the household.

Iftekhar Ahmad: That's correct, so it has enormous potential.

Robyn Williams: And what's its range? If it's out there in the bush, of course the bush is pretty big, especially in Western Australia.

Iftekhar Ahmad: Well, the radio range is quite large. We have tested in bushland and it can cover easily up to 1.5 kilometres. And if it is line of sight, that means there is no bush or no tree around, it can cover up to 10 kilometres.

Robyn Williams: And if you're making lots of these, they cost about $100, so fairly cheap?

Iftekhar Ahmad: That's correct. So if we go for large-scale manufacturing the cost can be brought below $100 each.

Robyn Williams: Where do you imagine these might be put out, in what kind of terrain?

Iftekhar Ahmad: Well, at this stage we are thinking that they can be put in areas like for critical infrastructure or close to the suburbs so that if there is a fire, so all the people in that neighbourhood get a text SMS.

Robyn Williams: Where the town is beginning to turn into countryside or somewhere where you've got a very valuable facility that needs protection.

Iftekhar Ahmad: That's correct. Given that Australia is very large, if we tried to cover every inch of bushland, that would be very expensive. So initially we are looking at putting them in areas of interest where we have critical infrastructure.

Robyn Williams: I suppose it would be suitable for places like California as well.

Iftekhar Ahmad: Well, absolutely, that would be the next stage of our enterprise. There is certainly some interest around. We are currently negotiating with them on how to commercialise it.

Robyn Williams: Iftekhar Ahmad is senior lecturer in the department of engineering, Edith Cowan University in Perth.

The Science Show on RN.

And this week the Science Unit said goodbye to Judy Lawson who worked with us for over 30 years behind the scenes. She died on Sunday last.

Our PhD talk this week is from Noushin Nasiri at the ANU in Canberra, and it's dedicated to Judy.

Noushin Nasiri: Last year a friend of mine passed away from lung cancer. She went through four rounds of chemotherapy but without success. It was too late for her, too late. If it had been detected at stage 1, the chance of survival would have been more than 75%. But at stage 4, her chance was only 6%. It's not only my friend. Do you know how many people in Australia died this year from lung cancer? Just lung cancer? 9,000 Australians, just in 2015.

But what if you could detect the disease at a very early stage when the chance of recovery is much higher? In my PhD I am doing this by looking at your breath. It might seem invisible but your breath tells a story. Your breath is a mixture of nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, water, and only 1% of other gases. That 1% includes thousands of organic compounds which can help me to detect diseases such as diabetes, breast cancer, kidney failure and lung cancer.

But there is one big challenge here; concentration. The biomarkers concentration difference between healthy people and patients is only parts per billion. How small is that? It's like finding one drop of blood in an Olympic-sized swimming pool. Is it really detectable? Yes. Dogs and bees have the ability to detect parts per trillion, 1,000 times less concentrated. Now the question is how we can make something that is sufficiently sensitive to detect this tiny concentration. The answer involves a fingertip-sized sensor made by billions of the nanoparticles, each of them has a diameter of a few atoms, 1,000 times smaller than the tip of your hair.

If you blow into my sensor it can detect any tiny possibility of having a disease in your body. It's 100 times more accurate than what we need and it's small enough to fit in your phone and help you to keep your health in check every day. My research into creating this technology can empower us with more knowledge about our health, our body and can help us to save many, many lives in the near future.

Robyn Williams: She is really determined, isn't she? Noushin is here from Iran, trying to save lives, Noushin Nasiri at the ANU in Canberra.

This year, Greece has meant politics and debts and international confrontation. But 3,000 to 2,000 years ago, Greece meant the foundation of our thinking in philosophy and science, and the flowering of everything from theatre to great architecture. But why? Why there, why then? One of my books of the year is titled Introducing the Ancient Greeks, and it's by Edith Hall, professor of classics at King's College in London.

My first question is why did it happen in ancient Greece? Okay, lots of other people created stuff, as you say in the intro to the book, but really the flowering of both philosophy and natural history and God knows what else was down there, what, 2,000, 3,000 years ago. How come there?

Edith Hall: The ancient Greeks were the most diaspora people of antiquity by far. They really lived more than 25 miles from the sea, so they lined the entire Mediterranean and Black Sea worlds. There were two major results of this. One was they developed seafaring and everything that has to do with seafaring, like navigation and carpentry and woodwork and understanding of the winds and the natural elements better than anybody else did, including the Venetians who were their great seafaring rivals. But most importantly they were in contact with far more other ethnic groups than anybody else in antiquity. They had to talk to them wherever they went, they intermarried wherever they went, and they appropriated and adapted ideas from every single other ancient culture. So they are the consummation of the combined wisdom of the entire late Bronze Age world of the Mediterranean and the Black Sea.

Robyn Williams: And if you look at the map you can see all these islands, and if you look at the terrain it's very mountainous, so that you are kind of separated. You could have a city-state but it can't be huge, and so you had a big enough to foment these ideas but to get difference.

Edith Hall: Well, I actually think that the very scattered nature of the ancient Greeks, the difficulty they had actually meeting each other physically by land was what drove them to develop a much stronger ethnic identity, and that was glued together wherever they went through their language. They did not lose their language, which was amazing if you actually think how far they spread. So they also met together at international festivals like the ancient Olympic Games and the ancient games at Delphi. They had annual games like that. And they all came to it, they were usually in the summer because that was when they could sail.

So they kept this very, very strong identity, but they were facing completely different types of environment and physical challenge depending on whether they are colonising the Ukrainian coast, which meant all kinds of different things, they couldn't even grow vines there, or whether they had gone to Libya and they were actually living cheek by jowl and intermarrying with desert nomads. So they had to be far more inventive then everybody else. Necessity is the mother of invention. I also think that they were rather sceptical about traditional religion, while loving everything that went with ritual, I don't think they were particularly spiritual people. So I think that their inclination to try and find out the natural causes of things was actually inherit in their national character.

Robyn Williams: So they had plenty of gods but the gods were there for a bit of a laugh, a bit of a story.

Edith Hall: Well, I think 'a bit of a laugh' is a little bit harsh, but they never had a sense of the authoritative god kings that you get in ancient Persia, ancient Egypt, ancient Assyria, Babylon, this idea of feudal structure with an eternal powerful god king on top who can never be questioned or challenged. I think that was one aspect that was actually part of their theology, that even their gods like their top gods...Zeus had actually kicked out his dad who had kicked out his dad, there wasn't this idea of a one permanent eternal God, there was always a chance to get in and have a coup.

But more importantly I think they were very, very poor. As you said, they could never actually make...because of the terrain in the mountains and they didn't have good pasture, they didn't develop very rich city-states, at least until after Alexander the Great's conquests. So they were driven on by poverty and famine. They were often very, very hungry. People who are hungry are not politically tolerant.

Robyn Williams: And indeed you say, and this is interesting, they are egalitarian, so you are open to your neighbour's ideas rather than just being full of your own.

Edith Hall: I think they are inherently egalitarian actually amongst their own communities, I think that's to do partly with being a colonising people, that they are not staying at home and building up feudal structures. It's a bit like everybody turning up in Australia or New Zealand or Canada who are not in general likely to erect the class structures that they had left behind in Europe. I do think that is part of the colonial mentality, it breeds an egalitarian spirit. Women tend to have more power and be more equal in those kinds of communities. They've got to be, it's all hands to the pump.

But I also think they were extremely open to other ethnic groups. The very fact that they had no idea of biological racism...they despised people who couldn't speak Greek and read philosophy but they didn't have biological racism, and they always intermarried with the local women. A typical colonising group is younger brothers with nothing to inherit, nothing to stay for in their own local village in Greece except hunger, so they go off, found a new colony, get a woman in Libya or the Ukraine, have mixed race children but they all learn Greek. And that is the typical profile, and that tended to breed actual democratic constitutions.

Robyn Williams: Well, you mentioned Alexander, of course his tutor was Aristotle. Aristotle wrote so much, unbelievable amounts, some of it...well, frankly unacceptable in modern scientific terms. A lot of it a very interesting. But did he go out like Archimedes, did he go out like Galen, for that matter, who was very practical, and experiment or investigate, or did he sit on a hillside in a toga and make it up?

Edith Hall: Now, Aristotle is crucial, it doesn't matter if some of his hypotheses have been disproven because he invented the idea of the hypothesis. So he invented a science that is based on an idea that you postulate and then open up the challenge to other people to disprove it. That is science. Science is not facts, it's a series of hypotheses waiting to be disproven. He theorised that, and nobody had theorised that before. He actually thought through the practice.

But what I think is most interesting about Aristotle is that his actual travels...he's brought up in northern Greece as a doctor's son, which means that he learned far more about...first descriptions of the physical bodies are all in the early Hippocratic doctors, and he learned a lot about botany if your father is a doctor because most of the cures were from plants. So he's brought up there.

Then he sent off to the academy in Athens to learn what we would call cerebral philosophy at the feet of Plato no less, spent 20 years with Plato learning how to argue. Then he goes off to Lesbos, the island of Lesbos, and Issos, which is just opposite on what is now the Turkish coast, and for three years did nothing but write about all the fauna that he found. And he did that in conjunction with his best friend, also a student at the academy called Theophrastus who at the same time invented botany.

And you can tell from the descriptions of all the marine life in Aristotle's generation of animals and parts of animals and history of animals, that he is actually dissecting sea creatures all the time. So it's absolutely grounded in empirical description and analysis, and it was only when he'd got a very large amount of data did he started to draw inferences of a more general client about how biological living organisms work.

So this is a man who combines intense theoretical training and argumentation with practice on the ground. He for example invented statistical analysis. We know this because he actually wrote down things he found out about a number of volcanoes, would you believe. It's volcanoes through which he invented statistical analysis. And you could never have had Ptolemy a couple of generations later doing all that empirical data on stars and eclipses, which is absolutely the foundation of all modern astronomy, even now. Even Newton and Copernicus still had to read Ptolemy, they really did. They wouldn't have done that, he couldn't have done that without Aristotle and in the 4th century BC. He invented empirical science.

Robyn Williams: Yes, impressive. We'll come to Ptolemy and a couple of the others in a minute. But one thing that puzzled me about Aristotle is that when he was writing about the meaning of life and the pursuit of it was supposed to be that made it real, he talked about you're supposed to attain happiness, meanwhile his student Alexander the Great was...talk about rape and pillage and torture in the most heartless away. We haven't actually mentioned that an awful lot of slaves where there amongst the egalitarian Greeks as well. But there is this disjunction between what you did in terms of happiness and well-being and friendliness, and on the other hand this cruelty that was so clear and apparent, all the way to Afghanistan Alexander went.

Edith Hall: It's very difficult trying to accommodate some of the clear virtues of ancient Greek ethics with how the ancient Greeks themselves often behaved. They do seem to have been able to draw this extraordinary binary distinction between the free human and the slave human, which is very baffling to us, though actually as someone born when there was still apartheid in South Africa it shouldn't be so baffling. We've seen people able to convince themselves that whole groups of people are completely inferior to others in our lifetimes. But they did, and I think that this was actually a necessary though lamentable spinoff of the economic system. The sheer amount of labour required to build those cities, maintain them and so on meant that you had to have I think about nine out of ten people bound to work.

And Aristotle is very clear that there's going to be a leisured class that can think and can devote its entire time to cerebral activity but it can only be supported by captive labour. And this is extremely depressing though, again, I actually think if you look in the Industrial Revolution in Britain, if you read Charles Dickens you find that a similar proportion, nine out of ten people are working 14 hours a day down the mines or in the factories. They may not actually be in a legal sense slaves, but to all intents and purposes they don't have any leisure or education. So I think it's quite easy to see the Greeks and the Romans as exceptional from that point of view. I don't think they were, I think they were like everybody until about 1914.

Robyn Williams: Indeed. The thing I found most disheartening about some of the slaves was they couldn't become too fit because if they were fit and looked as if they might become some sort of threat they killed them.

Edith Hall: Well, in Sparta they did, they certainly did in Sparta. But having said that, Aristotle is very clear that Greeks shouldn't enslave other Greeks. He thinks that anybody who is educated enough to be a free living person in a Greek city-state, and that includes the women and children, has already rendered themselves unsuitable for slavery, they are already too superior for slavery if they know Greek. So Aristotle says to Alexander quite clearly, this is reflected in his book The Politics; go conquer East, go get the slaves, they will then allow the Greeks to become the freest, greatest, most intelligent people who ever lived. Which is pretty much what happened.

Robyn Williams: We mentioned Ptolemy, the thing that is slightly confusing, there were so many Ptolemys, king after king, and a different Ptolemy who was actually an astronomer.

Edith Hall: Claudius Ptolemy, let's call him Claudius Ptolemy, Claudius Ptolemy wrote an awful lot of treatises in which he included all his observations of the natural movements of the stars, the planets, the satellites, comets, all that kind of thing, which he wrote down for 35 years which allowed him to predict things like eclipses which convinced everybody he was actually right and not some kind of magician, that he'd done this by scientific prediction.

So he's an Egyptian Greek, he's almost certainly got Egyptian blood, living in Alexandria where Ptolemy I, who was Alexander the Great's best lieutenant, who'd the minute Alexander the Great died went and grabbed Egypt and said, 'This is my fiefdom, I'm going to stay here.' And he founded a seven-generation dynasty of Ptolemys, the last of whom was Cleopatra. So that went on for several hundred years. But his great achievement was to build the library of Alexandria.

The library of Alexandria changed everything about intellectual life in antiquity. It shifted everything in terms of science and literature from Athens to Alexandria. It's like people colonising America and then building Harvard or something and buying in the greatest minds from Oxford and Cambridge and Paris and Berlin. So he sets up this great library, and two or three generations later along comes Ptolemy and he is able to build on pre-existing astronomical works, including by Aristotle, but many, and Babylonian wisdom because the Babylonians had had their own way of recording movements of the stars, and ancient Egyptian text, and then sit down and crucially do his own empirical data gathering. And it's that wonderful combination of inherited hypotheses which are then tested against heavyweight hard-core collections of data amassed over many, many years allowed him to disapprove previous hypotheses and set his own in place. And he managed to predict the circumference of the world to within a few hundred metres apparently. So he was the real genius when it comes to understanding the nature of cosmology.

Robyn Williams: Such a list of names. I want to talk about Galen because Galen wrote so much and demonstrated so much, and if you had any doubts about his anatomy he would take a monkey or something and open its chest and perform...not simply demonstrate the organs inside but sever the veins or the arteries and then stitch them up. It was most extraordinary. Well, he was a workaholic and he did this so much, his reputation became celebrated.

Edith Hall: Absolutely. Galen is from north-western Turkey from Pergamon which actually...under the Roman Empire, this is, this is the second century AD, so he stands at the head of 1,000 years of Greek medical practice. And we know that he is brought up in North West Asia Minor, Turkey, Anatolia. Hates his mother. Clearly rather a disturbed family but they are fantastically rich.

So his father packs him off too, guess where, Alexandria, where he reads every medical book in the library. He is just voracious, he is unstoppable. Yes, he is a workaholic, he seems to have never had any kind of private life. And he knew that he could turn medicine into an art as well as a science and actually a form of entertainment. He did put on medical shows. We hear about these in the 19th century, you had quack doctors who toured with tents and used to do miraculous operations and so on. Well, Galen certainly did do that but he clearly had a diagnostic talent that was really remarkable. And so he was able to both as a very good doctor have an almost supernatural instinct for what was wrong with people, maybe a lot of psychology, but then he had got all that intellectual equipment from all those books he had read.

He also, back at home...he went back to Pergamon for a while, and he had a very good job if you were a doctor which was looking after the royal gladiators of the local bigwig, the local petty king under the Roman Empire. So he got guys with really interesting injuries and indeed corpses all the time, and then he treated them. So if you've got a very regular supply of extremely badly damaged, strong humans, you're going to learn an awful lot very quickly about how bodies work. And indeed training them, regimens for good health. So he took all that lore off to Rome where he became the greatest celebrity.

What baffles me is how he had the time to write all this down because he actually...if you add up all the things we've got in pagan ancient Greek, which is I would say 1,000 volumes perhaps we've got of ancient Greek pagan texts, half of them are by this one man Galen. He wanted to write it all down.

He was then translated into Arabic as well as into modern European languages and had a huge impact on Arabic medicine as well as on Western medicine, and very many of his techniques actually are still in one form or another in use. He really was one who pioneered, for example, the pulse as a diagnostic test.

Robyn Williams: And did he really do a sort of open heart surgery, taking the sternum off and looking inside?

Edith Hall: Well, he tells us he did, so we have no particular reason to disbelieve it. We know that people were doing full cadaver biopsies by the 3rd century BC. He's quite a lot later than that. I fear that there was a large stock of criminal bodies from the amphitheatres, people who had been killed, to do so, but he was very good at using animals as well, which we would find upsetting, those of us who can't bear vivisection, but I don't suppose your average Roman would bat an eyelid.

Robyn Williams: No, but doing it on a human being who actually lived, unbelievable.

Hippocrates of course was the big daddy, we can't leave him out, and we know about the oath and we know about 'do no harm', but there is much, much more, isn't there.

Edith Hall: There is. Hippocrates did exist. He was a Greek who lived, again, off the coast of Turkey. The islands around the southwest corner of Turkey, like Cos, are where we know there were actual medical schools. They grew out of temple cults of the medical gods like Apollo, who is the god of healing, and Asclepius, but at some point stopped being so religious, and the combined medical lore...you know, originally doctors were priests of Apollo or his son Asclepius, but they turned into real medical schools.

And if you read the early Hippocratic treaties, and there are some from as early as the 5th century BC, the use of nonreligious explanations for what's going on in the body is a clear and loud sign that rational science is going on. If you compare that with Egyptian medicine, for example, we've got Egyptian papyri from even earlier than that, they sometimes use very rational explanations for wounds healing up. What they never do is produce a rational explanation for an internal organic problem. That is always still a god doing something. The Hippocratic school just got beyond that. And actually the more I read of the early treatises, which include some on gynaecology...now, a lot of the ideas are completely batty about gynaecology, they had some very odd ideas...

Robyn Williams: Still are.

Edith Hall: No, but for example they thought that the uterus wasn't a muscle, it was more like a shell and the foetus had to peck its way out of the shell, and that was what caused the pain of labour, rather than the woman having the strongest muscle in Homo sapiens and doing the pushing. They got lots wrong but the hypotheses were rational and based on inference. And because of that they developed very good treatments and they knew when to intervene and try and get the baby out, not by Caesarean but vaginally. They knew when a woman was in trouble, even if they had the wrong image for what was going wrong, and they knew how to get the baby out and we have these treatises, they are incredible.

Robyn Williams: What I also found incredible was that...we can't give every example because the book needs to be read, it's got wonderful stories in it, as you can imagine, and names...oh gosh, we can keep on mentioning the names, but atoms are there, the idea that there is a planetary solar system is there, rejection of the Earth-centred universe is there, the fact that they found most things way in advance is simply staggering, and the names continue. Has all this been forgotten? People don't necessarily study classics anymore as much as they used to. What would you like to see happen so we rediscover some of these wonderful things?

Edith Hall: I would like to see some compulsory school education in ancient Mediterranean history, but cultural history, intellectual history, the 10 best ideas that the Greeks had. They had lots of bad ideas, like slavery, but they had got so many things right. And what frustrates me is that this is the biggest privilege, the biggest asset in a way that the world has got. These people had an incredibly advanced civilisation with philosophical thinking and scientific thinking of a sophistication that is still jaw-dropping compared with the average education of citizens even in advanced western countries. But they failed, they stopped, their whole system of ideas stopped. In about 391, Theodosius, the Christian emperor, shut down all the temples, the universities all got shut down soon after that, and it took 1,500 years before we had a Renaissance of these ideas.

So we have this parallel universe I see it as, not as long dead and gone, but people exactly like us who faced all the same challenges like us who got incredibly good ideas about very many things, and I think we agree today with them about an awful lot of things like, for example, recreational sex is okay, which we couldn't believe in until after Freud, and we don't consult them. Why wouldn't we talk to our ancestors who were so wise and who failed. No other culture in the world...I've read the ancient Chinese texts, I've read the ancient Indian texts, they all have a continuity rather than this actually incredibly fruitful rupture.

So in my own head whatever it is I'm doing I think, now, what would have Aristotle have said about that? Half the time I really disagree with him, especially when he's saying that women are inferior intellectually, but half the time I think you're absolutely right and that's how I should do it, or that's how we should put the question, and I would like to share that with every...I think about 16...you mustn't have them too young because they are quite intellectually advanced, but the pursuit of happiness is an incredibly good goal to have in life.

Thomas Jefferson had read Aristotle, but it is an Aristotelian conception that all humans have the right to pursue happiness and how should we best do that, and Aristotle's answer is through partnerships and communities, you cannot have it on your own, no man can be happy as an island. He is the first person to theorise all that. So that's just one example. But I would like to get my hands on every 16-year-old in the world actually for about 10 weeks, one hour, I could do it.

Robyn Williams: A book recommended by Jim Spigelman, chairman of the ABC, Introducing the Ancient Greeks: From Bronze Age Seafarers to Navigators of the Western Mind, written by Edith Hall, professor of classics at King's College in London. A marvellous read.

Next week on The Science Show, cancer and exercise, and the year 2071, a play about climate.

Production today by David Fisher and Simon Branthwaite. I'm Robyn Williams.

M</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KEYWORD-HIT</p><p nitf:lede="true">MONITOR</p><p nitf:lede="true">PAGE SEVEN</p><p nitf:lede="true">Travnik: is this</p><p nitf:lede="true">city Bosnia's</p><p nitf:lede="true">last chance?</p><p nitf:lede="true">F IKRET Beso, a 30-year-old Muslim soldier, lies in a narrow bed in a</p><p nitf:lede="true">Travnik hospit al.</p><p nitf:lede="true">His chest and upper left arm are wrapped in bandages, the</p><p nitf:lede="true">aftermath of a Croatian sniper's round that struck him near Vitez three</p><p nitf:lede="true">weeks ago.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Two rooms away, Zoran Miskovic, a 33-year-old Croat, is recovering</p><p nitf:lede="true">from a Muslim sniper's shot that tore through his chest and upper right</p><p nitf:lede="true">arm.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>He too was hit near Vitez during bloody fighting between Croats and</p><p>Muslims last month.</p><p>The two men with the book-end wounds, one Muslim, one Croat, have</p><p>struck up a friendship.</p><p>""In this hospital I feel like I felt before the war," says Beso.</p><p>""No one carried a gun and every man looked the same."</p><p>Travnik, in central Bosnia, is both the last best hope of</p><p>Croatian-Muslim accommodation and a tinderbox awaiting a spark that</p><p>will lead it, too, into conflagration.</p><p>A former capital of Bosnia under the Ottoman empire, Travnik has</p><p>seen extraordinary efforts by both sides to talk instead of fight.</p><p>They are given incentive to co-</p><p>operate by the Serbian gunners who line the ridges and mountains</p><p>overlooking the town.</p><p>I F Travnik falls to the Serbs, or succumbs to Croatian-Muslim riv</p><p>alries, Bosnia's already dim prospects for any cohabitation among</p><p>nationalities will be extinguished.</p><p>""What is happening is that the former Bosnia-Herzegovina is being</p><p>split into two pieces," says one European</p><p>diplomat. ""That means no future for Bosnia as we have known it."</p><p>The Croats and Muslims in Bosnia were uneasy political and military</p><p>bedfellows when they were fighting a common Serbian enemy. Now,</p><p>increasingly, they are fighting each other, too.</p><p>Faced with a near-total defeat by Serbian forces in the parts of</p><p>Bosnia they once controlled, Croatian forces are grabbing as much land</p><p>as possible in predominantly Muslim regions.</p><p>Serbian frontlines have been mostly stable since last autumn,</p><p>allowing the Serbs to shell exposed cities and villages at will. Now,</p><p>in a classic pincer movement, Croatian forces are squeezing</p><p>Muslim-populated areas from other directions.</p><p>According to UN military sources, the Croatians attack Muslim towns</p><p>to provoke a response, so the Croatians can then retaliate even more</p><p>violently</p><p>.</p><p>During the past month, like a forest fire leaping from mountain to</p><p>mountain, fighting between the two former allies has flared in a</p><p>half-dozen towns in Bosnia.</p><p>The most recent outbreak was south-west of Sarajevo, where scores</p><p>were killed and wounded during Beirut-style house-to-house fighting.</p><p>The Croats and Muslims have shown they are as capable of committing</p><p>atrocities as the Serbs: Croats launched a tanker truck loaded with</p><p>explosives into a town centre in Vitez in mid-April. The blast killed</p><p>at least 97 Muslim residents and levelled surrounding buildings.</p><p>Earlier, at Cersca in northern Bosnia, UN forces discovered a mass</p><p>grave containing the bodies of 150 Serbs dumped there by Muslim troops.</p><p>""It is very hard to see who maintains the moral high ground,"</p><p>says one UN military official. ""But in the past four weeks in central</p><p>Bosnia, the Croats have been in the gutter."</p><p>""I believe in compromise,' says Mohamed Curic, Travnik's Muslim</p><p>mayor. ""I think many Croats here would be ashamed of what other Croats</p><p>have done."</p><p>The city's two governing bodies are divided equally among Muslims</p><p>and Croatians.</p><p>Last week, they passed a series of measures that would consolidate</p><p>administrative functions, remove armed soldiers from the city centre</p><p>and place the police force under</p><p>civilian control.</p><p>Drago Bilandeja, the Croatian president of the eight-member</p><p>supervising</p><p>body, believes continued cooperation is possible.</p><p>""We try hard to avoid confrontation," he says. ""Up to now, it is</p><p>working."</p><p>But there are hints that Travnik's fragile inter-ethnic truce may</p><p>not last much longer.</p><p>UN military sources say Croatian troops have removed their biggest</p><p>guns from Travnik and realigned some forces near the town, perhaps in</p><p>prelude to an attack.</p><p>Muslims have forced some Croats from their homes, which have been</p><p>turned over to Muslim refugees, who number at least 17,000 in Travnik.</p><p>The recent cut-off of relief convoys that supply most of Travnik's</p><p>residents with food and medicine has deepened tensions.</p><p>There is a shortage of seeds for the spring planting of potatoes,</p><p>onions and carrots.</p><p>""Our fields are deserts," says Senid Gerin, director of the</p><p>humanitar-</p><p>ian relief logistics centre.</p><p>The prognosis for Zoran Miskovic, the wounded Croatian in the</p><p>Travnik hospital, is better than the prognosis for Bosnia.</p><p>He can be released in a week. But he is bitter about the forces</p><p>that brought him, close to death, to his hospital bed.</p><p>""It is a shame what the politicians and military leaders are</p><p>doing," he says. ""They are out of their minds."</p><p>Unfortunately for him, his Muslim fellow patients and his country,</p><p>madness is the order of the day in Bosnia.</p><p>While Bosnia burns, the small city of Travnik is determined to keep</p><p>its mixed population of Croats and Muslims at peace. Mike Tharp</p><p>reports.</p><p>BOSNIA . . . a fragile hope.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC OF A YOUNG BOY CRYING AT THE BURIAL OF A SOLDIER, AND urn:contentItem:4P7G-YFF0-TXN5-R2J7-00000-00FORESTS DOOMED - BIG CHOP GOES ON1988-03-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 39FORESTS DOOMED - BIG CHOP GOES ONFACE OF ASIAFrom BILL MELLOR Staff Correspondent in Asia

ASIA'S forests are being chopped down at such a horrific rate that Australians who buy quality wood furniture may soon be accused of committing the ultimate in bad taste.

That is the opinion of one of the world's leading forestry experts, who told The Sun-Herald many types of trees are in as much danger as the rarest wildlife species.

"You can compare valuable timbers such as teak, rosewood and ebony with animals such as tigers, leopards and cheetahs," said Dr Y.S. Rao, Asia forestry chief for the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation.

"We have to put a stop to the destruction caused by human greed. We have done it in the case of wildlife. Now we must do it with trees.

"We must get over to people that buying furniture made of these woods is just not on - that it must become as unacceptable as wearing coats made from the skins or fur of endangered animals."

Dr Rao's comments may sound alarmist, even ludicrous to those of us who bask in the praise dinner guests lavish on our rosewood dining suites. (Guilty, Your Honour, I bought one ridiculously cheaply in Hong Kong four years ago, then told two million Sun-Herald readers how they could do the same.)

Facing disaster

But Dr Rao is no ultra-militant greenie. Top UN bureaucrats are invariably cautious and conservative. That's how they keep their jobs.

Rather, his warning is based on chilling official figures about the destruction of Asia's great tropical forests.

Jungle and forest areas in some Asian countries have been more than halved in less than 30 years. Between 1976 and 1980, Asia's total closed forest area was slashed by nine million hectares to 333 million.

Even then facing disaster, many countries and pressure groups stepped up their efforts to save what was left.

But still the situation worsens. In 1980, experts predicted the annual deforestation rate would level off. In fact, it has increased.

Now, it is estimated that between 1985 and the turn of the century, Asia will lose another 30 million hectares - another 10 per cent of its forest cover. At that rate, within our children's lifetimes, the vast majority will be gone.

The worst destruction is taking place on Australia's doorstep.

Get-away elephants

Indonesia is losing 500,000ha a year, more than any other country in the region.

This has been caused largely by its policy of "transmigration", moving vast numbers of people from the overpopulated main island of Java to form jungle clearing settlements in densely forested Irian Jaya and Kalimantan.

In Thailand in 1960, more than half the country was swathed in jungle. Today the conservative figure is 29 per cent. Deforestation continues to gallop along at the rate of 400,000ha a year due in part to timber poachers using highly-trained get-away elephants to escape with the booty.

Malaysia is the world's leading tropical hardwood exporter, with timber bringing in foreign earnings of almost $3 billion a year.

Forest cover is being reduced by 230,000ha annually.

In India, where 150,000ha of forest are being lost every year, firewood is now so expensive that many poor Indians can no longer afford to cremate properly relatives' bodies according to Hindu tradition.

Consequently, only partially charred corpses are being thrown into the river and to combat the health hazard authorities are being forced to breed carnivorous turtles to devour what should have been burnt.

Communist Indochina has not escaped deforestation, either. Areas of Vietnam's jungle which survived Agent Orange and other American defoliants are now being chopped down at the rate of 65,000ha a year. Its ally, Laos, is losing forest at twice that rate.

The civil war in Burma is a major reason why 100,000ha of jungle is disappearing each year. Minority armies are partly funding their revolutions by log poaching.

Loss of forest cover is causing the notorious so-called "greenhouse effect", which is raising temperatures world-wide.

The situation is not all gloom. China has made great strides in tree planting. But last year a forest fire destroyed more than 600,000ha.

Most countries continue to increase their awareness of the deforestation dangers.

But many Asian nations are deeply impoverished and desperately need their share of the $11 billion a year tropical hardwood industry.

An 11th-hour rescue operation, says the UN's Dr Rao, must involve Australians and other wealthy westerners changing their taste in furniture. Instead of solid wood, buy furniture made of reconstituted wood such as particle board, veneered or laminated, he urges.

urn:contentItem:4P85-14Y0-TXN5-R2RT-00000-00You got me, Babe ... all 40 of you1996-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMPg. 2You got me, Babe ... all 40 of youPETER SMARK

IN THE matter of animal movies, my generation is tough and battle-hardened. We survived, though it was hell, the death of Bambi's Mum. Never mind Psycho or Silence of the Lambs, the forest fire in Bambi was utterly terrifying, and we came through. We can take the tough stuff.

But we like to be left with a few illusions to help us through the two-hanky bits. The news that there wasn't one Babe but more than 40 different porkers cumulatively assembling the lovable character of the wannabe sheepdog is tough to take. Babe was one of the few creatures left worthy of our trust and affection.

With a Federal election looming, we need something we can believe in, and Babe looked like it. Now, the porcine charmer turns out to be the animal world's Michael Jackson - an assemblage of lots of disparate bits stuck together. Why have we been told this? It's like the recipe for haggis. It's better not to know.

In the '70s I did a story in LA about the making of a Lassie movie. Same thing. They not only used 20 or so collies, but half of them were blokes. Why didn't I realise as a kid that those barks sounded a bit baritone for a sensitive and loving female?

The movie-makers said they weren't worried about the collie-gender issue. They fixed the shots in the editing so any inconvenient bits of gear wouldn't show. But what if they were careless? What if it were to dawn on juvenile movie audiences that Lassie was not necessarily one of the earliest champions of the women's movement, but a gender conglomerate, a freak?

I accused them of tampering, perhaps irreparably, with the psyches of generations the world over. They thought I was joking. One of the many troubles with Hollywood is that it's the homeland of the Wicked Witch, where magic is made artfully but heartlessly.

For all I know, the disparate Babes were blokes and sheilas. I'm determined not to know. Because George Miller, director Chris Noonan and the special effects people have done so brilliantly with Babe, because they've pushed people worldwide into the rent-a-kid business ("Oh, we'll take little Nick and Nicola out for a treat. We'll go to see Babe"), because they've even managed to get unaccompanied adults shamelessly drinking up their fable, I intend to be grand and forgive them for the composite.

I intend to see Babe twice, and for the second viewing manufacture a pedigree and provenance for the cuddly porker. Then a single pig will be snugly settled in the mind. I've taken expert advice on the matter.

Remember, the Babes were Aussie pigs. So since the movies are illusion, customers, too, can be illusionists. Let's decree there's one Babe, not 40, and go on from there.

As I understand it, the cognoscenti of the pig world incline to the view that Babe is (more accurately, are) at least principally a Large White, perhaps with a bit of Berkshire in the background. The Berkshire is black with a white face and four white feet. It was very popular a couple of decades ago, and even with modern genetic ideas and new breeds has remained a very strong influence.

One or two pig-fanciers, perhaps wishfully, have read into Babe's background a tiny bit of Tamworth (golden red), though it's hard to discern.

Both mixes with the Large White are said to produce a pig featuring lightly developed forequarters, a long body and welldeveloped hams. There are lots of us who would want these characteristics ourselves. Oh, and the mixes are said also to produce pigs with lots of personality.

And a sense of humour. Ridiculous? Pig people are adamant that your porker is a creature of character and charm, with dogs and cats running a distant second and third.

So, for our second viewing we abolish all thoughts of spare parts porcine assembly. Our invented single-pig Babe has bits of Berkshire and Tamworth because we say so, so there. Very multicultural.

But there is a flaw. One seminal line can be ruled out. You will be wondering, as I was, why the Babe producers didn't plump for a collection of at least a cross of Wessex Saddlebacks (black with a narrow white saddle over the top of the shoulder and down each front leg). You'll be wondering this because the Wessex Saddleback is the only major lop-eared breed and if Babe could have been made any cuter, lop-ears might have done it. Ah, well, maybe in the sequel.

Also, maybe in the sequel there can be some sort of resurrection of the lost breeds, the superbly named Gloucester Old Spot, Poland China and Duroc Jersey, which fell from favour with Australian breeders decades ago. They weren't long enough or lean enough for the table and those fond of attaching human characteristics (which is what Babe is all about) will find that very true of many of us. We unfashionable breeds deserve a place in a movie, too.

What Babe is mostly about is making magic with heart as well as art.

In a world of yobbos, rioting in Bondi, of firemen subjected to hails of missiles while they try to save lives, we need a little warmth and humour, and we need to believe that Babe is one charming pig.

I believe in Babe: I don't necessarily believe that Babe or other pigs can fly.

Babe hasn't asked me to believe that; the politicians will, probably around late February and early March.

urn:contentItem:49NV-BKY0-01S8-C414-00000-00<published>1995-12-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Lara 'egotistical'</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>CRADDOCK ROBERT</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Leaked tour report details Windies rift WEST Indian captain Richie Richardson has made an impassioned plea for Caribbean unity as a once mighty cricket dynasty threatens to self-destruct.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Richardson is an eternal diplomat but even his placid nature is being strained by the forest fire of controversy raging at home in the West Indies following Brian Lara's withdrawal from the tour of Australia.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The West Indian hierarchy are chronically embarrassed by the leaking of tour reports from England revealing that Richardson described Lara as "egotistical" and feared Lara wanted his job as captain.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The report said Richardson was "left in shock" at the indignant way Lara treated respected manager Wes Hall, an icon of West Indian cricket.</p><p>A board meeting in the West Indies today will discuss Lara's future.</p><p>"I have not been reading the papers but have heard Brian and the board have been making statements," Richardson said. "All these comments are being made and I don't think it is really good. Whatever our problems we have to remain quiet and get together.</p><p>"When you start saying this and that it makes it very difficult for the team. It should be a unified thing. You do what you have to do and move on." Richardson spelt out his deeply held belief that the game is bigger than individual players and deserves respect.</p><p>"Cricket will always be here," he said. "We have just got to play it hard, enjoy it and move on. The players move on but the game will always be here." Richardson, who spent almost a year out of international cricket with chronic fatigue problems and who appears a slightly more fragile character since his return, can empathise with the stress which has engulfed Lara.</p><p>Lara has been quoted as saying "cricket is ruining my life" which is an extraordinary statement about a game which has given him three cars, one of the best homes in Trinidad and more than $3 million in career earnings in a land where many residents cannot afford a meal.</p><p>"It can be really tough," Richardson said. "People expect you to do well and you don't have much time to focus on what you have got to do.</p><p>"Sometimes you just want to be in your room but everyone wants you to do this or do that. Everyone wants a piece of you.</p><p>"It gets on top of you after a while. It is unfortunate that Brian is going through that at the moment. It's life. But there are ways of dealing with it. Sometimes you just have to cut yourself off from people." The West Indies face Sri Lanka at the Adelaide Oval today in what is something of a face-saving exercise after this week's humiliation by Rod Marsh's Australian Institute of Sport squad who skittled the tourists for a shameful 92.</p><p>Richardson is adamant his side has the talent to snap the chains of internal dissent and again be a winning unit.</p><p>But the side the West Indies have brought to Australia looks as vulnerable as any Caribbean touring outfit for two decades.</p><p>"People were very disappointed at home but we have done our country proud," Richardson said. "There will be times when things do not go so well but we are just having a lull at the moment. With hard work we will be back where we were 10 years ago. We have won before and we can win again.</p><p>"One of our problems is back home people are asking things in the press all the time. I can't afford to think about what is happening because I can't change it. The most important thing to think about is doing well in the World Series." West Indian coach Andy Roberts laments that the font that once produced so many great players is starting to dry up due to the ever-present influence of basketball on West Indian culture.</p><p>"The game has changed," Roberts said. "The young people today are different to when I was growing up. Basketball is on the television every day _ cricket is not. Our youngsters watch basketball every night." Richardson agreed, saying that West Indian children found it easier to afford basketball because all it required was a pair of shoes compared to the more extensive garb needed for cricket.</p><p>When asked whether any youth development program had been floated in the West Indies, Roberts said: "It has been talked about for a long time but I don't think anything is under construction as yet. We are hoping that in a year or so we can start moving in that direction. But our cricket has never been built on that.</p><p>"It has been built on kids growing up and picking up a bat and starting to play. The love for the game was there in the 60s, 70s and early 80s. I don't know if that love of the game is there now."
