urn:contentItem:57GC-DYD1-JD3N-53JN-00000-00TRIAL BY FIRE2013-01-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 11TRIAL BY FIREJAMIE WALKER

Lessons learned from previous bushfires have saved lives this fierce summer

JOANNA Gash knew at 7am her worst fears would be realised in the Shoalhaven. The temperature was already 32C.

In all her 60 years on NSW's scenic south coast, packed with summer holiday-makers, she had never seen the bush so dry, the wind so blistering or the heat as intense as it was on Tuesday morning.

``It just felt like a disaster waiting to happen,'' she tells Inquirer. ``I thought, `This is a totally unknown quantity. We're in for it today.' ''

The sense of foreboding was widely shared. Australia had been roasting for days and now it was burning, from the bottom up.

On Tasmania's Tasman Peninsula, the hamlets of Dunalley and Boomer Bay lay in blackened ruins after being engulfed by wildfires that destroyed 126 homes.

People were preparing to flee the town of Drik Drik in southwest Victoria as firefighters in that state struggled to keep a lid on the growing emergency. Most of South Australia was under fire bans.

And in Queensland's thickly populated southeast corner, emergency services went on high alert to cope with the extreme conditions coming their way.

Something had to give, and with Sydney forecast to bake in 40C+ temperatures, the area of maximum vulnerability was southeastern NSW in general and the Shoalhaven in particular.

Yet here we are at the end of this week of high anxiety and drama, after NSW faced what Premier Barry O'Farrell described as its worst day of bushfire danger on record and most of the nation sweltered in record heat, and not a single life has been lost to the flames. Not anywhere. There is a lot of summer to come -- but so far, so good.

Sussex Inlet, the waterfront town in the Shoalhaven most threatened, is still standing, though it was touch and go for a while on Tuesday.

By 2pm, the mercury had hit 43C and the fire burning in the nearby Jerrawangala State Forest was out of control. Fanned by the fierce winds, it jumped the Princess Highway.

Gash, the 68-year-old local mayor and outgoing federal Liberal MP, thought the conditions were worse than those of January 2, 2002, when a dozen homes were lost in Sussex Inlet.

``It was just so hot, and the winds were so strong,'' she says.

Then the southerly change arrived earlier than forecast. It may be that this was the piece of luck that spared Sussex Inlet, just as lives were unquestionably saved on the Tasman Peninsula by the proximity of the devastated communities to the sea, providing those caught by the fires with a last-minute way out that was not open to the 173 Victorians who perished on February 7, 2009.

Yet could it be, as Gash argues, that there is more to it than that. She says state and local authorities in the Shoalhaven absorbed the lessons of 2002, of the Canberra bushfires a year later, of Black Saturday and the royal commission it spawned, and put a plan into effect that made a decisive difference.

``People were very much on the ball, which has not happened before,'' she says. ``The temptation, I suppose, is for people to go, `Oh, this is overkill'. But I don't believe in that. I think our preparedness, how the fire and emergency services worked with the community, was the key factor on the day. And I would rather be accused of overkill than of killing someone.''

FOR now, the only casualty at Sussex Inlet is a single, burned-out packing shed in an orchard well outside the town precinct. Far more remarkable was the absence of deaths or even a case of serious injury in the firestorm that engulfed the Tasman Peninsula late last week. But as the NSW Rural Fire Service's commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons noted drily: ``We're not out of the woods yet.'' Temperatures are rising again, with Brisbane heading for the mid-30s today, Sydney forecast to top 39C and Canberra facing 37C, and there is no end in sight to the continent-wide heatwave at the seat of the emergency.

Bushfire management is an intensely complicated business. The priorities often compete. The interests of a fire service in reducing vegetative fuel loads don't necessarily accord with those of a national parks or state forestry agency managing public land.

On private property, the long-recognised need to establish cleared buffers between homes and forests in fire-prone areas was also a key recommendation of the royal commission into Black Saturday, but experts say the implementation is patchy at best.

Compounding this is what the Stretton inquiry into Victoria's 1939 Black Friday disaster described as the ``hand of man'' that helped kill 71: more people living in areas more vulnerable to bushfire, with more opportunity for conflagrations to erupt.

Then there is climate change. If the scientific modelling is borne out, hotter, drier summers in southern Australia will increase the general risk of bushfire and frequency of the catastrophic conditions that attended Black Saturday nearly four years ago.

Still, the choice for people caught in the path of bushfire remains primordial in essence: fight or flight. Prior to 2009, the policy was officially termed, in Victoria at least, as ``Prepare, stay and defend or leave early''. ``Stay or go'' was much catchier, and caught on.

While the Black Saturday royal commission found the central tenets of the policy remained sound, this week demonstrated the notion that anyone could or should defend property against a direct hit from bushfire in extreme conditions had been abandoned by fire services.

``We don't even refer to `stay or go','' says Stuart Ellis, a former chief executive of the Country Fire Service in South Australia who now heads the peak Australasian Fire and Emergency Service Authorities Council. ``The focus is very much on the primacy of life and having that as the fundamental message. Clearly the easiest and most guaranteed approach is not to be there in the first place.''

Fitzsimmons made no bones about what he thought people should do in the lead-up to Tuesday in the NSW danger zone. ``Leaving early under catastrophic conditions is your safest option,'' he said.

Philip Gibbons, a land management expert with the Australian National University, was struck by the shift in emphasis. ``The conventional wisdom used to be that you had a good chance of saving your property if you stayed and defended -- provided you were prepared and up to doing it,'' he tells Inquirer.

``Black Saturday was a game changer in that area and the message has now softened somewhat. It is far more cautionary.''

As Gibbons points out, the 2009 fires outside Melbourne set a grim new benchmark not only in terms of the death toll: 2133 houses were destroyed on Black Saturday, representing the highest ratio of fatalities to homes lost in a bushfire disaster, he says.

John Handmer, a disaster expert with RMIT University, analysed how ``stay or go'' played out. More than two thirds of the victims died in or immediately outside their homes, he found in research for the Victorian bushfires royal commission.

In a paper last year, Handmer and the University of Melbourne's Saffron O'Neill reported that at least 44 per cent of those who died on Black Saturday had limited physical capacity to fight a fire: they were too young or too old -- aged under 12 or over 70 -- or were disabled, ill or affected by alcohol.

Handmer says the disaster brutally exposed how the emergency services and the people they were supposed to protect were, in the main, ``ill adapted'' to such complex and fast-moving circumstances. The historic certainty that homes could be defended from a ``normal'' fire melted away when the conflagration tipped over into extreme or catastrophic levels. Less than half of the Black Saturday victims had a clear fire plan -- even though this was central to the ``stay or go'' ethos.

Fire plans that did exist were of ``variable'' quality. Some contained a fatal flaw, such as directing household members to shelter in a bathroom, from which there was no escape, and most had no back-up option if the preferred plan of action fell through. ``Agency decision-making on the day did not adapt to deal with the changed risk,'' he concludes in his study with O'Neill.

Handmer says the Tasmania Fire Service, in particular, took those lessons on board and maybe -- just maybe -- it worked on the Tasman Peninsula. ``The change means that when conditions are exceptionally severe, as they were when the big fires occurred that destroyed Dunalley (on the Tasman Peninsula), the fire service would . . . just focus on people's lives and key assets, because in the past there would have been a big rush to extinguish the fire, which is impossible in those conditions,'' he explains.

``This is a system that is only just coming in and I think it's too early to assess it. But I guess you could argue that it has had some success . . . so maybe we are seeing an early pay-off. I'd like to think so.''

In the Shoalhaven, ``we let the fire come to us'', Gash says. All available tankers and crews -- about 300-strong, mainly volunteers from the NSW Rural Fire Service -- were deployed in defensive positions to protect Sussex Inlet and vulnerable properties.

National parks were cleared 24 hours in advance. As in Tasmania, one of the main concerns was the number of tourists in the red zone, and Gash estimates there would have been more than 300,000 holidaying in the NSW south coast district, on top of its 100,000-odd residents.

Anyone foolish enough to question the order to leave a campsite or vulnerable area was brusquely told they would be marched out if they did not go voluntarily.

In Sussex Inlet, evacuation centres were set up at the local RSL and the bowling club. As the hour of reckoning approached on Tuesday, more than 600 people sought refuge. Text alerts were sent to those still in the danger area.

By now, the message from the fire service had shifted. For people in the immediate path of the fire, it was too late to leave. Come what may, they would be safer in their homes than on the road, fire chief Fitzsimmons said.

Ellis says it's a good example of how fire services have altered their approach. ``They are now in the business of providing information and warnings as well as emergency response,'' he says.

``The mantra here is putting out the information is as important as putting out the fire. The emphasis on the day may be as much as

Continued from Page 11

50 per cent on the information and 50 per cent on the operational response.

Gary Morgan, chief executive of the Bushfire Co-operative Research Centre, points out that people don't always respond to bushfire warnings as intended. Ahead of Black Saturday, there was no lack of information about the gravity of the threat. Then Victorian premier John Brumby employed language that was echoed by O'Farrell this week, in speaking of the state entering ``uncharted territory''.

Yet, in all too many cases, the message didn't sink in.

ELLIS wonders whether a degree of bushfire fatigue will set in with the public as the heat and the alerts continue to come.

The messaging this week was clear, effective and worked particularly well in NSW, he says. But ``if that was to occur next week and the week after and in February, are we going to get the same response from the communities? I guess that's quite a challenging question that is really unanswered.''

NSW Rural Fire Service deputy commissioner Bob Rogers says Black Saturday hammered home the need for agencies to be more direct in their language. The adoption of the new warning of ``catastrophic'' to denote Black Saturday-like conditions is a case in point. This adds a new, unambiguously ominous dimension to the threat level based on the Forest Fire Danger Index, which was introduced on a scale of 1-100 to rate fire risks such as heat, humidity and wind.

The conditions on Black Saturday were off the chart, up to 190 points under the FFDI. Like the weather bureau, which has increased the scope of its temperature tables to accommodate 50C+ heat, the bushfire warning system has been adjusted, with the catastrophic level kicking in at 150 points. Roughly, that would generally involve heat of more than 40C, single-digit humidity and winds gusting well above 35km/h, Ellis says. Tellingly, however, a fire risk rated as extreme -- that is, 50 points or above -- is the point at which the services now acknowledge that any outbreak may be beyond their control.

Andrew Sullivan, team leader of the CSIRO's Bushfire Dynamics and Applications Group, says the window of opportunity to contain a blaze is brutally tight in catastrophic conditions -- as little as 15 minutes for a grassfire and two hours in the forest.

Encouragingly, his research suggests the fire services are getting better at their job, partly because they are more realistic about what can be done.

Another weapon is prescribed burning to reduce fuel loads. The Black Saturday inquiry recommended a three-fold increase in the area being burned in Victoria, which was accepted by the state government. How it has been implemented, though, is quite another thing.

The ANU's Gibbons found that what counted was not how much country was burned, but where. In Victoria, much of the quota was filled by prescribed burns in remote areas. ``The management is focused on the target rather than the objective,'' he says.

Phil Cheney, a former head of bushfire research and management at the CSIRO, says state land managers such as national parks services, forestry agencies and water boards are palming off responsibility for paring back fuel loads to fire services, which lack the resources to do the job properly.

The honourable exception, he says, is Western Australia, which fires up to 8 per cent of its burnable estate a year.

No one would suggest this week's let-off in NSW was anything but a temporary reprieve, with 99 fires burning across the state, some still uncontained, and fire services stretched in Tasmania, Victoria, the ACT and South Australia.

A long, nervous summer rolls on for a nation that remains deeply scarred by the experience of that blackest of Saturdays

in 2009.

urn:contentItem:49NY-KPR0-01S8-81DM-00000-00<published>1995-12-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Captain's plea for team unity Windies look vulnerable</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY ROBERT CRADDOCK</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">West Indian captain Richie Richardson has made a heartfelt plea for Caribbean unity as a once-mighty cricket dynasty threatens to self-destruct. Richardson is an eternal diplomat but even his placid nature is being strained by the forest fire of controversy raging at home in the West Indies following Brian Lara's withdrawal from the tour of Australia. The West Indies today face Sri Lanka in the World Series opener at Adelaide Oval in what is something of a face-saving exercise after this week's humiliation by Rod Marsh's cricket academy squad who skittled the tourists for a shameful 92. But seeing will be believing. The side the West Indies have brought to Australia looks as vulnerable as any Caribbean touring outfit for two decades. Tension between the West Indies and local media heightened yesterday when team management ordered a security guard not to admit media inside the Adelaide Oval nets when the players were practising. Television crews were forced to film from above a fence behind the nets. The West Indian hierarchy is chronically embarrassed by the leaking of tour reports from England revealing that Richardson described Lara as "egotistical" and feared Lara wanted his job as captain. The report said Richardson was "left in shock" at the way Lara had treated respected manager Wes Hall, an icon of West Indian cricket. A board meeting in the West Indies today will discuss Lara's future. "I've not been reading the papers but have heard Brian and the Board have been making statements," Richardson said yesterday.</p><p>"All these comments are being made and I don't think it is really good. Whatever our problems we have to remain quiet and get together. "When you start saying this and that it makes it very difficult for the team. It should be a unified thing. You do what you have to do and move on." Richardson spelt out his deeply held belief that the game is bigger than individual players and deserves full respect. "Cricket will always be here. We have just got to play it hard, enjoy it and move on," he said. "The players move on but the game will always be here." Richardson, who spent almost a year out of international cricket with chronic fatigue problems and who appears a slightly more fragile character since his return, can empathise with the stress which has engulfed Lara. Lara has been quoted as saying "cricket is ruining my life" which is an extraordinary statement about a game which has given him three cars, one of the best homes in Trinidad and more than $3 million in career earnings in a land where many residents cannot afford a meal. "It can be really tough," Richardson said. "People expect you to do well and you don't have much time to focus on what you have got to do. Sometimes you just want to be in your room but everyone wants you to do this or do that. Everyone wants a piece of you. "It gets on top of you after a while. It is unfortunate that Brian is going through that at the moment. It's life. But there are ways of dealing with it. Sometimes you just have to cut yourself off from people." Richardson is adamant his side has the talent to snap the chains of internal dissent and again be a winning unit. "People are very disappointed at home but we have done our country proud," Richardson said. "There will be times when things do not go so well but we are just having a lull at the moment. With hard work we will be back where we were 10 years ago. "We have won before and we can win again. "One of our problems is that back home people are asking things in the press all the time. "I can't afford to think about what is happening because I can't change it. The most important thing to think about is doing well in the World Series." West Indies coach Andy Roberts laments that the font that once produced so many great players is starting to dry up due to the ever-present influence of basketball on West Indian culture. "The game has changed," Roberts said. "The young people today are different to when I was growing up. Basketball is on the television every day cricket is not. Our youngsters watch basketball every night." Richardson agreed, saying that West Indian children found it easier to afford basketball because all it required was a pair of shoes compared with the more extensive garb needed for cricket. When asked whether any youth development program had been floated in the West Indies, Roberts said: "It has been talked about for a long time but I don't think anything is under construction as yet. "We are hoping that in a year or so we can start moving in that direction. But our cricket has never been built on that. "It's been built on kids growing up and picking up a bat and starting to play. "The love for the game was there in the '60s, '70s and early '80s. I don't know if that love of the game is there now. "People forget we have lost four great players all at one time Viv Richards, Gordon Greenidge, Jeff Dujon and Malcolm Marshall. It's difficult to lose them because we have never had replacements for them."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>2 photos (color): carl hooper, roland urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGD0-TXN5-R2DC-00000-00HAWKE FIRM IN FACE OF ATTACK BY VANUATU PM1987-05-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 1HAWKE FIRM IN FACE OF ATTACK BY VANUATU PMDAVID JENKINS and PATRICK WALTERS

VILA, Monday: The Prime Minister of Vanuatu, Father Walter Lini, today issued a blistering attack on covert Australian intelligence activities against his small South Pacific nation.

Returning to work three months after suffering a crippling stroke, the 45-year-old Prime Minister confirmed his decision of late last week to suspend indefinitely all visits by Australian Naval vessels and Air Force planes.

In Canberra, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said Australia would continue to monitor developments in the South Pacific, despite the rift with Vanuatu.

"We have a legitimate concern about developments in the South Pacific, and we will continue to monitor developments in the region.

"We will say and we will do what we think is necessary to protect the interests of the countries in the region."

Government sources would neither confirm nor deny that Australia had engaged in intelligence activities in Vanuatu.

Father Lini said he remained willing to receive a senior Australian Foreign Affairs official, Mr David Sadleir, who arrives in Port Vila on Friday.

Mr Sadleir will visit South Pacific capitals to brief governments about Australian concerns over the alleged increase in Libyan activity in the region.

Father Lini also said he hoped Australia and Vanuatu could normalise relations "once certain understandings have been reached".

In an interview which went to air last night, Father Lini told a Channel 10 reporter that the Libyan leader, Colonel Gaddafi, had told him in Zimbabwe that he could give Vanuatu cheap oil - "much more than we get from Australia or Singapore or anywhere".

Vanuatu would look at this possibility and co-operate in such a scheme.

Anti-Australian feeling is running high in Government circles in Vila.

Officials here are angered by what they see as Canberra's attempt to pillory them for their links with Libya, and dismayed at the forest fire of negative publicity their nation has received lately in the Australian press.

In a statement issued at noon today, Father Lini, who is also the acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, said the decision to bar Australian military ships and aircraft was taken to demonstrate the Government's "extreme displeasure over the reported

activities by Australian intelligence against Vanuatu".

He said he was not retaliating against Australia over the Libyan connection, which he saw as a non-issue.

His main concern was "Australian intelligence interference into Vanuatu's domestic affairs".

Vanuatu, as a sovereign state, would "strongly oppose these types of covert activities".

The move by Vanuatu comes after reports in the Australian press that the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, made his recent early-morning visit to New Zealand after intelligence reports that showed an increase in Libyan activities in the South Pacific.

According to the reports, small quantities of arms and ammunition may have been shipped to Vanuatu from Libya.

Officials in Vanuatu have vigorously denied that any such shipments have been made.

There has been no indication about the source of the reports.

The abrupt downturn in Australian-Vanuatu relations, which comes several weeks before the South Pacific Forum Meeting in Western Samoa, has already had a significant impact on the military front. Among the consequences:

Australia has been forced to cancel a visit to Vanuatu by Vice-Admiral Peter Sinclair, the RAN Fleet Commander.

Australia will almost certainly be obliged to cancel the planned visit of an Australian warship to Vanuatu next week.

Australia has suspended flights out of Vanuatu by long-range Orion maritime patrol aircraft.

Despite the row, there has been no ill-will shown to Australian tourists or residents in Vila.

It is understood that Vanuatu has given no indication that it would refuse to accept an Australian-made naval patrol boat later this year, despite some Australian press reports to this effect.

Referring to reports that some countries might raise the issue of Vanuatu's links with Libya at this month's South Pacific Forum meeting in Apia, father Lini said the forum had no mandate to interfere in domestic policies of its member states. He said if this were allowed to happen it could signal the end of the forum.

The Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Mr Paias Wingti, will host a pre-Forum summit meeting of the three Melanesian leaders next week to discuss Libya's growing interest in the region.

"We cannot allow the question of Libya's interest in the region to divide members of the South Pacific Forum," Mr Wingti said today.

He is expected to voice PNG concern about Libya's involvement in the Pacific when he meets the Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands, Mr Ezekiel Alebua, and Father Lini in Rabaul.

In Port Moresby, a spokesman for OPM rebels opposed to Indonesian rule in Irian Jaya said they were receiving guerilla training in Libya.

He refused to give details of the training or recruitment or to say whether Libyan trained rebels were operating inside Irian Jaya.

urn:contentItem:53D1-6D61-JCVT-J1X0-00000-00Future shock2011-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisWEEKENDERPg. 6Future shockCOVER STORY GREEN EDITIONJODIE DUFFY

The effects of climate change will hit the Illawarra hard, writes JODIE DUFFY. IMAGINE LIVING IN A WORLD WHERE bushfires were up to three times more likely to destroy the escarpment and Royal National Park. A world where a 100-year flood happened every year and Wollongong commuters who work in Sydney have to find alternative transport as 50km of rail-line in the Illawarra and Shoalhaven is inundated by water. Also say goodbye to the southern brown bandicoot, the green and golden bell frog and 67 other endangered species that reside in the region's bush and wetlands. Warmer weather will put all living things under stress, including people.

Pile on top of that severe droughts interspersed with frequent flash flooding. That's the future our grandchildren will face if they choose to live in Wollongong and we do nothing this decade about global warming, says Climate Commissioner Professor Will Steffen. What it will take to halt or slow the process is a reduction in carbon pollution from burning coal, oil and gas and an investment in cleaner forms of energy. Prof Steffen, a renowned climate scientist, has prepared an impact statement on climate change in the Illawarra and Shoalhaven to be released at the Transforming Australia conference to be held on Monday and Tuesday in Wollongong. The report is a future snapshot of what life will be like in the region with a warmer world and rising sea levels. While much of the impact can be stopped or slowed, some of the changes, like an increase in bushfires, have already begun. "We've already seen that bushfires have risen 10 to 40 per cent in south-eastern Australia because of the higher temperatures and humidity levels," Steffen says. "This is not something for the future, it's already occurring." Not only will bushfires be bigger, they'll also be more intense. Statistics from the Forest Fire Danger Index show that in Nowra, for example, between now and 2050 the number of extreme fire danger days will increase depending on the climate scenario. "Instead of one extreme fire danger day a season Nowra will get two to three days," says Steffen. "That figure will be the same for the Illawarra and the Royal National Park." Unlike other regions along the east coast it's harder to predict what will happen to the Illawarra's rainfall, which is already high due to the position of the escarpment. "The Illawarra doesn't fit into the modelling for the rest of the east coast," he says. "So we're a lot less certain as to what's going to happen in regards to rainfall in the area. We have seen a drying trend in the last 40 years in the Illawarra, but there's no consistency. "Some (experts) say it'll get wetter, while others say it will get drier. The fact that the Illawarra has naturally high rainfall variability makes it hard to pick." When droughts occur he says they will be more severe and will have a greater impact on all plants and animals. "I think that it's likely there will be more severe droughts punctuated by more extreme heavy rainfall on the escarpment with flash flooding downstream caused by a rise in sea level," Steffen says. "A fair bit of the Illawarra will be at risk of inundation depending on how high the sea levels continue to rise." Sea levels have increased by 20cm since the 1880s and will continue to rise, with predictions of an increase of 50cm by 2100. "Rising sea levels is something we will all have to live with," he says. "It's already in the pipeline because of big thermal inertia in the ocean. Even a modest rise of 50cm, although we may not notice the difference, will lead to a much larger increase in flooding events than you would expect." Many parts of the coastline, including the Illawarra, will see a one in 100 year flood event every year depending on the topography of the area and how high sea levels rise. Such extreme sea level events, or flash flooding, will occur with a combination of a high tide and a deep east coast low. Steffen says the risk is greater in any coastal area that has an escarpment. "When you couple that with an extreme rainfall event on the escarpment you have a double whammy event," he says. "A storm surge plus heavy rainfall could be bad for the Illawarra." Steffen says rising sea levels threaten infrastructure, property and buildings - particularly those built on sand dunes. "Wollongong is second to Newcastle in terms of the length of rail lines at risk of being inundated by rising seal levels," he says. "An estimated 50km of rail in the Illawarra and Shoalhaven will be subject to more frequent flooding by a sea level approaching a metre." A sea-level rise of 1.1m, which Steffen predicts will probably occur next century, will threaten hundreds of buildings in the Wollongong and Shoalhaven areas. Since the 1940s flooding events have already increased three-fold in some areas of Australia. "That's consistent with the 20cm rise in sea levels that we've already seen," he says. "So we're starting to see things happen which are consistent with a warming climate. I think there is little doubt which direction this is going." Even if the world manages to constrain climate change future generations will still have to deal with the fallout of global warming. "We need to mitigate climate change and cap the temperature rise by two degrees," he says. "If we can do that we'll really be making a big difference to the world that our children and grandchildren will have to live in. There will still be some impact, but the severity of a lot of things will be affected on what we do now. Our grandchildren will be the recipients of the actions we take or don't take in this decade." It's also thought that low-lying areas around Lake Illawarra and Windang will be badly affected as the lake, which is a ponding area for several streams, floods. Chief Climate Commissioner Professor Tim Flannery, a keynote speaker at the conference, says it's not so much about bringing down global temperatures, but preventing the Earth from heating up further. Even after all carbon emissions are stopped the planet will continue to warm for some time. "A carbon price for polluters is a necessary measure," he says. "Other countries have done it and now Australia has joined them." Flannery refuses to comment further on the Federal Government's climate change policy. "We've given away the power to comment on that," he says. "The Climate Commission wants to be respected by people as an independent source of information. We take a longer term view based on the science." He says it's not too late to avoid the most dangerous implications of climate change but warns a carbon price alone won't be enough. "It's an important step but doesn't do everything that's required," he says. "Countries overseas have a mix of policies which also include subsidies and regulation." Other measures are using energy more efficiently and investing and researching in cleaner forms of energy. Australia has a bipartisan agreement to increase renewable energy and reduce carbon pollution by 5 per cent by 2020, with the aim of living in a decarbonised economy in 40 years. "It's a big job," he says. "But it's achievable if we take action this decade. This is a critically important time in history. A defining moment. "Early action is relatively inexpensive action, if we leave it beyond this decade it gets more expensive. There are choices our generation needs to make." He's urged ordinary Australians to become better informed on the issues by listening to the peer-reviewed science which says that there's a 95 per cent chance that global warming is caused by human pollution. "Peer-reviewed science is a bit like a set of audited accounts in business, it's credible. It's been certified by the experts," he says. "If scientists choose to step outside peer review science what they're really giving is just their opinion. Some of the science will be alarming to some people. But I think once people are well informed they can make their own decisions." Flannery says a lot of money needs to be invested to research and develop sustainable energy. "I don't think we will need nuclear power stations in Australia because we have an abundance of renewable energy," he says. "I think in the end we will rely on a mix of things. Wind is now coming into its own as an industry and I think if we invest in a super grid, a high-voltage connector across Australia, we won't lose a lot of electricity." South Coast Labour Council Council Secretary Arthur Rorris says renewable energy industries have the potential to create hundreds of Illawarra jobs. He says the region is best placed to tap into the government's $10 billion sustainable investment package because it already has a Green Jobs Illawarra Action Plan which was launched in 2009. "There are 20 recommendations in that plan on how the region can create green jobs," he says. "What was missing before was a vehicle for investment and now, with this package, we have it. The Illawarra should be a winner from this. It should secure green jobs for our region. Some of the recommendations include research and development, a Green Street to showcase the available sustainable technologies at West Dapto, upskilling and retooling the manufacturing sector so they can play a bigger role in renewable energy, a community windfarm project and a $1 billion co-generation plant at Port Kembla to be built by BlueScope Steel which would create 2000 construction jobs and stop one million tonnes of greenhouse gases being released into the atmosphere each year. One Illawarra company, David Brown Gear is already reaping the benefits of renewable energy technology attracting $300,000 in work to repair transmissions in wind turbines and tower inspections for wind farms. It's estimated that wind turbine work will make up 10 per cent of the company's business over the next decade. "David Brown Gear makes gearing systems for the coal mining industry," Rorris says. "What the company does is transform these gears for use in wind turbines. So in a way it's a fairy tale solution about transforming local industry." He says other job opportunities may exist in the manufacturing of clean energy. "We need to make sure that our region remains competitive and I think we should look at the steel industry as our strength," he says. "While it's a big producer of carbon emissions because that's the nature of steel making, we also need to make steel to manufacture and harness renewable energy. For example it takes 150 tonnes of steel to build each wind turbine." " The Transforming Australia conference will be held at the Novotel Northbeach on Monday and Tuesday. A Smart Living Expo at the Town Hall tomorrow, showcasing sustainable products and businesses, will kick-start the conference.

urn:contentItem:52V9-HJ01-JD3N-54KM-00000-00Letters to the Editor OPINION2011-05-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 34Letters to the Editor OPINION

Time for reflection

THE further delay to Ku-ring-gai Council's decision on the Jewish community's application to erect an eruv in St Ives, according to council now not expected until late June or early July, is probably no bad thing.

It gives us all, particularly our councillors, more time to reflect that some peculiar things are done in the name of religion.

It becomes important to ask whether we of a secular bent are really supposed to accept that a wire strung between poles (the eruv) makes it OK for Orthodox Jews to carry out such simple tasks as pushing a pram or a pedestrian crossing button on the Jewish Sabbath? Surely not. There's no rationality to it, at least to a mind not steeped in arcane religious practices.

Of course, there's no rationality either to a belief that makes an Islamic woman cover up in public to the extent of having to open a flap over her mouth each time she wants to spoon in food.

Nor does there seem to be much sense to the medieval papal dictate that condemns Christian priests to lives of celibacy.

No doubt those of deep religious conviction can explain and rationalise these mysterious shibboleths, but why ask the rest of the community to not only accept them but, in the case of the eruv, have it imposed?

Which all goes to show that freedom to practice the religion of one's choice in Australia is fine as long as the peculiar bits are not imposed on the rest of us.

Alexander Johnson

St Ives

Transport a tangle

THE online Ku-ring-gai Integrated Transport Strategy Report is an intention to try to minimise traffic by convincing residents to abandon their motor vehicles in favour of public transport, bicycles or even walking.

These three options, initially, seem quite feasible until the problems of each are considered.

Weather conditions combined with the individual's physical capabilities would be major considerations to the outcome of these options. Even if 1 per cent of all company employees cycled to work, would there be mandatory showering facilities awaiting? Would a family shopper be expected to cycle home from the supermarket laden with a week's supply for a family of four?

Public transport is a continually flogged option but no matter how efficient Ku-ring-gai's system may become, as long as the car is an option, that's how most will travel.

We have been told that the saturation of high rise has been built close to stations to entice people on to trains, but again as long as people can drive they will.

The council's Sustainability Vision Summary Report 2008-2033 states: ``Ku-ring-gai will be a creative, healthy and liveable place where people respect each other, conserve the magnificent environment and society for the children and for the grandchildren of the future''.

Believe it or not, Ku-ring-gai is achieving this already but the immoral destruction of the existing character being replaced with heartless concrete slabs will create a less personal atmosphere alienating people from each other resulting in more social problems.

Although it was terrific to see the demise in March of the previous state government it seems Ku -ring-gai will now suffer the commitment of a premier who is determined to enforce the cap of 10,000 units by 2031 as mutually agreed to by the previous government and our own local council, but it was never agreed to by the community.

I call on Premier Barry O'Farrell to come clean with Ku-ring-gai and tell us what his ultimate plan and/or vision is for our once unique municipality.

Finally, as a community we should consider that bad things happen if good people do nothing.

Jeremy Lowther

Turramurra

Village people

THESE smaller, village-type shopping strips dotted throughout Ku-ring-gai municipality fulfill a need and have a real potential to serving the needs of the local community (``Princes St upgrade to start, at long last,'' Times, May 6.)

They are convenient, easily accessed and divert their clients away from more congested areas like central Wahroonga and Turramurra.

They should be supported so they offer an alternative to these more congested places.

The support should include ways to make them more visually appealing and provide an atmosphere which will aid in adding more opportunities and $ turnover to these local centres.

Mark White

online comment

Planning powers

WHILE I thank Premier Barry O'Farrell, MP Jonathan O'Dea and Planning Minister Brad Hazzard for honouring part of their election promises to Ku-ring-gai citizens in abolishing Labor's appalling Ku-ring-gai Planning Panel there is still a way to go in honouring their promise to hand back planning and decision-making to local communities.

The new Liberal Government has left the Sydney West Regional Planning Panel (SWRPP) and other similar panels in place in NSW.

The developments these panels are determining on the whole, is not state significant development. The SWRPP removes decision-making from the local community and Ku-ring-gai Council.

Until the SWRPP (and all regional planning panels across NSW) is abolished we will continue to see the majority of Ku-ring-gai's high-rise unit developments being determined by an appointed government panel instead of the elected council.

I urge the Premier and his Government to honour his written election promise to return powers to local communities without any further delay.

Kathy Cowley

Lindfield

Thanks to hospital

ON the New Year long weekend I took my sick husband to Royal North Shore Hospital emergency department.

My husband had a serious heart problem and had not been coping well in the weeks leading up to New Year.

From the moment we arrived at the emergency department, where he was treated immediately, we were treated with respect and with the utmost consideration.

When all one reads in the newspapers these days is how hopeless our systems are it takes away our confidence in their ability to give proper care and attention.

Our treatment was tremendous and my everlasting gratitude goes to those noble people.

My husband died, however, not one member of my family felt that any more could have been done to save him. This is a great comfort to us all.

Amber Edwards

Roseville

Help for helpers

I WRITE on behalf of The Salvation Army to ask readers for their help with this year's Red Shield Appeal.

To be frank, after all the challenges we've faced in recent months, including helping the victims of floods and Cyclone Yasi resources, are severely stretched.

It has already been a year of unprecedented natural disasters. Australians have joined together to respond with typical generosity. And many Australians are facing personal disasters such as homelessness, financial hardship, violence in the home, suicide bereavement and unemployment.

We need to raise $79 million by the end of June to continue our vital work of assisting vulnerable Australians. It's remarkable to think that every 12 months the Salvos help around 1 million people. All donations help us to change lives.

To help, you can either call 13 SALVOS (13 72 58) or visit www.salvos.org.au.

The Red Shield Appeal doorknock is on the weekend of May 28/29 and the need for support is simply enormous.

Major Peter Sutcliffe

The Salvation Army

Don't rubbish the charity bins

A COUPLE of years ago you reported on the appalling amount of rubbish left outside charity bins in the car park at Koola Ave, East Killara.

For a while there was some improvement but now, once again, thoughtless people are dumping an enormous amount of rubbish in the car park.

So much of it could be easily disposed of by Ku-ring-gai Council's excellent waste disposal services. For example, cardboard boxes can be flattened and put out in the regular paper recycling bin.

Charities will collect good, useable household items or you can take them to the various charity shops nearby.

Even broken furniture, crockery, useless electrical appliances and toys can all be taken away legitimately, at no cost, by the council's monthly pick-up service. All it takes is a call to Ku-ring-gai Council requesting the service.

As I was waiting in the car park yesterday I saw a man adding yet more rubbish to the pile already in front of the bins. I very politely asked him if he realised it was illegal to dump rubbish, pointing out the Council's notice prohibiting such behaviour, and advised him of the services available. He replied casually he would ``let them know about it''.

Perhaps it would help if Ku-ring-gai Council enclosed with their rate notices, an advice in different languages, regarding their services and warning of the fine for disposing of their rubbish so thoughtlessly.

Audrey Howard, Killara

to the point

May 13

* YOU may like to make your own assessment of the voting intentions of the two St Ives councillors, Tony Hall and Carolyne Hardwick. I am led to believe that they will both vote in favour of the proposal to proceed with the installation of the eruv, against the wishes of the majority of their constituents. I guess the residents will have a chance at the next elections to express their disapproval or otherwise.

Ian Cameron

St Ives

* I WOULD like to express a huge thank-you to the Forestville-Frenchs Forest Fire and Rescue officers and Frenchs Forest policemen who attended my grandson's house on Saturday morning. My two-year-old grandson, Ben, got his finger stuck in the bath plughole. He was very upset and distressed but the caring, compassionate way the officers responded to my grandson was very professional and much appreciated. Great job, fellas. Well done.

Dennis Gilmour

Forestville

* SCULPTURAL and decorative as the new seats are at Chowder Bay, they are hopeless as viewing seats for people, especially the elderly. They seem to be used for standing or lying upon. I'm sure I'm not alone in voicing the need for a few proper park benches with backs to enjoy this marvellous view of the harbour. Perhaps on the nearby grass area.

A Crawford

Mosman

* I WOULD like to compliment the staff at the Oaks for presenting the hotel so beautifully on Mother's Day. The mauve and pink balloons, along with a chrysanthemum on each table, were truly lovely touches. In a day when most restaurants make little or no effort on Mother's Day, the whole atmosphere could only make all mums feel very special.

Sharon Glasson

Mosman

urn:contentItem:4H87-5X50-015H-90V3-00000-00<published>2005-10-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>LETTERS TO THE EDITOR</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Milk price rise unjustified</p><p nitf:lede="true">Milk is going up 18c a litre on the basis, it is claimed, of the increase in fuel prices.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A typical milk tanker seems to be around 30,000 litres, so the community is paying some $6000 extra per load just for the increase in fuel costs.</p><p nitf:lede="true">A milk run from farm to processing factory is, say, a round 250km.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Fuel consumption in a typical sort of prime mover the tankers are pulled by is, say, three miles per gallon or one litre per kilometre, so the increase in cost (remember, not the total fuel cost) is around $100 per load.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Assume distribution from the processing factory to the retail outlet is three times more expensive due to start and stop, et cetera, so an additional $300 in increased fuel costs.</p><p>The total increased cost so far then is $400. Where is the other $5600? Not all in increases in incoming cartons, I think.</p><p>Now this is, of course, all voodoo economics but even if I am out by a factor of five, that still does not explain 67 per cent of the increase.</p><p>It would certainly seem that Minister Truss's comments that only one or two cents is justified are correct.</p><p>Are we being milked?</p><p>G. A. Watts</p><p>Claremont</p><p>Objectivity</p><p>In Commentary (October 3) Greg Barns, under the headline "Donnelly gets an F for objectivity", gives us some fascinating reading.</p><p>Since all state governments at the moment are Labor, it's hard to see how Donnelly can be accused of bias when he ranks Queensland, New South Wales and South Australia first in various disciplines.</p><p>When Barns refers to "ideological fetishists like Mr Donnelly" and "the barrow-pushing Mr Donnelly", he does not exactly qualify to be graded A for objectivity!</p><p>John Solomon</p><p>Taroona</p><p>Professionalism</p><p>Greg Barns' commentary "Donnelly gets an F for objectivity" (The Mercury, October 3) is informative for those who seek balance in the debate about the worth of educational reforms in Tasmania.</p><p>To the same audience, I suggest that none of the recent media flurry about our Essential Learnings has disproved the following assertions:</p><p>Tasmanian students deserve a curriculum that prepares them for an uncertain, hard to predict and rapidly-changing world.</p><p>Els integrates traditional subjects and child-centred approaches to teaching within a values framework in a way that is intended to help our students to adapt and prosper as lifelong learners and Tasmanian citizens.</p><p>Debate and anxiety are corollaries of reform. They will diminish once parents understand ELs and teachers adapt to teaching them.</p><p>Teachers will not say they are ready to report students' progress against the ELs until they are satisfied that their reporting will be accurate and meaningful.</p><p>The professionalism of our teachers will ensure that the first phase of ELs will be implemented and reported by the end of this year.</p><p>Those who misrepresent uncertainties about ELs as showing failure in our system of education should reflect on our teachers' fine work in effecting such important improvements for our students before undermining their efforts.</p><p>David Billing</p><p>President</p><p>Tasmanian Principals Association</p><p>Hobart College</p><p>Toy Run</p><p>As a participant in the annual Toy Run in recent years it is regrettable that this year's charity event is under threat.</p><p>It should be remembered that the run provides not only toys but donations, food, goods and other items to the Salvation Army which distributes those donations throughout the entire state to the many needy and less fortunate in our community.</p><p>It is estimated that such donations have a monetary value above $20,000, all of which has been provided by participants in the run.</p><p>It is also clear that the run brings pleasure to the thousands of people who line the route from the Derwent Entertainment Centre to the waterfront, which in turn sets the scene for the forthcoming festive season.</p><p>I hope the funds are available for this worthwhile tradition to continue with the ultimate benefit to the less fortunate in our community.</p><p>Fabian B. Dixon</p><p>Liberal candidate for Denison</p><p>Hobart</p><p>Young hopefuls</p><p>Why do multinational companies keep employing young staff?</p><p>These multinational companies employ eager 15 to 16-year-olds, many in their last year at high school.</p><p>When first employed they enjoy quite a few hours each week.</p><p>Then it starts to dwindle to one shift (of three to five hours) a week, then one shift a fortnight.</p><p>By law they have to give them one shift every three weeks.</p><p>Why do the shifts start to dwindle? Because they have just employed another batch of young hopefuls.</p><p>You wonder why the kids start to get disheartened.</p><p>Jenny Elkin</p><p>Moonah</p><p>Imagine!</p><p>Did anyone notice that our sister Commonwealth country Canada appointed a new governor-general recently?</p><p>The new governor-general is a woman under 50 years of age. This is wonderful news for Canada.</p><p>But wait. She is also black. Now wait again. She is a migrant.</p><p>Can we try to imagine Australia with a female GG and then from say Iraq, Vietnam, the Sudan or even our own Aboriginal population. No I can't. Not while the likes of John Howard are voted in.</p><p>David Rowe</p><p>Battery Point</p><p>HOT TOPIC AVIAN FLU</p><p> I respond to the article (The Mercury, September 30), "Deadly flu plan call."</p><p>I note that the Federal Government has a stockpile of antiviral medication.</p><p>I would like it to be publicly known that this "is in reserve", not for the public necessarily but "essential services".</p><p>These include politicians, all defence force, fire, police and emergency aid services (ambulance, for example) and hospital administrators.</p><p>Interestingly, these essential services do not include medical staff of hospitals, nurses or the medical staff serving the general community -- GPs.</p><p>It's odd really, isn't it. Who's going to look after the sick people?</p><p>Maybe the politicians will be manning these infectious community centres?</p><p>Dr Jane Chapman</p><p>Bellerive</p><p> With the spread of deadly bird flu and concerns that it could mutate from birds to humans, isn't it time the Australian Government took a long, hard look at battery farms and broiler chickens?</p><p>All these birds are kept in overcrowded, filthy conditions which are an open invitation for viruses to spread like wildfire once they take hold.</p><p>Could avian flu become the next mad cow disease? Could the public pay the ultimate price due to producers putting profits above the welfare of customers?</p><p>During the 14th century humans lived in overcrowded, unhygienic slums which then became a breeding ground for plague which killed many thousands of people.</p><p>Are these conditions not being replaced now in battery farms and any place where battery and intensive farming is practised?</p><p>Factory farming is an environmental disaster waiting to happen.</p><p>Chickens in battery and broiler farms are providing the perfect environment for the spread of avian flu. Australia has around 10.5 million battery hens living in huge sheds which can hold up to 60,000 birds each.</p><p>To save space and pack in as many birds as possible the cages (holding up to five birds each) are stacked one on top of the other, often six to eight tiers high.</p><p>When the top birds poop, it falls through to the bottom cages where it hardens, pulverises and turns into dust which is then inhaled by the birds.</p><p>Most workers in the sheds wear masks but the birds are not protected at all. Litter is never changed during the birds' short, miserable lives, meaning that the stench, dirt and dust in the sheds is indescribable.</p><p>One infected bird could cause this whole tinderbox to ignite.</p><p>Disease would spread through the chickens with the same speed as a forest fire.</p><p>The Government should act now to close down these sheds, put people before profits and realise that the threat of avian flu is as great if not greater than that of terrorism to Australia and its people.</p><p>Elizabeth Hardy</p><p>Railton</p><p> Images of bird flu in Asian countries shown on our TVs depict affected birds living in profoundly cruel, miserable, cramped unhygienic conditions.</p><p>Our authorities seem to deliberately avoid making any criticism or reference to these practices, the reason for this being no doubt that almost all "farmed" birds in this country are kept in similar conditions.</p><p>Nature abhors such aberrations.</p><p>Pam Clarke</p><p>Kingston Beach</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P0W-WSF0-TXN5-V31V-00000-00Proud tradition questioned2003-04-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisNEWSLettersPg. 17Proud tradition questioned

IN the aftermath of the Dragons capitulation to Manly last Sunday, Mercury editor Mitchell Murphy wrote that coach Nathan Brown should be hauled over the coals and for club officials to remind him of the club's proud tradition.

One grand final choke followed by three years of under-achievement hardly constitutes a proud tradition. For proud tradition look no further than Redfern.

- PETER HEDGES,

Bulli.

Sex ideas a failure

IN response to the article titled "Sex earlier, more often, says survey" (Mercury, April 9).

Having "sexperts" advising our children on the prevention of pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) is like having arsonists in charge of the fire department!

Sex education has been going for about three decades and the evidence shows it is a total failure with more unplanned pregnancies, STDs and an increase in sterility as a result of the diseases.

So what is the agenda? Explicit, naturalistic, class-based sex education destroys God's holy laws on life, marriage and family, purity and faith, and undermines potential authority over our children.

This kind of explicit sex training stains our children's innocence and their sense of modesty, self-control and maturity, which can only lead to an even deeper social crisis than we are currently experiencing.

- ADRIAN DEVLIN,

Corrimal.

How to find peace

I FIND it amazing that with modern technology the way it is, the whole world can watch a war live on TV.

Radio reports continually update events as they happen and newspaper headlines daily present the allied progress and associated facts.

The Middle East is again the centre of world attention. Men, women and children are dying for the cause of peace and freedom. Or is that just a dream?

I wonder what the headlines would have said at Easter time 2000 years ago, when Jesus Christ the Prince of Peace was illegally tried and found guilty of blasphemy. The penalty was death by crucifixion.

In reality, his only "crime" was his love for a lost and helpless world heading for destruction. He came to be a substitute for all of mankind, and paid the penalty for our crimes against God and our fellow man.

After three days he rose from the dead, and now waits for all people everywhere to turn to him to find the peace and freedom they are looking for. Nothing in the world will ever have the power or authority to do that.

Peace, freedom, forgiveness and a future home in Heaven can only be received as a gift from God.

- FRAN FRAGAR,

Lansdowne.

Mature want work

RECENTLY I attended a workshop for the "mature unemployed seeking work".

This was an interesting experience and the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR) sent a representative to hear our concerns, which was all well and good, but whether the Government will do anything about seriously helping us - instead of making things more difficult - remains to be seen.

What really needs to be done is for employers to come forward and offer us a chance. There needs to be another forum for those of us who are in the higher range of 40-plus and prospective employers, where the employers are asked: why are you so hesitant in employing us? It's the employers who need to answer age discrimination or any other factors which stop them from hiring mature workers.

There are "job expos" for the young school leavers and there is a myriad of peer support for our youngsters, but it has come to light that there is not nearly adequate peer support for those of us who are older, wiser, more experienced, and facing this huge battle of searching for work. Just look around in the agencies and you will see what I am talking about.

We were told to look for part-time or casual work, but as everyone knows, it can be more disadvantageous when you are in receipt of benefits and even then, who is the preferred choice for part-time employment?

Would the Illawarra Business Chamber be interested in helping the 40-plus with a forum consisting of the unemployed and prospective employers? Or would this once again be fobbed off to the government departments? Why not have our local government do something like this for its constituents?

Take the results far up the ladder if it is a fruitful exercise and, who knows, it may be an example to other local government areas to follow.

Surely there must be a way to address this problem in the Illawarra and other areas?

It is easy to sit there and tell yourself that you are OK, since you have a job, but what if it were you having to search? I bet the attitude would change real quick.

- SONJA OUDHOFF,

West Wollongong.

Thank the soldiers

IT is the soldier, not the reporter, who has given us the freedom of peace.

It is the soldier, not the poet who has given us the freedom of speech.

It is the soldier, not the campus organiser, who has given us the freedom to demonstrate.

It is the soldier,

who salutes the flag,

who serves beneath the flag,

and whose coffin is draped by the flag,

who allows the protester to burn the flag.

- RB STORM,

Corrimal.

Grow right trees

NOT one person has given some thought for our wildlife, birds and animals that have had so much of their habitat wiped out by the bushfires and also by man.

Where the fires have destroyed so many of the old trees that were breeding grounds for so many species and the trees that have weathered the fires have had the sustenance knocked back, meaning that it will be quite a few years for them to recover.

Also some thought must be given to replacing some of the breeding grounds, by placing boxes on the trees, as a substitute for the loss of the old hollow trees.

The idea of greening Australia is right, but more thought should be given as to the type of trees that should be planted, trees that in time will benefit all. Trees that come into flower quickly and will in time produce natural breeding grounds for so many species again.

There are so many trees that fit that category; many types of gum and box. One that comes to mind is the great red gums that have just about disappeared from the coastal belt and from the top of the escarpment.

The planting of so many casuarina trees, better known to most as she-oaks, along the highways and as habitats is wrong, as they don't produce much in the way of sustenance.

When planting large growing trees, they should not be planted along the roads and highways or the built-up areas, as in time they become a hazard to property and life.

There also must be a lot of thought given to the planting of the coniferous type of trees, most of them are a must, as they give sustenance to quite a number of wildlife and breeding grounds.

Still care must be taken, as they become such a fire hazard if planted too thickly, as was the case in the suburbs of Canberra. Also it is important that in the future pine forests should be confined to the open spaces, well away from natural forests.

I know as I have fought bushfires and also had the experience of helping in the Penrose pine forest fire many years ago, a very frightening experience.

All I have written is so important and a lot so urgent, too, if we are to save many of our wildlife species.

-F R RUSE,

Kiama
