urn:contentItem:51XJ-3CY1-F031-X3MM-00000-00California Burning2009-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisForeign Correspondent5:32 PM AESTABCMichael BrissendenCalifornia Burning

Since fires raged over south eastern Australia late last year - most tragically destroying small bush townships near Melbourne - there have been questions, allegations and recriminations about preparedness, procedures and protocols.

A Royal Commission into the bushfires was established, and is still under way. When released, its full findings will reveal what lessons can be learnt from those extraordinary fires. Everything from improved warning mechanisms and communications to better building standards have been considered but perhaps the most controversial issue has been over whether residents should stay and defend their property or leave early and leave it to the fire fighters.

These same issues are hot topics around the world as countries from Spain to Greece and most recently America face similar mega fires. Everyone wants to know why these fires are becoming more ferocious and more frequent - and what we can do to stop them.

Recently, North America correspondent Michael Brissenden travelled to California to report from the fire frontline as wildfires raged around Los Angeles.

Here they've met mega fire with a mega response - hot shot crews, smoke jumpers, even 747s loaded with retardant. It's a $50 million dollar extravaganza - but it's $50 million dollars this cash strapped state doesn't have, despite the big talking ways of Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger.

Even with this arsenal of manpower and equipment the fires continued to burn unchecked for days and it's got people, even the fire fighters themselves asking if there is a better way. One solution would be for homeowners to take more individual responsibility. If people continue to build on the urban fringe there is a need for them to be better prepared.

The push is now on for safer and stricter building regulations to be implemented, and there is a great deal of discussion over the role the residents can play in defending their homes themselves.

"The situation about how we try to defend houses here is absurd. You know I could legally defend this place with an AK47 and a bazooka if I choose - but apparently not with a garden hose - I'll be evacuated." Stephen Pyne, Fire Historian

Until recently most American communities forced the evacuation of their residents in the face of fires - leaving the task of fire fighting to the professionals. Homeowners have been actively deterred from staying to defend their property. Now authorities are looking at aspects of the Australian policy of "stay and defend, or leave early" as one possible answer.

As the climate changes and urban encroachment continues, experts predict fire seasons are going to get hotter, more frequent and more devastating. We need to learn lessons from each other around the world to better adapt to these environmental challenges - and to learn how we can live with and control this natural threat.

Transcript

NEWS REPORT: The fire started near here where Air 7HD first spotted the fire at Five Acres.

FIRE CHIEF: Today what happened is what I call the perfect storm of fuels, weather and topography coming together.

WOMAN: [press conference] The Station fire was the result of an act of arson.

CIVILIAN WOMAN: It took a turn, it took a huge turn and it's time to go.

CIVILIAN MAN: It's not good [looking at burning hills behind him]. It's pretty scary, especially once it gets over the ridge.

ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER: [Press conference] You know we have a lot of fires all over the State of California - fires, fires, fires.

BRISSENDEN: Fighting fire in the hills and mountains around Hollywood is a big, almost cinematic operation, and like any big budget production, an army of cast and crew are up before dawn taking their direction.

It's a daunting logistical exercise. They're trying to outsmart and eventually conquer a wildly unpredictable and extremely dangerous enemy. This is no special effects monster, this is the real deal, what we call a bush fire and what's known here as a wildfire or a forest fire. And this wildfire, like so many these days in California, is big.

PATRICK TITUS: [Holding map] We've anchored flanks. We've anchored in over here in a good safe place and we're bringing this line around so we're pinching that fire down.

BRIAN SAVAGE: [Division Supervisor] For 12 years I've been on teams but I've been doing fires for 25 and you know this fire for instance was pretty dynamic, but 4,000 people assigned to a single fire in the United States, you don't see that very much. I've never seen a fire with 4,000 people assigned.

BRISSENDEN: So far this year California has had more than five thousand forest fires close to towns and cities. This one, called the Station Fire, has morphed into a mega fire. From fire fighters and law enforcement officers, to caterers and cleaning staff, nearly 500 engines, 14 helicopters, 64 bulldozers and fixed wing planes - including two DC 10's and for the first time a 747 capable of dropping 70 thousand litres of retardant in one go. When it's closing in on homes and lives, the response to a mega fire is equal force and here there won't be much change out of 50 million dollars.

Like much of southeast Australia, California has been in drought now for many years. The fire season here used to be three to four months. It's now an almost year round state of alert and many here are starting to believe that the change could be permanent. So the question is, should we stop trying to assume we can contain fire, and rather find better ways to deal with this new reality?

STEPHEN PYNE: Houses are still burning down. The place is flooded. We're spending tens of millions of dollars. We're flying Boeing 747's with retardant now in mountains. I mean this is how nutty this is getting. The fire guys don't have a choice. They're told you've got to take action. We need to show we're responding. That is simply a broken system. Well you know the situation about how we try to defend houses here is absurd. You know I could legally defend this place with an AK 47 and a bazooka if I chose, but apparently not with a garden hose, I'll be evacuated.

BRISSENDEN: In arid Arizona, far from the Station blaze, fire historian Stephen Pyne is sounding the alarm on America's fire-fighting strategy and the new peril of the suburban sprawl.

STEPHEN PYNE: I regard a lot of these as our sub-prime landscapes. This is the environmental flip side to Wall Street's conflagration. We shouldn't have built it on a lot of funny money and fraud going into it. There's no reason to build these things there and they're burning down just as the economy melted down.

BRISSENDEN: Stephen Pyne is one of the world's foremost authorities on the culture of fire. In California broadly, and Los Angeles specifically, unchecked development and bad fire management have collided with global warming and the result according to this expert, is very grim indeed.

STEPHEN PYNE: The whole literature of Los Angeles is about Los Angeles in apocalyptic meltdown. I'm not sure for fire there's a lot they can do. I don't think they can go back to the fundamentals and rebuild it.

BRISSENDEN: It's hard to know where the sprawl of Los Angeles ends. It certainly appears seamless all the way here to this neighbourhood, but this is Orange County, south of L.A.

This summer, Orange County fire officers have been visiting homeowners on site and giving their houses fire safety ratings. Many of them fall badly short. Many of the houses in this neighbourhood wouldn't last long if and probably when, a forest fire sweeps up out of the surrounding bushland. That's why the local strategy called 'Ready Set Go' is so important.

(CLIP FROM 'Ready Set Go' VIDEO)'Ready Set Go' is modelled on Australia's 'Stay and Defend or Leave Early Policy' and was adapted here by this man, Mike Ferdigh. Mike Ferdigh was working with Victorian Fire authorities when the Black Saturday infernos erupted and knows the Australian strategy has been heavily scrutinised ever since.

MIKE FERDIGH: [Emergency Planning Co-Ordinator] I think it can work real well. I talked to several people and there was one lady in Marysville.... I'm probably going to insult her, I'm going to guess she was in her 70's.... and her house survived. So if a house is defendable I think it can work.

BRISSENDEN: But the reality of mega fires, makes it more difficult.

MIKE FERDIGH: I think the hardest part which was obviously the same in Australia, and the same thing here, is how do you prepare a home owner when that fire comes.

BRISSENDEN: And how do you?

MIKE FERDIGH: I don't think we can. I've been doing this for 30 years and I'm still amazed. So how can you take someone that goes to work every day, does a great job at their daily job, has air conditioning in their house and sits in a fairly nice environment and put them in a smoky environment where they can't see a foot and they want to throw up because of the smoke, and it's hot - I don't think there's any way you really can prepare someone for that.

TAM SCHUMANN: [Local TV reporter, describing fire] It was very, very dark. It was pitch black and I thought two things, I thought this is what living in war must be like or what hell must be like.

ED SCHUMANN: Fireman and some neighbours kind of made a fire line and everybody was just passing these bottles of water.

BRISSENDEN: He's a senior attorney and she's a judge but when last year's so-called freeway fire stormed up to the Orange County home of Ed and Tam Schumann deciding to stay or go had them scratching their heads before it was almost too late.

ED SCHUMANN: We thought we were pretty safe and we have a really nice buffer zone between us and any open land and either the wind shifted or the fire just found more fuel in our direction and it started coming up back over the hills, back here behind us and we got everybody out and took off.

TAM SCHUMANN: And when we fled the streets on either side were already aflame. The flames were just high and shooting and it was pitch black and embers were falling through.

ED SCHUMANN: This is Tam's riding arena. Last year this would have all been completely cleared so there's nothing that would have burned on this whole hillside. So we felt safe you know? That should have been a really good buffer.

BRISSENDEN: Their experience demonstrates why 'Ready Set Go' is such a difficult call. They thought they were insulated against fire and now as the Station fire blazes well out of range and north of them, the Schumann's are still very uncomfortable.

TAM SCHUMANN: We were really surprised at our reaction. Post Traumatic Stress Syndrome really, really exists. Both Ed and I were shocked at our reaction to that, to seeing this new batch of fires.

ED SCHUMANN: Yeah it kind of makes you relive it again. You see the hillside burning and you kind of, you think God it can happen again.

PATRICK TITUS: [Battalion Chief] You know this is my 30-something years doing this. When I was younger, on the hand crews and the hotshots and stuff, a big fire was 15,000 acres and now it's so common that a fire is you know 100,000 plus acres. We had a fire in the Las Padres earlier that was 90 something thousand acres.... so you know it's not that those didn't happen when I was young but they were very, very rare. Now they've become very commonplace now.

BRISSENDEN: The Station fire was an act of arson that within a day tore through 25,000 acres and doubled in size every day for the first four days. It's become the largest wildfire in Los Angeles' County history. And that's before the deadly seasonal winds have arrived, the dry desert Santa Anna's.

BRIAN SAVAGE: [Division supervisor] If we had a Santa Anna wind condition set up and we have a current fire burning like we do, we're going to get pounded. That fire is going to spread. It will go to the foothills and we will be fighting a fire fifty miles away and trying to save homes where we can.

BRISSENDEN: The specialist crews in American fire fighting can sound like they've been named by a Hollywood producer. These are the hotshot crews and by day they're hard at it 'cutting line' forging defensive firebreaks along the ridgeline. It's tough, demanding work. With lumbering aircraft continuing to bomb the blaze, it can look like a war. In fact, the hotshot crews are modelled on small organised units from the World War II battlefield. And then there's the US fire fighting paratrooper, the smoke jumper.

JIM RAUDENBUSH: They started in about 1940 and it was just a way to get fire fighters to inaccessible fires and.... they decided to try parachuting, and that's when it got going. They've been around for almost sixty years now.

BRISSENDEN: These very specialised operators are based in Boise Idaho and from here they can be deployed at short notice anywhere across the country.

JIM RAUDENBUSH: We carry two days worth of food and water and if we need additional food and water we can be resupplied. You never know what you're doing from day to day. You can be sitting here in Boise one day and wake up in Alaska the next on a fire out in the middle of nowhere.

BRISSENDEN: Boise is fire-fighting central. At the national command centre enormous warehouses hold every piece of fire fighting kit imaginable. It can be rushed to fire crews as they call for it or as management at headquarters sees fit. At the Centre's coordinating bunker they can be dealing with dozens of fires across the country at any one time.

It's a supply and coordination centre but it's also gathering data and developing a clearer picture of the fire threat in the United States. From his national vantage point here, Rick Ochoa, one of the country's leading fire related weather specialists, is seeing a tinderbox getting drier.

RICK OCHOA: [Weather analyst] You know we have much drier fuels, much hotter temperatures and so on. So the weather and the climate and the fuels and fire is changing. Our jobs are also becoming more challenging in the fact that we have to look at more and more areas and events that in the past you know we had some wind, we had some humidity, we didn't think we'd see that much fire potential or fire behaviour, we're seeing a lot more of it now because the fuels are so much different.

BRISSENDEN: From computer screens in Idaho to fire fronts in California, the picture is the same. Global warming is proving to be an alarming accelerant.

RICK OCHOA: I think it's a permanent change. I think this is here to stay. We're seeing here in the States and Australia, longer fire seasons, hotter fire seasons, it's just because we're dealing with a much warmer globe.

MIKE FERDIGH: I believe you're in a twelve year drought, we're in a four/five year drought so we're just starting the same path that you guys are maybe ten years ahead of us. So if the drought conditions, if you wanted to throw in global warming, what that's doing to the environment and the drought conditions we have here presently in Southern California, it has the potential to be another bad fire season.

NEWS REPORT: Arnold Schwarzenegger served the breakfast to fire-fighters today at the Lake View Terrace Command Post. He assured them that state money would be there to fight the fires. He told me there's enough in reserve to keep the money flowing to fire-fighters.

ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER: Public safety is the number one priority so yes you have to be frugal, yes you have to look at every dollar but we will have the dollars available to fight these fires and we will go all out.

BRISSENDEN: The Californian economy was in freefall before the global financial crisis made things even worse. An increasingly demanding fire season, more and more mega fires, has a huge financial dimension and fire historian Stephen Pyne wonders if the state can in fact deal with its fiery future.

STEPHEN PYNE: That cycle, spending more money, evacuating more people.... this can't continue. This is just insane and it doesn't solve the problem. The problem comes as with our financial system by taking a systemic view and reorganising it. We've made this mess and it's a big deep mess. It's going to take a long time to disentangle it, but we can begin. There are a number of things, we'll start small, we'll begin putting it together again.

BRISSENDEN: Some of those small changes are being implemented in the big houses along San Diego's ridge tops. They're a long way from the subprime fuelled suburban expansion on the LA fringe but the fire danger here is just as alarming. Nearly 10,000 homes have been lost to wildfires here in the past 40 years.

CLIFF HUNTER: [Fire marshal] Our preferred method is to evacuate and evacuate early but there may be some time constraints depending on the fire and the wind conditions which stop you from doing that. It's very difficult once it gets to a certain point from a safety perspective, to get in and try to fight it.

We're in a community called the Cielo and it's a sheltered place community. It's one of six in the Rancho Santa Fe fire protection district and our goal is that if you live in a sheltered place community, you would not have to evacuate if a wild land fire came through. That means if a fire were to come through the community, you would be safer to stay in your home, close your windows, close your doors and try not to evacuate.

BRISSENDEN: The houses here have all been designed to conform to the local Rancho Santa Fe Fire Protection code. It's a much stricter regulatory environment and certainly more expensive than elsewhere in California, but the man behind it all, local Fire Chief Cliff Hunter says the lessons learnt here can be used more widely.

CLIFF HUNTER: You can do this in a regular home owner situation. You can still look at the vents, you can still look at the roofs..... we can still look at landscaping and we would hopefully look at the infrastructure, which are the roadways and water supply and telephone and power and all those things. So yes I believe it is 100% achievable in another community.

BRISSENDEN: All over California regulators are slowly getting tough and homeowners are getting the message that if they want to live with nature, they must adapt.

ED SCHUMANN: This is what's left. We sorted through the last of this today and found what we could.

BRISSENDEN: Tam and Ed Schumann learnt the hard way. Their home was not fire safe. For them the cost of complying with tougher building regulations isn't even an issue if it means their new home will survive another fire.

TAM SCHUMANN: I was not going to let this fire get me down. I was going to.... it was almost like I was going to shake my fist and say, I am not getting driven out by this. I'm going to rebuild and my life is going to go on.

ED SCHUMANN: We've had to compromise and make some changes but we are building the house we want. The city has changed a lot of the fire codes with the way things are rebuilt..... so personally I think we're pretty safe.

BRISSENDEN: How do you think you will feel when you move back to the new house when it's built? What are you going to do, anything special?

TAM SCHUMANN: Throw a huge party.

ED SCHUMANN: And don't call it a house warming. We've had the house warming party, now we're going to have the house cooling party.

BRISSENDEN: When the smoke clears from this fire, as happened in Australia after Victoria's Black Saturday tragedy, questions will be asked about building safer homes, about homeowner's responsibility and about the fire fighting efforts as well.

PATRICK TITUS: My crystal ball's worn out. I don't know. I don't know but things have changed and I think the fire service, not just in California but nationwide in the United States, I think we're changing with it a little bit. I think our leadership and a lot of leadership are really coming to terms with what a whole different way of thinking about how we approach the fires.

BRISSENDEN: Controlling fire, living with it and adapting to a rapidly changing fire environment has become one of the big challenges of our time and it seems we all still have a lot to learn.

STEPHAN PYNE: There's a big disconnect and fire is being separated from the way we manage the land. We've forgotten what has been such a brilliant defining characteristic for us. I mean that's what we do. We're the fire creatures. You know other animals knock over trees and dig holes in the ground.... we do fire - and that has always been our unique signature.

FOR a successful country act, Fred Eaglesmith is a little left and a lot lower

than centre.

But some of Australia's leading country

performers, Kasey Chambers among them, doff their hats to the hard-edged

Canadian honky-tonk artist.

Weekender ensnared Eaglesmith as he arrived at Sydney's Mascot for his second

Australian tour in two years.

He had no trouble getting through customs. Well, not this time.

'It was easy,' he grins.

'But now they check every single bag coming into Australia. You don't even

have a chance ... they've lost all their sense of adventure.'

Travelling light and alone, all customs found in his luggage was a guitar,

three pairs of pants and four shirts.

But the singer-guitarist and his unlikely looking band, who crisscross North

America in a convoy of beat-up buses and tour vehicles, have a knack for

attracting the unfounded attention of authorities.

They have been handcuffed by border guards and pulled over by police in the

middle of the night in the middle of nowhere.

Devoted fans - 'Fredheads' - joke about their penchant for rough-and-tumble

roadhouses,

saying there should be chicken-wire in front of the stage to protect them (to

protect the band or the patrons, Weekender is unsure).

'I've just bought a fifth bus - we keep wearing them out,' Eaglesmith says.

'We did 300 gigs last year and we're going to do about 250 this year.

'We just did a cruise, can you believe that? There wasn't any chicken-wire,

that's for sure, but the passengers all ate so much that they couldn't even

move anyway.'

Eaglesmith was going straight to Tamworth for the Australian Country Music

Festival, where a Canadian TV crew is shooting a documentary on his hillbilly

life and music.

Well, maybe 'straight' isn't the right word.

'I like Tamworth and I have fun there but I'm not exactly a straight country

music guy,' Eaglesmith explains.

'It's all a little to the right from where I'm

coming from but I think I can hold my own. Somebody needs to hold down the left

and that's me.

'When everything else fails, people head to the left. They all go right to

get the money then they go left to have a career.'

Eaglesmith credits Kasey Chambers with

introducing his music to Australian audiences after recording a version of his

song Freight Train on her 1999 chart-busting album The Captain.

'Fred has an amazing way of making you laugh and cry in the same song,'

Chambers says.

'He tears my heart out but always in a good way.'

Fellow Central Coast singer Audrey Auld, who now distributes Eaglesmith

albums Down Under through her label Reckless Records, followed with a dose of

his Alcohol and Pills on her 2000 album The Fallen.

She does a duet on B-Grade Affair with the deep-voiced Canadian on her new

album, Losing Faith, while her former partner, Kasey's father Bill Chambers,

covers Big Ass Garage Sale* on his latest LP, Sleeping With The Blues.

Novocastrian starlet Catherine Britt booked a ticket to Eaglesmith's Drive-In

Movie on her 2001 debut Dusty Smiles and Heartbreak Cures.

'I think Kasey found my songs through a publisher and passed them on to

Audrey,' Eaglesmith says.

'I finally met them and we've become pretty good friends. I also got to know

Catherine a little bit last year.'

Eaglesmith has a three-fold mission during his week-long Australian jaunt.

His main plan is to enjoy himself, his second is to play a few gigs (on his

lonesome and as part of a Canadian showcase) and his third is to push his 11th

album Falling Stars and Broken Hearts.

He will perform at Hamilton's (Newcastle) Northern Star Hotel on January 29,

with support from Auld, and with Canadian Country On Show at Newcastle's Wests

Leagues Club on January 30.

The 45-year-old says he's been happy 'for a long time' but you wouldn't know

it from his music. His humour is more wry than jovial and many of his songs are

about drinking, preaching, cars, 'real people' (usually in blue collars or

overalls), trains, being short of a quid and/or romance on the skids.

'Money doesn't make you happy,' he says.

'I've had a really normal career ... I'm not too famous but I'm having a good

life. I think most of the guys who make the money aren't too happy.

'I like to write about real people because they're the people I like.

'Even when I talk to the top-feeders who pretend they don't live like us,

they're always fascinated by my lifestyle and what I do. That makes me think,

because I'm never fascinated by theirs.'

The Country On Show concert series, also featuring The Wilkinsons, Michelle

Wright and Jason McCoy, is supported financially by the Canadian Government

through its Music Fund - not that Eaglesmith is overly fussed.

'The Government likes more of that right country than they do me,' he says.

'... they didn't pay for my air tickets. They didn't pay for anything as far as

I know. If they did, I didn't see any of it.

'I don't live on government grants ... I have my own career and I pay my own

way.'

Eaglesmith grew up working farms and hopping freight trains in southern

Ontario. His father, a 'very religious man' who went bankrupt twice, took the

family to Christian Reformed church

services five times a week.

'I like to put preachers in my songs because I was raised with preachers,' he

says. 'I went to church twice on Sunday and three times during the week plus I

went to (a Christian) school. I should be saved by rote.'

To corrupt a line from Hank Williams, Eaglesmith saw a different light about

a decade ago and become a Buddhist.

'I'm a lousy Buddhist but I'm a Buddhist.'

Eaglesmith believes 'true riches' rest in personal fulfilment rather than

material possessions.

'The poorest people usually have the most answers,' he says.

Plenty of punters tell Eaglesmith that they have found deep meaning in his

'alternative country' music. Some even refer to his live performances as

'getting religion'.

'I'm always astonished when people say that they revere you or one of your

songs,' he says.

'I look at the lyrics and it's a song about how I like trains or something.

'There's no new-age revelations. But, hey, some people find their answers

with the Backstreet Boys, although that could just be childhood

infatuation.'

Eaglesmith will play tonight and tomorrow in the Blazes auditorium at

Tamworth's Wests Leagues Club. The name of the room should make him feel at

home because he has spent time as a volunteer fire-fighter in his native

Canada.

'I remember fighting a forest fire once and these bigwigs came in from the

Ministry of Natural Resources to have dinner with us,' Eaglesmith says.

'I was talking to this other guy about hopping freight trains ... We were

arguing over whether the doors of box cars should be opened or closed.

'I remember these bigwigs, who were probably making $250,000 a year, looking

at us with these huge eyes as if to say Can you believe this

conversation?".'

The doors, by the way, should be left open no matter how nasty the weather.

'Otherwise,' he explains. 'You're gonna die young because they'll lock 'em

and you'll be stuck inside.'

* The 'garage' in Big Ass Garage Sale is pronounced monosyllabically, as if

spelt 'grrrage'. ('But I thought everybody knew that already,' Eaglesmith

laughs.)

urn:contentItem:4FX8-G4M0-0045-5234-00000-00<published>2005-04-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>A;</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Missing lynx on extinction brink THE ENVIRONMENT</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>The Canberra Times</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">HE WORLD'S most endangered big cat doesn't live in Africa, the Amazon or the Himalayas. It is barely surviving in a few isolated populations in southern Spain and Portugal and unless numbers can be boosted and habitat destruction halted, it could become extinct within the next five years. If this happens, the Iberian lynx will be the first big cat to become extinct since the sabre-toothed tiger died out around 10,000 years ago. The plight -and some wildlife biologists would add, the neglect -of one of the world's oldest wild cat species has become Europe's most controversial conservation issue. Wildlife biologists say the lynx is "in an extinction vortex". It is the first cat to be classified as being in "critical danger of extinction", with only two surviving wild breeding populations. There are 8000 surviving tigers in the wild and 10,000 cheetahs, but there are only about 100 wild lynx left in Spain and Portugal. Early last century, there were 100,000 Iberian lynx, and their range extended through Spain and Portugal, into southern France. But although they posed no threat to humans or livestock, hundreds were killed in government-sanctioned "vermin drives". They were also shot by boar and deer hunters. By 1960, there were only 3000 left, and by 1988, numbers had crashed to 1200. In 2001, there were 300 lynx left in the wild, but numbers have plummeted further. Scientists are worried that disease, a diminishing gene pool and a natural disaster such as a forest fire could wipe out remaining populations.</p><p>"It is the most threatened cat species on the planet," Dr Luis Castro, a wildlife biologist with Portugal's Institute for the Conservation of Nature, said in a recent interview. "The decline of the lynx has been a problem for many decades. Currently we are in an emergency situation and the problem is that, for the species to survive, it needs large areas, positive action and political and technical motivation." Dr Caroline Lucas, a Green Party member of the European Parliament, has called for the European Union to take a more active role in halting the lynx's rapid demise. "The European Union's contribution to lynx conservation to date is dwarfed by the subsidies which have been given to forestry and intensive agriculture projects, that have turned natural ecosystems into virtual deserts and native vegetation into exotic plantations," she said, in a recent report on the status of the Iberian lynx. "The EU has to accept its responsibility, duty and potential to address the current situation, and recognise that it is an emergency, not just for the lynx, but also for the reputation of the EU's environment and conservation policies." Wildlife biologists were first alerted to the plight of the Iberian lynx after the IUCN (World Conservation Union) Cat Specialist Group published a global survey of wild cat species. Sobering results had been anticipated for several species -tigers, cheetahs and snow leopards -but the results for the Iberian lynx were unexpected and profoundly shocking. Only a few hundred animals remained, scattered over 50 small, isolated populations. "Eight years later, what has changed? The answer is not the one you might expect," writes Eduardo Goncalves, a Portuguese journalist who is also president of SOS Lynx, a non-profit conservation group dedicated to saving the Iberian lynx. "The situation has got worse. Much worse. Of the 48 breeding populations in Spain that had earlier been found clinging grimly to survival, only two remain. "Of the five found in Portugal, none remained." For the lynx, it has been a "death of a thousand cuts" -habitat loss for agriculture, forestry and holiday homes; loss of its main food source; loss of breeding sites; road kill as bigger roads and faster traffic encroach on its habitat; tuberculosis from contact with domestic cattle and illegal hunting. Lynx habitat has been cleared for pine and eucalypt plantations, which lack an under-storey to support rabbit populations -the lynx's main prey. The loss of cork forests, which are being replaced by intensive strawberry agriculture, has also taken a heavy toll on lynx numbers. Cork forests are used by female lynxes to rear their young. Recent studies showed the majority of den sites were found at the base of old, hollow cork oak trees. The kittens stay in the natal den for the first 20 days, with the mother subsequently moving them to as many as 12 other den sites as a protection against predators. The trend toward plastic champagne corks and screw-tops for wine has led farmers to cut down cork plantations as demand for wine corks declines. Cork forests have been a major industry for southern and central Spain, producing 15 billion corks annually from sustainably harvested tree bark. But hunting remains the main cause of high mortality rates, despite the lynx being declared a protected species in both Spain and Portugal in the mid-1970s. Deaths from hunting and game-keeping activities accounted for more than 50 per cent of all lynx deaths in Spain's Donana national park in the 1980s. "The majority of lynx territories remain unprotected," writes Goncalves. "Hundreds, perhaps thousands, of kilometres of highways are being built in the heart of lynx country. By contrast, the total amount spent on lynx conservation to date would barely be enough for 1km of new road. "Whilst European leaders lecture so-called Third World politicians on the need to preserve the habitats of tigers, elephants and black rhinos, one of the world's oldest feline species is being allowed to die out on our own doorstep." But Australian science has unwittingly played a role in the lynx's demise. Its diet chiefly consists of wild rabbits (other prey includes ducks and partridge) and, when rabbit numbers are low, the survival and breeding rates of the lynx show a corresponding decline. "In the 1950s, a French doctor lost patience with rabbits that had been attacking his vegetable garden, and imported from Australia a disease called myxomatosis with catastrophic results," wrote Goncalves in a column for The Ecologist magazine. "Entire rabbit populations were wiped out and many lynxes starved or failed to reproduce. Then, a few decades later, just as rabbit populations began to develop immunity, disaster struck again. "A new virus virtually eradicated rabbits from the Iberian Peninsula in the late 1980s and early 1990s. Today, rabbit populations are thought to number just 5 per cent of 1960s levels. "There can be few more shocking spectacles than that of a starving, emaciated lynx barely able to walk." European governments and conservation authorities have been slow to respond to the plight of the lynx. A recent report, commissioned by Lucas, on "the Iberian Lynx emergency" says "the lynx conservation effort has developed late and slowly, is still new and not very extensive and has yet to demonstrate a significant impact on the lynx". The report has called for rabbit vaccines, a revision of land use and habitat protection, more financial incentives for nature protection on private land and a new political commission to focus on lynx conservation. The recent birth of three Iberian lynx kittens at a special breeding program at Donana national park in southern Spain has raised hopes that the species can be saved. Last century, the French writer Colette once found an exhausted young lynx cowering in her garden in rural southern France. The animal was on the run from a nearby hunting party, and Colette -always a formidable woman -stalked out to confront them. Recalling the incident when writing about the treatment of wild animals in later years, she angrily asked: "Can we not leave these creatures, dispossessed of everything else, at least one refuge?" urn:contentItem:457Y-8JH0-0197-50GG-00000-00<published>1996-03-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>GLEN BAXTER</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>JOANNA MENDELSSOHN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FOR an Englishman, Glen Baxter certainly has the measure of Australian political life. One of his drawings on view at Michael Nagy shows two men climbing up lampshades. The caption, which is presented upside down, reads: "Life in Canberra carried on as usual." Too true.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> There are other Australian allusions in this exhibition. A man with a televisionset head and wearing a safari suit is captioned: "I well remember the arrival of the first portable television set in Brisbane," while a drawing of a woman bashing some flattish object on an anvil is labelled: "It was not too long before Mrs Trundle's omelette became the talk of the Hunter Valley."  Before the population of Queensland and rural NSW lodges formal complaints about regional vilification by visiting Poms, it should be pointed out that these works are part of a long tradition of Baxter giving real place names to absurd images.</p><p>Baxter has made several visits to Australia since he first came out for the 1992 Adelaide Festival, and there is a cult following for his work here. It is therefore a compliment to be included in his personal geography.</p><p> His mock autobiography, Glen Baxter his life: the years of struggle, manages to produce the most absurd jokes about Yorkshire and Englishness since Monty Python. One of the many pleasures of Baxter's art is that he translates the sensibility of Pythonesque humour into works of art that are worth more than one quick look.</p><p> His manipulated images pay a gentle tribute to the archaic tradition of English juvenile pulp fiction as he appropriates the drawing style of that utterly strange culture of midnight feasts, boy scout camps, Fifth Form at St Dominic's and Deeds that Won the Empire. There are twisted narratives of noble heroes who overcome bullies, win cricket matches, shoot the enemy and generally behave with the utmost propriety despite all odds.</p><p> The illustrations to these one-dimensional stories are likewise simplified and repetitive, the hero figures being almost interchangeable. What Baxter has done to both the narrative and the illustrations is add an extra dimension, a twist of bile and whimsy. Nevertheless, these are affectionate images of a world that lacks any purpose except a belief in itself.</p><p> One of his running gags is the awfulness of school days and adolescence: "I was beginning to realise the other boys and I were just not getting along" shows a passive schoolboy being torched by two others. "It looked like being another long, hot, awkward summer", combines both the stilted imagery of the schoolboy illustration genre with a fun, horror-story fantasy as one man sprouts a fox's tail.</p><p> My small children are currently addicted to R. L. Stine's Goosebumps stories, where adolescent boys discover their true selves as werewolves, so perhaps animal transformations are a part of a universal juvenile fantasy.</p><p> One of the reasons for the success of his work is the whole unreality of the culture he appropriates. The archaic children's fiction on which he relies is based on a world of boarding schools that was never a mainstream experience, although its values dominated popular illustrated magazines aimed at children.</p><p> It was as much a fantasy land as the same comics based on adventures in the colonies or the wild west. So Baxter mixes familiar geographic names with his unreal images, and absurd visual images are placed next to banal captions.</p><p> He uses the same deadpan drawing style as his beloved source materials in creating his drawings and prints. The figures stand or sit in standard poses and make stilted gestures as to form static tableaux. Then Baxter carefully mimics the crudities of cheap, coloured printing processes in his carefully planned draw ings. The total effect is to give them a sense of belonging in a time past. It is a world of total nostalgia for a past that could have been, a bit like the ever popular Tintin comics, which also have boys in knickerbockers, a self-conscious archaic landscape and men with guns.</p><p> "The news from Sydney is not good" a consignment of new Baxter drawings has just arrived!</p><p>Roared Brenda illustrates three white hunters by their tent.</p><p>The same figures could be rearranged into other narratives, they are all so gloriously stereotypical. Sexual identity is another of Baxter's jokes and Brenda has been a recurring character since the early 1980s.</p><p> Another recurring favourite is the small boy quietly arranging the destruction of a relative as he cooks with concrete and iron filings. It is an image of infantile experimentation, lifted out of the banal by its deadpan caption: "I was determined to ensure that Uncle Frank's birthday cake would not be forgotten in a hurry." This is the same boy character who appears in Baxter's earlier work. Systematically poisoning plants, and using a saw and trestle to cut his mother's homemade bread.</p><p> Then there is sex. One of the funniest prints shows a tree with an extended arm, and just past it a hiker wearing a blissful expression: "As a first sexual experience it had not been a total disappointment." How to have sex is a strangely empty yellow drawing with a ladder, an anteater and legs. It is most instructive.</p><p> IN BRIEF: American Colour, photographs by Constantine Manos at Byron Mapp give the strident reds and pinks and blues of a trashy glitzy society. This is a vision of the strange juxtapositions of everyday life - of a woman contemptuously flashing her breasts to counter the asceticism of chanting Hare Krishnas, or the ravages of a forest fire behind a wiredoff swimming pool.</p><p> When the camera lingers on flesh in this world it is to look at absurdities, not beauty. Even the shot of young girls in bikinis on a summer's day is made to look harsh and banal, and beauty queens yawn on their float as they wait for the big parade.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4D7S-R230-015G-Y4V2-00000-00<published>2004-09-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>BODY AND SOUL; Pg. 106</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Wide world of WACKY-SAURS!</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">HAVING recently taken a tour of the Chinese Dinosaurs exhibit at the Queensland Museum (check out today's Social Factor!), we are in a really, really big dino-mood.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Rooooaaaaarrrrrr!</p><p nitf:lede="true">Hey, did you know that the word "dinosaur" (meaning "fearfully great lizard") was coined in 1842 by a guy called Sir Richard Owen?</p><p nitf:lede="true">Interesting!</p><p nitf:lede="true">Now, while we are fans of the T-rex and other dino-favourites, we are even bigger fans of dinosaurs with wacky names.</p><p>That's right.You see, newly discovered dinosaurs are named by the discoverer or palaeontologist - and sometimes the discoverer or palaeontologist gives "their dinosaur" a fully wacky name! Cool, eh?</p><p>So, what would you name your dinosaur if you discovered one? Hmm, we reckon "Factorxosaurus" has a nice ring to it, what do you think?</p><p>Check out these wackybutreal dinosaur names!</p><p>BAMBIRAPTOR</p><p>"Bambi" hardly sounds scary, but "raptor" sounds very scary.</p><p>So, was the Bambiraptor (also known as Bambi) scary or not? You decide: the Bambiraptor was a small, fast, meat-eating dinosaur with a deadly, sickle-shaped toe claw on the second toe of its foot.</p><p>(Oooh, we say scary!) The Bambiraptor lived in the late Cretaceous period (about 75 million years ago) and was named in 2000.</p><p>AFROVENATOR</p><p>Was this dinosaur named after Guy Sebastian or Jimi Hendrix? No, but you'd be forgiven for thinking so! Afrovenator actually means "African Hunter".</p><p>The Afrovenator was a 9m-long, meat-eating, three-fingered, stiff-tailed predator from Africa during the Cretaceous period (about 130 million years ago).</p><p>It was found in 1993 and named in 1994.</p><p>QANTASSAURUS</p><p>Qantassaurus sounds like it was named for the Australian airline, Qantas, right? Yep, and that's exactly what happened after the airline helped transport the precious fossil after finding it in Victoria.</p><p>This plant-eater was the size of a small kangaroo and had large eyes and a long tail.</p><p>It dates from about 110 million years ago, during the Cretaceous period, and was named in 1997.</p><p>GIRAFFATITAN</p><p>It sounds more like a giant giraffe than a dinosaur, doesn't it? Well, that's actually not such a bad description.The Giraffatitan was a huge, 30m-long, lightly-built, long-necked, whip-tailed, plant-eating dinosaur from the late Jurassic period (about 150 million years ago).</p><p>It was a brachiosaurid sauropod from Tanzania in Africa.</p><p>Giraffatitan means "gigantic giraffe" and was named in 1988.</p><p>STRUTHIOSAURUS</p><p>Nope, the Struthiosaurus was not named after the first word uttered by an Aussie fossilfinder.</p><p>Not even close!</p><p>Struthiosaurus actually means "ostrich lizard".The Struthiosaurus was a small, 2m long, armoured, plant-eating dinosaur.</p><p>It lived during the very late Cretaceous period (about 65 million years ago) and was named back in 1870.</p><p>JURASSOSAURUS</p><p>The full name of this dinosaur is Jurassosaurus nedegoapeferima.</p><p>Jurassosaurus means "Jurassic lizard"; nedegoapeferima is fragments of the names of cast members of the movie Jurassic Park, Sam NEill, Laura DErn, Jeff GOldblum, Richard Attenborough, Bob PEck, Martin FErrero, Ariana RIchards and Joseph MAzzello.</p><p>Steven Spielberg, the director of the movie, donated money for Chinese dinosaur research, so he was allowed to suggest its name.</p><p>The Jurassosaurus was an armoured, plant-eating dinosaur that was about 3m long.Not surprisingly, it lived during the mid Jurassic period (about 175 million years ago).</p><p>ELVISAURUS</p><p>Could this dinosaur have anything to do with rock legend Elvis Presley? Yes, actually!</p><p>The Elvisaurus, which means "Elvis (Presley) lizard", was named as such due to its crest's likeness to Elvis Presley's hairdo. How funny!</p><p>The Elvisaurus was a meat-eating dinosaur about 6m long and had a horn-like, upward pointing, Elvis-style crest above its eyes.The Elvisaurus lived in what is now Antarctica during the early Jurassic period (about 190 million years ago).</p><p>DELTASAURUS</p><p>No, this dinosaur wasn't named after Australia's popular piano-playing songstress Delta Goodrem, but Deltasaurus fossils have been found in Australia. Deltasaurus actually means "river delta lizard" and was named in 1965.This carnivore had very good hearing in the air, (but we doubt it could play the piano!)</p><p>Why did dinosaurs eat raw meat?</p><p>Because they didn't know how to cook!</p><p>What do you get when two dinosaurs crash their cars?</p><p>Tyrannosaurus wrecks!</p><p>What do you call a fossil that doesn't ever want to work?</p><p>Lazy bones!</p><p>What do you call a dinosaur with no eyes?</p><p>Doyathinkysaurus!</p><p>What do you call a dinosaur that never gives up?</p><p>Try-Try-Try-ceratops!</p><p>NQWEBASAURUS</p><p>Oh my goodness, what on earth were the palaeontologists thinking when they named the Nqwebasaurus (pronounced n-KWE-bah-SAWR-us) in 2000?! It's quite a mouthful to pronounce, isn't it!</p><p>The Nqwebasaurus is actually the first dinosaurwith a click sound in its name. To correctly pronounce Nqwebasaurus, pull your tongue off the roof of your mouth to produce a click on the "q".</p><p>Nqwebasaurus means "Nqweba lizard".</p><p>(Nqweba is an African language similar to Zulu.)</p><p>TECHNOSAURUS</p><p>Perhaps the Technosaurus would have preferred to live in today's technologically-advanced society.</p><p>Perhaps not! Either way, the Technosaurus was a small, plant-eating dinosaur that was about 1.2m long and weighed about 11kg. Pretty small, eh? It lived during the late Triassic period (about 230 million years ago) and was named in 1984.</p><p>PAWPAWSAURUS</p><p>Pawpawsaurus doesn't quite sound as menacing as Tyrannosaurus Rex, does it? Nevertheless, the Pawpawsaurus (which means "paw-paw formation lizard") was a pretty tough character.</p><p>It had bony eyelids and armour over most of its body.</p><p>The Pawpawsaurus was pretty similar to the Ankylosaurus, actually, except it didn't have one of those cool clubs at the end of its tail. The Pawpawsaurus lived from the mid Cretaceous period (about 97 million years ago) and was named in 1996.</p><p>SUPERSAURUS</p><p>Could the Supersaurus be the dinosaur version of Superman? Who knows! What we do know is that the Supersaurus was one ofthe longest dinosaurs, at around 42m in length (that's about four buses long!).</p><p>This sauropod was a Jurassic long-necked, long-tailed plant-eater with a small head.</p><p>OZRAPTOR</p><p>Could the Ozraptor have been a fierce Aussie dinosaur? Pretty much, yeah! The Ozraptor (which means "Australian plunderer") was a 3m-long, meat-eater from the mid Jurassic period (about 175 million years ago).</p><p>It was an advanced dinosaur that had threefingered hands, long legs and a stiff tail.The Ozraptor wasnamed in 1998 and is known from a part of a tibia (shin bone) found right here in Australia.</p><p>DISCOSAURISCUS</p><p>A groovy disco-dancing dino? Hmm, perhaps! The Discosauriscus walked on four short, sprawling legs, had a long tail and hadsharp teeth in wide jaws.</p><p>It lived during the early Permian period (almost 300 million years ago) and was named in 1876.</p><p>Hundreds of Discosauriscus fossils have been found in Central and Western Europe.</p><p>PYRORAPTOR</p><p>Hmm, could this be a fierce dinosaur that loved to start fires?</p><p>No, but Pyroraptor does mean "fire thief " - it was given this name because it was found (in France) after a forest fire.</p><p>The Pyroraptor was a meat-eating dinosaur that lived during the late Cretaceous period (about 80 million years ago) and was namedin 2000.</p><p>GARGOYLEOSAURUS</p><p>Well, judging by its name, the Gargoyleosaurus must have been an ugly and mean-looking dinosaur.Yep, Gargoyleosaurus means "gargoyle lizard" and was named as such because its wide, triangular skull resembles that of a gargoyle. It was a short, armoured plant-eater that lived during the late Jurassic period (about 150 million years ago). The Gargoyleosaurus was named in 1998.</p><p>What does a Triceratops sit on?</p><p>Its Tricera-bottom!</p><p>Mark: I wish I had enough money to buy a dinosaur.</p><p>John: What would you do with a dinosaur?</p><p>Mark: Who wants a dinosaur? I just want the money!</p><p>Why are there old dinosaur bones in the museum?</p><p>Because they can't afford new ones!</p><p>Why did the Archaeopteryx catch the worm?</p><p>Because it was an early bird!</p><p>When can three giant dinosaurs get under an umbrella and not get wet?</p><p>When it's not raining!</p><p>Information courtesy of <url normalizedValue="http://www.enchantedlearning.com/subjects/dinosaurs/">www.enchantedlearning.com/subjects/dinosaurs/</url></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P7G-YKD0-TXN5-R3C0-00000-00REGULAR SHORTS1987-06-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESBriefsPg. 15REGULAR SHORTS

VICARS TAKE WING AND A PRAYER

LONDON, Wednesday: Britain is about to launch the ecclesiastical equivalent of Australia's flying doctors. Thomson Hoidays has put together a team of flying vicars to minister to the spiritual needs of senior holidaymakers escaping the English cold at Mediterranean resorts next winter. Nine retired Anglican vicars are expected at three resorts, between October and April. - AAP

WHILE A NEW FIRE SPREADS

BEIJING, Wednesday: Two fires in virgin forests in northern China's Inner Mongolia have been brought under control, but a third was still spreading, the Xinhua News Agency reported today. The blazes were near the site of the massive fire which recently claimed 193 lives. - AP

PRINCESS 'A DOG' ROW

LONDON, Wednesday: A radio sports journalist was suspended today for saying on the radio that the Princess of Wales was "a bit of a dog". The switchboard at Beacon Radio, a commercial station based in Wolverhampton, was immediately flooded with calls from complaining listeners. The station's sports editor, Pat Foley, also said that the Princess was "a bit rough". Later he described the Duchess of York as being "frumpy and overweight". Foley made his comments while presenting a sports bulletin after a disc jockey had referred to a story about the Princess sitting on the bonnet of Prince Charles's Aston Martin. - PA

STRIKE ENDS IN PANAMA

PANAMA CITY, Wednesday: Business and opposition leaders in Panama have ended a nationwide strike and urged the Government, in return, to lift a six-day-old state of emergency. The strike was called last Wednesday as part of a protest movement aimed at ousting Panama's military chief and de facto ruler, General Manuel Antonio Noriega. - Reuter

PNG POLITICIAN CHARGED

PORT MORESBY, Wednesday: A prominent Member of the Papua New Guinea Parliament has been charged with conspiracy to murder a man standing against him at the polls. The Member for Bulolo, Mr Mathew Bendumb, is alleged to have arranged for his opponent to die in a traffic accident. The alleged victim was not on board, but two people were injured. Mr Bendumb was charged last week and bailed to appear in Wau court tomorrow. - AAP

HOPE FOR PEACE TALKS

MANILA, Wednesday: The Chief Government negotiator, Mr Emmanuel Pelaez, said peace talks with the Rebel Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF)collapsed last month but both sides had maintained informal contacts and officials were hopeful Manila could prevent a new war with minority Muslims. "There is a glimmer of hope," he said. - Reuter

RECEIVER FOR NEWSPAPER

LONDON, Wednesday: One of Britain's few left-wing newspapers, the recently-launched News on Sunday, is to be put in the hands of an official receiver as a first step towards rescue from a financial crisis, a company spokesman said today. He said the receiver would be appointed to handle the newspaper's affairs for the time being, but a group of shareholders hoped to put together a financial package which would enable publication to continue. - Reuter

MORE POWER TO COSMONAUTS

LONDON, Wednesday: Soviet cosmonauts Yuri Romanenko and Alexander Laveikin walked in space for 3 1/4 hours today to assemble a new solar battery on the surface of their orbiting station Mir, Tass news agency reported. The battery is designed to increase the power supply aboard the space station, considerably raising the effectiveness of scientific research. It was the third space walk of their mission. - Reuter

132 KILLED IN CHINA'S FLOODS ...

PEKING, Wednesday: Floods in the Chinese province of Shaanxi have killed 132 people and destroyed more than 10,000 houses in the past three weeks, the People's Daily reported. The paper said 264 villages had been washed away. - Reuter

... WHILE FIRE CLAIMS 193 LIVES

PEKING, Wednesday: The final casualty toll in China's huge forest fire was 193 dead and 226 injured, according to the New China news agency. It said 56,000 people were left homeless by the fire, which burned from May 6 to June 2 near the Soviet border in Heilongjiang Province. - Reuter

PILOT DIES IN AIR CRASH

PEKING, Wednesday: A Boeing 737 airliner operated by China's State airline collided with a Chinese air force jet fighter in the east China city of Fuzhou, killing the fighter pilot, the New China News Agency reported today. It said one passenger was slightly injured. - Reuter

NIXON FIT AFTER SURGERY

NEW YORK, Wednesday: Former President Richard Nixon, 74, was listed in good condition in hospital today after undergoing prostate surgery, a spokesman for Mr Nixon said. - Reuter

PRESIDENTIAL ADVISER DIES

NEW YORK, Wednesday: Walter Heller, chief White House economist under President John Kennedy and an adviser to two later Presidents, died in Minneapolis, yesterday aged 71, the University of Minnesota said today. - Reuter

ISRAELI JETS ATTACK BASES

TEL AVIV, Wednesday: Israeli aircraft today attacked bases used by Palestinian and radical Shi'ite Muslim guerillas in southern Lebanon, an Israeli army spokeswoman said. In an apparently unrelated raid, Israeli jets later bombed what the army spokeswoman described as "a terrorist target" at the entrance to Ain Al-Hilweh, the largest of Lebanon's Palestinian refugee camps, near the port of Sidon. - Reuter

urn:contentItem:55B8-97N1-JD34-V0HC-00000-00Unleashing of a mass killer2012-04-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESInsightPg. 9Unleashing of a mass killerDeborah Sontag

Haiti has emerged from the world's largest cholera epidemic with fingers pointed at United Nations peacekeeping troops from Nepal. Even now, feelings of distrust remain, writes Deborah Sontag in the central town of Mirebalais.

Jean Salgadeau Pelette, handsome when medicated and groomed, often roamed this central Haitian town in a dishevelled state, wild-eyed and naked. He was a familiar figure here, the scion of a prominent family who suffered from a mental illness.

On October 16, 2010, Pelette, 38, woke at dawn in his solitary room behind a bric-a-brac shop off the town square. As was his habit, he loped down the hill to the Latem River for his bath, passing the beauty shop, the pharmacy and the funeral home where his body would soon be prepared for burial.

The river would have been busy that morning, with bathers, laundresses and schoolchildren brushing their teeth. Nobody thought of its waters, downstream from a United Nations peacekeeping base, as toxic.

When Pelette was found lying by the bank a few hours later, he was so weak from a sudden, violent stomach illness that he had to be carried back to his room. It did not immediately occur to his relatives to rush him to the hospital.

"At that time, the word 'cholera' didn't yet exist," said one of his brothers, Malherbe. "We didn't know he was in mortal danger. But by four that afternoon, my brother was dead. He was the first victim, or so they say."

In the 17 months since Pelette was buried, cholera has killed more than 7050 Haitians and sickened more than 531,000, or 5 per cent of the population. Lightning fast and virulent, it spread from here through every Haitian state, erupting into the world's largest cholera epidemic despite a huge international mobilisation still dealing with the effects of the January 2010 earthquake.

The world rallied to confront cholera, too, but the mission was muddled by the United Nations' apparent role in igniting the epidemic and its unwillingness to acknowledge it. Epidemiologic and microbiologic evidence strongly suggests UN peacekeeping troops from Nepal imported cholera to Haiti, contaminated the river tributary next to their base through a faulty sanitation system and caused a second disaster.

"It was like throwing a lighted match into a gasoline-filled room," said Dr Paul Keim, a microbial geneticist whose laboratory determined that the Haitian and Nepalese cholera strains were virtually identical.

And, as the deaths and continuing caseload indicate, the world's response to this preventable, treatable scourge has proved inadequate. Cholera, never before recorded in Haiti, stayed one step ahead of the authorities as they shifted gears from the earthquake recovery. While eventually effective in reducing the fatality rate, the response was slow to get fully under way, conservative and insufficiently sustained.

While the world has dedicated $US230 million ($223.7 million) so far to combating the unexpected epidemic, the United Nations is now pleading for an additional $US53.9 million just to get the vulnerable displaced population through the rainy months ahead.

At the same time, Haitian cholera victims are seeking compensation from the United Nations, pressing it to accept responsibility. Early on, protests against the United Nations hindered the construction of treatment centres and the delivery of lifesaving supplies. Now distrust of some cholera programs lingers, and the issue has strained the peacekeepers' relationship with the Haitians they are protecting in an eight-year-old mission to stabilise the politically volatile nation. So, too, have unrelated allegations that they engaged in criminally abusive behaviour.

"In telling the truth, the UN could have gained the trust of the population and facilitated the fight against cholera," said Dr Renaud Piarroux, who led an early investigation into the outbreak. "But that was bungled."

The United Nations maintains an independent panel of experts determined the evidence implicating its troops to be inconclusive. Questioned for this article, those same experts said Keim's work, conducted after their own, provides "irrefutable molecular evidence" that Haiti's cholera came from Nepal, in the words of G. Balakrish Nair, an Indian microbiologist. Even so, Anthony Banbury, a UN Assistant Secretary-General, said last week, "We don't think the cholera outbreak is attributable to any single factor."

Many health officials consider the cholera response "pretty remarkable," as John Vertefeuille, the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention's director in Haiti, said.

A sky-high initial fatality rate of over 9 per cent has declined to 1.3 per cent (less than 1 per cent is considered a well-managed epidemic). And the most recent statistics show new cases dropping to 120 daily.

Others, though, believe the bar for success was set too low and more lives could have been saved. Some critics bemoan weak disease surveillance and case-tracking, others inadequate water distribution and latrine building, and still others what they see as a penny-pinching reluctance to use antibiotics and the cholera vaccine.

Also, some think cholera could have been stymied last winter during the dry season after the first wave. Instead, it flared with the rains even as aid groups shut down or reduced operations. And now health authorities fear a reprise.

"I think it's going to be another bad year for cholera," said Dr. John Carroll, an Illinois doctor who works in Haiti.

Inside City Hall, the deputy mayor described how he personally buried 27 bodies for fear that workers would not take precautions, how he nearly lost two of his children to cholera and how he seethed every time Nepalese troops entered his offices.

"They were in my face every day, and the feeling inside me got stronger and stronger," said Ocxama Moise, the deputy mayor. "A few months ago, I even considered killing a soldier or two to see what would happen. I shared the idea with some friends and they said, 'Don't. You're an official.' But it's only a matter of time before the population finds a way to get justice."

Haiti had escaped the cholera that raged through Latin America in the 1990s, and even the cholera that struck the Caribbean in the 19th century. It appeared "extremely unlikely" that cholera would present itself, a CDC post-earthquake brief said. Seven months later, that assumption would be challenged.

On October 8, 2010, hundreds of Nepalese troops began arriving in Haiti after a cholera outbreak in their homeland, where cholera is endemic; the country weathers outbreaks well, with that one causing nine deaths. Cholera also affects individuals differently; many infected develop no symptoms or only mild diarrhoea.

Falling violently ill in October 2010, Pelette was not one of the lucky ones. Severe cholera causes profuse watery diarrhoea, often accompanied by vomiting. Treatment is straightforward: replacing lost fluids and electrolytes, orally or intravenously. But those like Pelette who get no treatment can become so dehydrated they go into shock and swiftly die.

Enter the epidemic

A couple of hours after Pelette died from what the family priest proclaimed to be a poison of some sort, Rosemond Laurime, 21, a "small-businessman" in his family's description, got sick in nearby Meille.

From Meille, the epidemic coursed through the Artibonite River valley, landing with a thump 75 kilometres north-west, and downstream, in the coastal Saint-Marc area. On October 19, three children died in rapid succession in a classroom in the rice fields. On October 20, the St. Nicholas Hospital was overrun.

Patients sprawled on every surface, doubled and tripled up on beds, in the halls, in the courtyard and even on the pavement outside. By nightfall, there were 404. Forty-four died.

"At that moment, I felt like I didn't want to live any longer myself," said Dr Yfto Mayette, the hospital director. "It was so sudden and so brutal."

On October 21, as a brass band accompanied Pelette's white coffin to the cemetery, the US national laboratory completed its analysis of the bacteria. It was cholera.

In Port-au-Prince, Jocelyne Pierre-Louis, a senior Haitian health official, had steeled herself. "We were in a way waiting for the other shoe to drop," she said. "We had barely picked ourselves up after the earthquake when the cholera fell on us."

The 'blame game'

Within a week of the outbreak, officials in Mirebalais were pointing fingers at the UN base, and UN officials were trying to stifle what they portrayed as rumours. The struggle began between those who thought determining the epidemic's origin was important and those who lamented "the blame game".

At first, the United Nations said the base's handling of its waste met international standards - that it used sealed septic tanks, which were regularly emptied by a Haitian contractor, with the waste buried in a proper landfill.

But on October 27, Al-Jazeera filmed peacekeepers with shovels "working furiously to contain what looks like a sewage spill". Latrines appeared to be emptying black liquid directly into the river, a reporter said, and the air smelled foul with excrement.

That same day, the Associated Press observed an overflowing septic tank at the base and discovered the landfill to be open pits in a residential area uphill from the community's bathing stream.

Even four months later, the United Nations' own experts, examining the base's supposedly improved sanitation, discovered haphazard piping with "significant potential for cross-contamination" between toilets and showers.

Before long, hundreds of Haitians were marching on the base, with demonstrations spreading to Port-au-Prince and riots developing in Cap Haitien. Edmond Mulet, then head of the UN stabilisation mission, complained that it was "really unfair to accuse the UN for bringing cholera into Haiti". UN officials believed agitators were taking advantage of the issue to sow unrest before November elections. But many Haitians were genuinely incensed - and fearful. Some wanted an explanation, others a scapegoat.

In early November, the CDC said Haitian cholera samples matched strains commonly found in South Asia.

Delay and disbelief

In February 2011, nearly four months after the outbreak, the United Nations' independent experts arrived in Haiti.

The Secretary-General's office wanted them to move quickly but not too quickly; it did not want the findings released until the Nepalese contingent had concluded its six-month rotation, Daniele Lantagne, an American engineer, said.

When the experts revealed their findings in May, the Secretary-General's staff members were surprised, Lantagne said. Early theories had proposed environmental explanations for the outbreak.

"I believe they fully expected our results to be that there was no possibility cholera was imported into Haiti," she said.

Instead, the panel said not only that the cholera had come from South Asia but that it originated in the tributary behind the Nepalese base.

Yet the UN experts noted "the introduction of this cholera strain as a result of environmental contamination with faeces could not have been the source of such an outbreak without simultaneous water and sanitation and health care system deficiencies". And they diplomatically concluded that the epidemic was "not the fault of, or deliberate action of, a group or individual".

It is tempting now when reported cholera cases are at a low for Haitians to relax their guard and for health officials to take a breather.

"We are no longer 24/7 cholera," said Pierre-Louis, the senior Haitian health official. The same thing happened last year. Then the rains hit and Port-au-Prince, like other places, experienced more cases - 24,000 - during a 42-day period than at the epidemic's start. It was a scramble to deal with the surge; many grants had expired, emergency workers had gone home and treatment centres were closed.

Vertefeuille of the CDC also said cholera was likely to persist in Haiti, without the development of water and sanitation systems. A singular achievement was the opening of Haiti's first wastewater treatment site last year.

However, many express keen frustration that the dry season is not being used for aggressive case tracking - chasing the disease into pockets where it flares, investigating and chlorinating the water source and mobilising the community.

"You can't wait with your arms crossed until the rain falls again," Piarroux said. "You have to go after these areas like firemen trying to extinguish every last burning ember of a forest fire."

In Meille, the walled gate at the UN base is freshly painted now with the insignia of Uruguayan peacekeepers. The Nepalese are gone. The mission itself is reducing its forces nationwide. Nepal's troop strength is being cut by two-thirds, more than any other country's. UN officials said that this was unrelated to tensions over cholera.

But people here think otherwise: "If they hadn't left, we would have burned it down," Moise, the deputy mayor, said of the base.

Behind the base, the stream where the epidemic began bustles with life now as it did before the outbreak; many who live and work beside it have no other access to free water.

Recently, just behind the base's barbed-wire periphery, Dieula Senechal squatted with her skirt hiked up, scrubbing clothes while a naked 6-year-old girl, Magalie Louis, defecated by the bank and splashed into the water to brush her teeth.

Approaching with a machete on his way to hack some cane, her gap-toothed father, Legenord Louis, said Magalie had contracted cholera late last year but after four days of "special IVs" was restored to health. He knew the river water was probably not safe, he said, but, while they brushed their teeth in it, they did not swallow.

For drinking water, Louis said, his family relies on a local well. But he lives from hand to mouth and cannot afford water purification tablets. So he gambles.

"If you make it to the hospital," he said, "you survive the cholera".

urn:contentItem:4P89-SVT0-TXN5-T2FY-00000-00Forests: leaner, meaner and greener1998-01-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisSATURDAY MAGAZINEPg. 7Forests: leaner, meaner and greenerWith new emphasis on both wilderness protection and financial performance, the controversial reform of State Forests has also been blamed for the grief of timber industry job losses. Maureen Fitzhenry spoke with the new regional forest chief from his new Newcastle headquarters about the challenges of managing our bush.MAUREEN FITZHENRY

RESIDENTS of the Hunter Region live with the forest in their backyard.

The extensive `urban interface' with the bush and the Watagan Mountains is unique in Australia and part of what makes this area such a joy to live in.

It also creates a big headache for the people trying to balance the use of our forests among the commercial timber industry, recreational users, and wildlife habitat not to mention the challenge of forest fire prevention.

And as more people leave the cities for the tranquility of life in the bush, the dilemma multiplies.

`Instead of dealing with one farmer on 100 acres (40.5ha), we might be dealing now with five property owners on 20 acres (8ha) each,' explained Mr Mick Cooper, the new Hunter Regional manager of State Forests.

`We'll come in to do some selective harvesting or maybe some hazard-reduction burning and it can become very complicated.

`It's the encroachment of urban society into the forests.'

It is this `people factor' that makes Mr Cooper's new job different from his last position as regional manager based in Taree.

`The one thing I see in the Hunter is the extra range of responsibility,' he said from new offices on King St in Newcastle, just opened in November.

`Forests here are close to a lot of people, which further underlines the need for sustainability so all these different uses can continue without jeopardising opportunities for future generations.'

With the change of State Government in 1995 came a forest reform program that has recently come into full implementation, characterised by two main tenets protecting old growth forests and improving financial performance and accountability.

On the surface, these are conflicting goals.

But Mr Cooper said the key to proper forest management was balance. The idea was to shift timber operations to regrowth areas and dramatically expanded plantations, while drawing up careful, detailed assessment plans before logging proceeded in any native forest area.

At present, NSW forest and plantations provide little more than half the sawn wood requirements of the State, with the remainder imported. The goal for 2015 is to meet 90% of the State's own needs.

But not at the expense of the environment.

At present, there is no new logging proceeding outside plantations or regrowth areas. Logging quotas have been cut to about 50% of 1995 levels.

New parks and wilderness areas have been declared, including a substantial increase to the Barrington wilderness area.

But these moves have caused a great deal of pain for traditional timber companies and the communities like Gloucester, Bulahdelah and Stroud which have relied on them.

One prediction is that half of NSW sawmills will close. Since reform began, Boral Timber has closed seven NSW operations, including a December 11 announcement of the closure of Gloucester's sawmill in March, putting 30 employees out of work.

Industry estimates have cited 350 of 1200 jobs at risk across the Hunter.

WE lay the blame fair and square on Mr Carr for locking up timber resources in wilderness areas and ignoring the social consequences,' Gloucester council's general manager, Mr Norm McLeod, said.

Environmentalists, however, have long been concerned about overharvesting native forests, pointing to soil erosion, water pollution, loss of habitat, ecosystem destruction and contributing to the greenhouse effect. Regrowth forests are a sad replacement, they say.

Armed with opinion polls that consistently show a majority of Australians opposed to woodchipping of State forests, the Newcastle Wilderness Society barraged Newcastle City Council in September with 1000 letters, pushing unsuccessfully for a boycott of Boral Timber products.

Mr Cooper said the bottom line was that the forests belong to the people.

`And we've got the important and responsible role of managing them for the people,' he said, adding people have the power to make their wishes known through voting and through soon-to-be-established public Harvest Advisory Boards.

`Management must become adaptive to community expectation and the process has to be transparent. People can't just huddle in an office and make decisions.'

But, make no mistake this is big business and it's supposed to be run as such.

Mr Cooper, 52, manages a budget of $5million, oversees 240,000ha of forests 60 employees and is expected to return dividends to the Government in exchange for the taxpayer investment.

The department is expected to be increasingly innovative in its ways to make money, but a full 75% of its income comes from the sale of timber.

And Mr Cooper is a great proponent of increasing the use of timber.

`One thing that concerns me is that people don't realise what a valuable renewable resource timber is,' he said.

`Coal and oil will run out, they won't be there forever. Iron ore and aluminum supplies won't go on forever either: these are non-renewable resources and it takes a lot of energy to extract them and a lot of pollutants are created in the process.

`When you look at timber, it is a renewable resource and there are less energy inputs into your product. Timber needs water, carbon dioxide . . . and it needs sunlight. And if sunlight runs out, I suggest we're in deep trouble already.'

Environmentally, that makes timber a more viable option than steel. And Mr Cooper said we were all large consumers of timber whether we liked it or not.

`There has been a huge increase in the pulp and paper industry from things like faxes and photocopiers,' he said. `The days of having one circular and passing it around are over. Instead, we run off a copy for everyone.'

In his long forestry career, Mr Cooper has done almost everything related to trees.

`We develop as multi-skilled people. When you're a forester, you're there as a firefighter, a forest industry engineer, a silviculturalist (tree planter), a school tour guide, a land-use manager, a harvester you're there to run the whole business.' *

Branching out: The new Hunter Regional manager of State Forests, with staff in the new King St, Newcastle, office.
