urn:contentItem:4PTG-KFP0-TX52-H0DY-00000-00Your Say ... / Letters to the Editor2007-10-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 37Your Say ... / Letters to the Editor

Talkin' about an evolution

Your environment reporter Saffron Howden is right -- climate change affects everybody, everywhere ('Sacrifice today will stop a barren future,' The Daily Telegraph, October 3).

Dr Penny Whetton, CSIRO scientist and co-author of the report ''Climate Change In Australia'', is correct to suggest we need to adapt. There's something Darwinian happening here: we either evolve, or various businesses and our way of life will die out.

After all, the Earth does not belong to us, we belong to it, so it's our responsibility to manage climate change.

Malcolm Turnbull, Minister for the Environment, should do something for our environment and insist that Prime Minister John Howard ratify the Kyoto Protocol before it's too late.

Dixie Coulton

Elizabeth Bay

Cut the claptrap

The CSIRO did not make a scientific announcement yesterday. It made a political one. It did not quote any recent studies, but rehashed disproven old theories.

Climate change is occurring, but it requires a lot more than emotional scare-mongering to combat it. Controlling carbon emissions is like using a wet bag to fight a forest fire. Models can't predict future climate because the data used in them is inadequate. When some real scientific data is put into this debate instead of the emotional claptrap -- ''Will someone think of the children?'' -- the better equipped we will be to do something real about climate change.

Charlie Kenny

Penrith

More out of Africa

Kevin Andrews' move to cease accepting any more refugees from Africa until next year is inhumane ('African refugee scheme is closed,' The Daily Telegraph, October 3).

It is hardly surprising that some refugees have had problems. Many of them have lived through horrors that most of us can only imagine. This is the nature of being a refugee: it is not a cosy fireside choice made by the comfortably-off.

To say that we have reached our quota is unacceptable to those with a sense of justice.

Janet McNeill

Redfern

Some home truths

We are running out of water, and don't forget that water is life. Our infrastructure -- roads, schools, hospitals, etc -- can't cope with the increase of the population. Everything we need to maintain our prosperity is in disarray in spite of a stong economy. The main priority should be to fix all these problems, then we can start talking about immigration.

In a democratic society the people should decide who comes to this country and the circumstances in which they come. Is it hard to have a referendum on this issue because I'm sure that would seal many lips.

Rick

Sydney, online comment

Steer hoons straight

I believe that hoons are an everyday fact of life ('Safety lessons or prison for hoons,' The Daily Telegraph, October 3). Why? Because there have always been hoons, and there will always be people who want to push the boundaries of man and machine.

How do you combat people doing this on public roads? Give them more readily available access to secure areas where they can test their mettle. After they scare the wits out of themselves, they will be less inclined to show how fast and furious they are on the street.

I also believe the key to avoiding idiots behind the wheel has a twofold solution. First, educate young drivers early, in schools, not with some driving instructor out to make a buck passing on bad habits.

Secondly, harsh fines and immediate loss of licence for anyone not on full open licence if they are caught doing anything wrong. If you actually enforced this law, all those fools would be too scared to do anything in public.

John

Townsville

Scare the idiots

These hoons are not thinking of anyone else, just the excitement of the speed and the race. So the police, ambulance drivers and a visit to the spinal unit, burns unit and emergency should enlighten them. Hopefully they will make better choices in future and be better safer drivers. Good luck with the program.

Diane Magaric

Mt Kuring-gai

Stop horse-trading

The Premier of NSW has short arms and long pockets ('Backflip over EI cash for low paid', The Daily Telegraph, October 3). His rescue package for the payment of workers in the racing industry is long overdue.

The state Government is always happy to take its swag of money from the industry, but are reluctant to hand anything back, especially when the whole industry has its back to the wall.

This state Government only shows how much out of touch it is with Australian life.

Dick Filmer

Manly Vale

HOT TOPIC

Blog on ...

Austin Healey is a halfwit. He has a very high opinion of himself that never really translated to on-field talent.

Rugby Boy

Sydney

I think he has us confused with New Zealand. How can a Pommie have a go at us? They can't play cricket, tennis, rugby, football, they whinge and they don't wash. They are going to get a hiding on Saturday.

The Rodster

Sydney

Surely this brain-dead Pom is kidding. So he doesn't like our way of life -- who cares. If one were to go back over the centuries, one could find a lot not to like about the English. We out here are proud of all our sporting teams, as they have served us well over the years. I hope the Wallabies make you eat your despicable words.

Dawn Hall

Acacia Gardens

Waltzing Matilda, we bloody killed her. Go Ole England and reduce Australia to tears like we did so easily in 2003 in their own backyard. Australia to choke again -- Aussie whingers.

Poms

England

You have to take Austin Healey's words with a touch of spice -- surely we know that by now. However, give him credit, since he was spot-on calling Justin Harrison a ''plank''.

Rowley Aird

Hong Kong

We will see on Saturday if lil' Johnny can stand the heat the loose forwards will put on him. After watching their last game, his boys can't protect him from ours.

Mark

Sydney

Anyone would think this is a two-horse race. Who do you think the all-time champs are? You'll remember when the All Blacks raise the cup.

Terry Flinders

Bondi

SHORT & SHARP

Why doesn't Christine Anu put the shoe on the other foot ('Anu shows gay support after run-in,' The Daily Telegraph, October 3). The reality is that a 13-year-old with dark skin running around with a gun, real or not, in that area is not something that would surprise many readers. Now she's going to make some complaint about the police for doing their job, wasting time and money to investigate her friend's hurt feelings. And as for being branded a lesbian, she was only asked a question.

D. Farrelly

Paddington

I don't know why so much money is being spent on Diana's inquest ('How did Diana really die,' The Daily Telegraph, October 3). It seems like a pretty elaborate scheme. If they really wanted to get rid of her, a staged suicide would have been the way to go. She had attempted it before and few would have asked questions if she had done it again

Robert Thompson

Wyong

In reply to Brett McMillan ('Your Say,' October 2), the Grants Commission and the States worked out a share of the GST to each State. Bob Carr, as then-NSW Premier, would have taken part in the discussions.

Pat Hutchinson

Narromine

The new Commissioner of Police, Andrew Scipione, has stated he intends to make his mark on the force with his leadership. Does this include excusing officers when they remove identification badges because they ''may be used as weapons against officers''? We saw this under the Premiership of Bob Askin, and it wasn't any better then than now. That's a step back, Mr Scipione.

David Jerome

Berry

What a pack of hypocrites the Labor Party is ('Labor pulls rates ad,' The Daily Telegraph, October 3). During the bad old days of the Keating era, when interest rates were at 17 per cent plus, my daughter lost the house she was buying. To put the icing on the cake, Keating introduced capital gains tax. They couldn't manage a piggy bank.

J. M. Samios

Davistown

As a Pom living in Australia for the past six months, it has really surprised me the one-way criticism, loathing and narrow-mindedness of a majority of Aussies who think England care what the Australians think of them ('Friendly rivalry? No, we hate them,' The Daily Telegraph, October 3). Everyone wants to beat England at sport, which I can't understand because we are generally OK, not great, at most sports. You Aussies will have to join the queue of nations who don't like us.

Paul Meredith

Gold Coast, online comment

ON THE STREET

Should we have a quota on the number of refugees?

The question is how to test if they are genuine refugees but there shouldn't be a quota.

Jonothan O'Keeffe

Surry Hills

There is not a big enough problem with them to justify a quota. We have space.

Julie O'Connor

Newtown

They should be processed on their individual merit, not by numbers.

Mark Castle

Mascot

We need to be strict on immigrants. But most refugees aren't here by choice.

Yvonne Biemans

Sydney CBD

While others, in my opinion, book months too early, I usually attempt to book weeks too late.</p><p nitf:lede="true">On the other hand, my mismanagements have sometimes turned out luckily.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Indeed, that is how I first discovered my favourite holiday destination in Europe, the large Mediterranean island of Corsica.</p><p>Officially Corsica is part of France. As such, it can claim the highest number of hours of sunshine of any French department, not least because it lies further to the south than anywhere else in France.</p><p>Yet, because much of the island is high above sea level, the climate is seldom excessively hot, even in high summer. Soft winds blow much of the year round off the surrounding sea.</p><p>Although the island is only 200km in length, it boasts a higher mountain than anything in Australia. Monte Cinto, which is situated in the northwest of the island, is some 500m higher than Mount Kosciuszko.</p><p>Much of the inland of Corsica, which is known sometimes as the Granite Isle, is mountainous and primitive. Roads to some areas are certainly not for the faint-hearted yet generally reward visitors with breathtaking views or with a personal discovery of some village that has remained virtually unchanged since the 18th century.</p><p>My first experience of Corsica arose through my failure to book a cabin for the 24-hour sea crossing which links Britain with northern Spain. Understandably, my female friend declined to spend that length of time sitting on deck.</p><p>So what else could my regular travel agent suggest at very short notice in the peak period of the European holiday season? He did have one villa which was always difficult to let. That was because access to it was up a precipitous, twisting, slippery track with a sharp drop to one side lying in wait for the inebriated or unskilful.</p><p>"I'll take it," I cried in relief.</p><p>However, after my first hair-raising ascent of the track to the villa near Propriano, in the southwest of Corsica, I wondered how often I would venture out again during the next fortnight.</p><p>Yet what glories awaited us.</p><p>At 500m, the villa I rented was the last evidence of development on the hillside. Beyond the garden, le maquis began: the thick carpet of aromatic vegetation which covers all but the highest peaks of the island. The odours of myrtle, arbutus, rosemary and thyme mingle with those of ever-present pine trees to create a heady, almost intoxicating scent.</p><p>The great Napoleon, who was Corsica's most famous son, always claimed that he could smell myrtle the moment he approached the isle of his birth by ship.</p><p>The fine house of Napoleon's family is only one of the many attractions of the large seaport of Ajaccio. Ajaccio with a population of 60,000 and Bastia with 40,000 are the only large towns on a generally under-populated island.</p><p>In the 19th century, when the total population of Corsica stood at about 100,000, that figure was depleted annually to the tune of 1000 men by the depredations of the vendetta, the name given to the murderous family feuds which were once central to Corsican codes of honour. Those fascinated by the history of such feuds can let their imaginations run free in the ancient and gloomy southern town of Sartene where for years members of feuding families hardly dared to leave their houses.</p><p>A vendetta could begin with something as trivial as a donkey wandering on to someone else's land or a too admiring glance aimed at someone else's sister.</p><p> Indeed, the tradition of the vendetta may well have accounted for the longevity of one of the world's more amazing archaeological secrets.</p><p>Fifty odd years ago English author Dorothy Carrington was chatting with a local farmer in Corsica's southwest. The conversation ran roughly like this:</p><p>Carrington: "Have you heard about the amazing carved menhir (standing stone) someone's just found?" Farmer: "What's so surprising about that? I've got plenty of them on my property."</p><p>Broadly speaking, this was how Filitosa was discovered -- a kind of Corsican Stonehenge. The stone warriors of Filitosa are 4000 years old yet represent only one of the wonderful megalithic sites found on Corsica.</p><p>As I have mentioned, people did not wander across other people's land in the old days of the vendetta. That was why Filitosa's secret was preserved.</p><p>Happily, landowners are mostly less touchy these days. I managed to track down another extraordinary site myself after a long trek across fields.</p><p>When I got there, several cows were my sole companions as they scratched their backs on a double line of some 70 historic stones.</p><p>Modern Corsica is French-speaking and generally offers homelier versions of French cuisine. On the other hand, wonderful local seafood, including lobsters, are available at most beachside cafes and restaurants. These are usually washed down with a local dry rose.</p><p>Superb beaches abound, on the western, rockier side of the island especially.</p><p>For those swimming near Propriano, however, a particular hazard exists. This comes in the form of bright yellow, twin-engined firefighting aircraft which swoop down on to the sea's surface to fill their water-tanks. At least one snorkeller has been said to have been swept up and deposited rather unwillingly on a forest fire.</p><p>Although distances are not great in Corsica, travel by car tends to be slow owing to narrow, twisting roads. If you want to explore the island thoroughly, allow two or three weeks at least. In high summer, the narrow roads can also be crowded with coaches and buses. So here is a good tip.</p><p>IF YOU do not especially like being the motorist permanently exposed to huge, unsecured drops, circumnavigate the coast of Corsica clockwise (the French drive on the right). This advice applies particularly to Cap Corse which sticks up like a finger at the top of the island.</p><p>When is the best time of the year to visit Corsica?</p><p>My choice would be late May, June or late September.</p><p>I have flown there from London but also travelled there on a giant car ferry from the French port of Toulon. This ferry is 12 decks in height and about 170m long. Standing on the top deck in the harbour of Toulon you probably have the best vantage-point in town.</p><p>Corsica offers beautiful historic towns, untamed countryside, lovely beaches and an agreeable climate. Remarkable butterflies, moths and other insects abound, as do handsome wildflowers in the aromatic maquis. Le maquis also gives its name to the island's best hotel which is situated just south of Ajaccio.</p><p>If you like top-class food, a private beach and floodlit tennis court, sea views and a restaurant by the pool, Le Maquis could be your kind of place. It is certainly mine although I could never really quite afford it.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49NM-MXM0-01S8-80J2-00000-00<published>1994-06-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:58:46Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Port and Norwood no longer the match of the day but. . .</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>STEVEN TRIGG</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Big mistake to write off the Magpies Throughout its celebrated 124-year history, Port Adelaide has not often been upstaged, particularly when it has played the old foe from The Parade.</p><p nitf:lede="true">But while tomorrow's Port-Norwood clash at Alberton would customarily assume match-of-the-day status, the Central v Eagles game at Football Park certainly looms as the big hit of the round.</p><p nitf:lede="true">That, in turn, leads us to make some sort of sense out of Port's recent, uncharacteristically poor form.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Those who aren't Port supporters have been crossing fingers and toes, hoping that the black-and-white demise will continue. And much of the media's attention has broadly been on the fact that things just aren't as they used to be.</p><p>But to be objective, and identify a few of the trees amongst a forest on fire, reveals a couple of valid reasons for the run of outs, and probably a more familiar scenario for the weeks to come.</p><p>Sure, the Magpies have had a lean month, just like all good sides do from time to time. Like the Eagles, for example. But as a general principle it's not an all bad thing to be ironing out flaws and functioning at less than peak performance in the month of May.</p><p>Consider for a moment the losses Port is having to cover. Where analysts tend to give other struggling clubs the benefit of the doubt by focusing on their player losses, how many times have you heard about the Magpies' difficulty in replacing valued stock? More than that - it has to be reluctantly conceded - how many times have you heard Port itself bleat about the loss of personnel? The answer to both questions is rarely, if ever.</p><p>Surely they could be forgiven for being tempted, because a quick summary reveals some critical departures in the past two years.</p><p>Greg Phillips, Mark Williams, Nathan Buckley, Braden Lyle, Che Cockatoo-Collins, Shane Wakelin, Bruce Abernethy, Danny Hughes, Troy and Shane Bond have all moved on. And long-term injuries to David Hutton, Paul Northeast, Adrian Settre, Daryl Borlase, Paul Rigoni, Tony Malakellis and Richard Foster complete a list that is in itself the backbone of a team.</p><p>A list that understandbly dictates a need for re-organising and re-stabilising. It's not unique to Port by any means, but it is a definite factor.</p><p>In itself, the volume of new and young faces means a little more fragility, and less of an established commitment to the mystique of the only remaining lace-up jumper.</p><p>It also remains that despite the protestations of the Magpie administration and team leaders that the very emotive and public AFL bid has no bearing on the teams performance, it is impossible for that not to be the case. It must be a distraction at some level, at some time.</p><p>Whether it is a direct thought process in a player's mind concerning the possibilities of his personal future; or the constant barrage that would surely be confronted in everyday life from an inquisitive public</p><p>- it's no doubt a diversion from the ideal preparation.</p><p>But it is conceivably less likely to be a factor when the finals series looms in three months time, and the focus switches to a certain participation in the major round.</p><p>The Magpies still represent a very powerful side, and one which is bound to recover from its woes.</p><p>A side that boasts the experience of Tim Ginever, Roger Delaney, Stephen Williams, Darren Smith and George Fiacchi; and is complemented by the exuberance and dash of youngsters like Damien Angove, Troy Olsen and Stephen Carter will bounce back. Especially when one considers the added riches available in front of goal.</p><p>Jack Cahill has declared that his own worth should be questioned if Port does not make the five this year. And though this has fuelled the forest fire for those with suspicious minds who believe Jack may already know what he's doing next year, it is more likely based on the huff and puff that has been the cornerstone of the Magpies' long-term success.</p><p>There is also an element of confidence for the coach in the knowledge that the quality of personnel is there. With some work and greater urgency it will come together because the bottom line is that Port is a good side, going through a difficult patch. So if your fingers are crossed for a continuation of Magpie misery, you might be disappointed, even though tomorrow's match has seceded No. 1 billing.</p><p>Certainly the Redlegs themselves have not pulled their weight in creating that top billing for the game by displaying such erratic and generally poor form. And against a Port side which invariably plays better at home, it is a daunting task for Norwood.</p><p>The match-of-the-day status accorded to the EAGLES and CENTRAL DISTRICT is essentially because of the Bulldogs' wonderfully committed performances over the season, and more particularly in recent weeks.</p><p>Extraordinarily, over the past two months the 'Dogs have won their games by an astounding average of 75 points, and had their daylight outings upset only by North Adelaide.</p><p>But the Eagles, having endured their own mini-slump until last week's extraordinary second-half revival, look to have a little too much scoring power. Though based on the night final a couple of weeks ago, it promises to be a defensively tough and absorbing bout.</p><p>GLENELG should be able to bounce back and roll a rejuvenated SOUTH at Adelaide Oval, and WEST will enjoy hosting NORTH for the second time this season by also scoring a win.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>2 photos: john cahill; roger delaney; John Cahill: Has declared his own worth should bequestioned if Port doesn't make five. Roger Delaney:Experienced defender back for Magpies.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">ADVSUN-ADV9406042033872005</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">THEADVERTISERLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:49NM-MXM0-01S8-80J2-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">244790</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-21</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="889"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>The Advertiser</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1994 Nationwide News Pty Limited</copyright><publicationDate day="04" month="06" year="1994"><dateText>June 4, 1994 Saturday</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newspapers</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="subject"><classificationItem score="68"><classCode>STX001009</classCode><className>FOREST FIRES</className></classificationItem></classification><classification classificationScheme="city"><classificationItem score="73"><classCode>GX018</classCode><className>ADELAIDE, AUSTRALIA</className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup></metadata></articleDoc></content></entry>

urn:contentItem:51TY-93N1-JCVT-J1HC-00000-00THE DEADLY DECADE2010-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisINSIGHTPg. 15THE DEADLY DECADEAdam Morton is environment reporter.

The past 10 years have been the hottest since measurements began, and climate scientists have long warned of the extreme weather still to come. Adam Morton reports. NEVILLE Nicholls is a climate scientist. He has long believed his role was research, not advocacy. But when he woke on the morning following Black Saturday, turned on his TV and caught his breath after witnessing the shocking aerial footage of what was once Marysville, he instinctively blamed himself.

"My initial thought was: is this my fault? Has this happened because I haven't been out there saying that this stuff is going to have catastrophic consequences for us?" he recalls. "It is the first time I have ever been shaken from my belief that I shouldn't be an advocate on climate change." Nicholls - an Australian Research Council professorial fellow at Monash University and an author and reviewer with the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) - resolved to take more responsibility to be a public voice; not to lobby for a particular political response, but to explain and defend the science that is his life's work. He wasn't alone. Increasingly, as the first decade of the century unfolded, Australia's most decorated scientists in climate fields were concerned that published evidence in their areas of expertise was being misused or ignored. Believing they faced a misinformation campaign driven by fossil-fuel interests and an intransigent political system, they formed Climate Scientists Australia as a means to improve the quality of public information and decision-making. For some members, the challenge they faced was underscored in July when the Victorian Bushfires Royal Commission released its four-volume final report and made little reference to climate change. It has been said so often that it should be well known by now: no extreme event can be definitively blamed on the surge in atmospheric greenhouse gases since industrialisation. But when events closely replicate what dozens of climate models have predicted will come, neither can they and climate change be divorced. The 13 members of Climate Scientists Australia believe February 7, 2009, was such a case: 46.4 degrees in Melbourne - not just the city's hottest day on record, but more than 3 degrees warmer than February's previous maximum. Coinciding with turbulent winds and coming after a record 12 years of below-average rains, it added to an unprecedented score of 172 on the Forest Fire Danger Index, according to a report to the royal commission by Melbourne University fire ecologist Dr Kevin Tolhurst. Ash Wednesday in 1983 - the second-worst day for dangerous fire conditions - rated just 120, the devastating 1939 inferno 100. In the October edition of the Bulletin of the Australian Meteorological & Oceanographic Society, Nicholls summarised: "A quantitative analysis leaves no doubt that the combination of weather conditions leading up to Black Saturday, and on the day, had not been observed previously in the 150 years of Melbourne instrumental weather data." The commission, though, found neither the day nor the fires were unprecedented, accepting oral evidence from land and fuel management experts that the Black Saturday fires were not a shift from what had come before. Nicholls, one of several scientists to lodge a submission with the commission linking the fires with human-induced climate change, was surprised. "I think a focus on the fact that we had not previously seen such extreme fire weather and climate conditions is important," he says. "If we simply note that Black Saturday was just another instance of serious fires occurring in association with hot, dry, windy conditions, then we could lose sight of how extraordinary the weather conditions were, and we may not consider changes in strategy that could help us cope with even more extreme fires in the future." The public debate over climate change has yielded its share of controversies, confected and otherwise, but in the eyes of leading scientists the royal commission's response is emblematic of the biggest of the past 10 years: the failure to convince policymakers and shapers to take the warnings of the world's most reputable scientific agencies seriously enough to respond effectively. The global public's awareness of climate change grew significantly over the decade, but by this year, according to some polls, its acceptance of the science had diminished. The decline was particularly marked in Britain and the US. Britain was home to the so-called "Climategate" affair, in which senior scientists were accused of manipulating data after ambiguous emails were leaked from the University of East Anglia. The scientists were exonerated of the most serious claims of dishonesty by a series of inquiries, but the damage was done - the findings clearing their names received only a fraction of the press coverage of the initial allegations. A separate investigation by the InterAcademy Council recommended changes to the IPCC, including greater care and transparency, but found its work synthesising published climate science was mostly successful. In the US, there was a concerted attack from the resurgent Republican Party and influential parts of the media claiming climate science was a hoax and conspiracy. A University of Maryland study published this month found Fox News viewers were 30 percentage points more likely to incorrectly believe that most scientists do not agree that climate change is occurring, or that views are split. The public mood was not helped by the debacle of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change meeting in Copenhagen in December 2009, which left people with the not unreasonable perception that the world's leaders had no idea how to tackle the problem. The recent follow-up meeting in Cancun managed to glue the pieces of the broken talks back together, but left the most challenging issues in forging a new treaty to build on the Kyoto Protocol - which covers little more than a quarter of global emissions - to a later date. Meanwhile, the claims made on climate change's behalf continued to mount. Delegates in Cancun were handed a report by aid agency Oxfam, quoting insurance agency Munich Re, which had linked 21,000 deaths in the first nine months of 2010 to climate change. It was twice the number of casualties caused by extreme weather in all of 2009. The mid-year floods that soaked a fifth of Pakistan alone killed about 2000 people and affected the lives of 20 million. The same weather system caused extraordinary summer heat in near-Arctic Russia that wiped out crops, caused rampant wildfires and doubled the usual summer death rate for Moscow. It rang alarm bells for those familiar with the IPCC's projection, based on more than 20 climate models that to date had proved remarkably accurate, that a significant temperature rise above pre-industrial levels would increase the likelihood of floods in southern Asia and the risk of heat waves and wildfires in Europe. The New York Times - a journal of influence not known for running hard on the science of climate change - responded by running front-page pictures of the Pakistani and Russian disasters alongside a shot of storms pummelling Chicago under the headline "In weather chaos, a case for global warming". "The climate is changing," the National Climatic Data Centre's Jay Lawrimore told the paper. "Extreme events are occurring with greater frequency, and in many cases with greater intensity." Munich Re reported that its database of natural catastrophes showed the number of extreme weather events such as windstorms and floods had tripled since 1980 "and the trend is expected to persist". Not everyone working in the area is comfortable with linking the current shift in extreme events with greenhouse gases. There is disagreement in the scientific literature over whether extreme weather disasters have started to worsen. According to one view, there is little to no change in the proportions of people affected once population growth is factored in. What does not remain a contested area in the scientific literature is that the planet is getting hotter. Analysing the data from the world's three temperature datasets, the World Meteorological Organisation last month reported that the past decade was the warmest since instrumental measurement began in 1850, and 2010 was on track to be the hottest year, and certainly in the top three, regardless of the extraordinary snow dumps clogging European and US cities over Christmas. (There is significant evidence to suggest that global warming is responsible for the extreme northern winters of the past two years. An increase in air pressure in the Arctic atmosphere caused by warmer heat coming off a relatively ice-free ocean is pushing cold air south.) Eighteen countries broke their records for the hottest day ever this year. Only one year in the 20th century - 1998 - was warmer than any so far in the 21st. The noughties was the decade of the killer heatwave. Western Europe was hit in August 2003, when extreme heat was estimated to have contributed to the deaths of 46,000. About a third of the deaths were in France. Usually home to mild summers, it was unprepared for the impact on the weak and elderly of a week's worth of days hotter than 40 degrees. There were widespread crop failures and forest fires, particularly in southern Europe. About a tenth of Portugal's forests burned. In Australia, Victoria had never had three consecutive days above 42 degrees until January last year, when there were three above 43 degrees. The horrendous bushfire death toll in early February was dwarfed by the "invisible disaster" of the January heatwave, which is estimated to have killed 500 people in Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania. Perhaps the biggest step-change came in Russia this past northern summer, when at least five days in Moscow topped 100 degrees fahrenheit (37.78 degrees celsius) - a barrier that had never been crossed. An estimated 15,000 people died and the country's massive grain harvest was devastated by wildfire. According to Russian state weather service chief Alexander Frolov, it was the country's worst heatwave in a millennium. "Nothing like it can be seen in the archives," he said. Nicholls says there are clear similarities between the three disasters, and others in Pakistan, Greece and California: "They have all been unprecedented, they all killed a lot of people and destroyed a lot of infrastructure." Greenhouse gas emissions have continued to rise. Earlier this month the Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii showed that atmospheric carbon dioxide had reached 390 parts per million - a 40 per cent increase on pre-industrial levels. All of this is in line with the IPCC's most recent assessment report, published in 2007, which found that there was at least 90 per cent certainty that most of the increase in the globe's temperature since mid-last century was due to the rise in industrial greenhouse gases. Even the world's most prominent climate sceptic, Lord Christopher Monckton, whose arguments have been shown by mechanical engineering professor John Abraham to repeatedly misrepresent the science he claims to be quoting, has acknowledged there is a greenhouse effect warming the planet, though he disputes its extent. There is, of course, still significant uncertainty about the future impact of climate change. But the fundamentals predicted by climate models - marked declines in Arctic sea ice in summer, rising sea levels due to thermal expansion and glacier melt and increases in temperature - are being matched by observations. That's the science. The response, the politics and economics, remain thornier still. The preferred model under the 1997 Kyoto Protocol is carbon trading, under which emissions are capped and pollution permits exchanged so that the cheapest way to meet the target can be found. This method has been adopted haphazardly across Europe, New Zealand and a band of US states, with more countries including Australia and China looking at signing up. There is near-universal agreement among economists that a carbon price is the most efficient way to reduce emissions, but carbon trading faces criticism that, while nice in theory, it is ineffective in the real world when it includes poorly policed offset schemes. For separate reasons, the US Congress has rejected a national trading scheme; Japan and South Korea have postponed a decision on theirs. What are the hopes of a global solution to this diabolical problem? A recent prognosis by the Paris-based International Energy Agency found the national targets submitted under last year's loose Copenhagen Accord would put the world on a path of 3.5 degrees of warming by the end of the century. Even if you assume that countries introduce policies to back their international promises - Australia and the US, to name just two, currently have no way of meeting their targets - few scientists or policymakers expect the temperature rise to be kept within 2 degrees, the goal agreed under the UN process. In Australia, next year will see a concerted effort from Labor, the Greens and significant parts of the business community to introduce a carbon price - most likely a tax that could evolve into carbon trading. If they succeed, attention is likely to turn to the challenge that has just begun to enter the public debate but will increasingly arise over the next decade: adapting to unavoidable change.

urn:contentItem:4P6V-66W0-TXN5-R1SD-00000-00The life of Pai2007-04-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisTRAVELPg. 20The life of PaiThailandJohn Borthwick. The writer travelled courtesy of the Tourism Authority of Thailand.

Has the living ever been so easy? John Borthwick kicks back.

WITH 2073 bends in the tortuous road between the northern Thailand towns of Chiang Mai and Mae Hong Son, it is little wonder that many travellers leap off the bus at Pai, roughly halfway along the 248-kilometre route.

"I stopped here for a day - three weeks ago." It's not unusual to overhear comments like this in the cafes of Pai, a once snoozy hill village that has blossomed into Backpacker Central for young travellers from everywhere.

Pai (pronounced "Bye"), is where Thai meets tie-dyed. Where sheeshas, reiki, reggae, dreadlocks and downloads are now more common than rice noodles and som tam salad.

Gladly putting the 137 kilometres of snakes-and-ladders curves from Chiang Mai behind me, I slip into the hot mineral water tub on the deck at Thapai Hotspring Resort. I'm overlooking a river and the wild baize of rice fields beyond it, and when I extract myself at last from this soporific soaking there will be fresh river fish and cold beer waiting in the restaurant. A very agreeable slice of Pai.

In 1991 Pai had seven guesthouses and three restaurants. Now there are about 150 places of accommodation, from backpacker dorms to unpretentious spa retreats, and a similar number of cafes and restaurants. As a quiet market village, Pai was home to mostly Shan people, originally from nearby Burma. And then "the dream catchers" started to drift in - creative wanderers, Thai and farang (foreign), drawn by Pai's cool, 600-metre altitude, its hot springs, pretty river and the exotica of the surrounding Karen, Hmong and Lisu hill tribes.

"The longer you stay here, the deeper you go," muses Jenny, an English backpacker sitting in a Mac-powered internet shop that's called, yes, Apple Pai. She's staying near the Buddhist temple, Wat Klang, at a guesthouse named Pai in the Sky.

It's easy to see why travellers and Thailand's version of bohemians become so comfortably immersed in the life of Pai. "A major activity in Pai, well-practised by both locals and tourists, is simply doing nothing," says my guidebook. I go in search of this nothing but the options are exhausting. I must choose between learning Thai cooking, the Thai language or Thai massage, or watching Everton play Wigan or numerous other round-ball games live on satellite TV.

I might buy any amount of hill-tribe tat and embroidery from brightly garbed women of the Acrylic Tribe, get a tattoo, hire a motorcycle, go rafting or try extreme elephant trekking ("No seat and swim with elephant").

Taking the line of least resistance, I opt for a traditional massage where my choice is simply a one- or two-hour session. A languid German lad flops onto the adjacent mattress. "How long are you doing?" I ask. "One month so far," he replies.

Pai is an ambling town, where the folk on the main drag include Muslim women in full burqas, toga-clad Viking sadhus and flamboyantly garbed Thai teens; where every second cafe declares "WiFi here" or "Laptop friendly"; and where the B-Bop Club or the Sabai Reggae Bar can keep you up all hours. It's like Bangkok's Khao San Road gone bush.

"Pai is the kind of place I'd be inclined to despise if there wasn't so much that I liked here," one blogger noted. It might not be "Thailand", but it is huge fun, and friendly. Having morphed from Buddhism to Buddha Bar, from Shan to Shakira and from opium to cappuccino in the space of one generation, Pai - now with a population of about 10,000 - is riding a wave of prosperity.

It is also at the point where the hardheads meet the airheads, with the former, the investors, reaping very good financial returns, to the point that earlier visitors now look back with nostalgia at the snoozy, misty Shan village that once was. But that was yesterday. Today everyone wants their piece of Pai.

First you hear them, then you see them. As our raft bounces down the watery stairs of a rapid on the Nam Khong River, west of Pai, and a stained-glass ceiling of jungle closes over us, the next raft comes round the bend and into sight, shrieking with delight. Noi, Cherry and a group of their Bangkok office pals are on the river, hooting all the way, it would seem, to Mae Hong Son.

The 45-kilometre river run will take us a day and a half. After a brief demo on how to paddle, we stroke clumsily away, six passengers to a rubber raft, plus a Thai boatman at the stern. Our flotilla of five rafts holds a mixture of Westerners and Thais.

We drift down a burbling water alley colonnaded by arching stands of giant bamboo and teak. Silence is a concept much admired in the abstract by the Buddhist Thais, but in practice it is nowhere near as much "sanuk" (fun) as making noise. So we stroke and scream our way through alternating rapids and calm reaches. There's a sapphire sky overhead and the water is clear and warm. Warm is good because surprise attack water fights are a part of any rafting trip.

Post-drenching, we drip-dry in the sun, only to get doused again, either by slamming through the moderate rapids or catching another watery broadside from a passing raft. For the Thais the thrill is amplified by the fact that few of them can swim well.

Late afternoon we stop to swim at a broad, low waterfall before paddling to the jungle camp where we will pass the night deep in the Lumnampai National Park. A long, sheltered sleeping platform with bedding and mosquito nets accommodates us all comfortably. Saucepans, food and beers emerge. Cooking stoves are lit and soon there's a feast to tuck into. With a million stars snagged in the trees above and a thousand frogs burping in the blackness, we share that bush-time pleasure of sitting around the camp fire, yarning with new-found friends.

Next morning, after a chilly night, we're back into the boats, stroking in a moreco-ordinated manner through the mists. Other than a few brilliant blue kingfishers, there is little apparent wildlife, but paddling amid the park's tall stands of teak, mango and myriad other species is like running a gauntlet of green gods.

"There's a hot spring just here. Pull the boat in," says our guide, Pu. We hop ashore and dig a trough in the sands, catching the piping hot water that bubbles up. Soon we are wallowing, happy as pigs, and slowly turning into a tom yum farang soup. "Time to go," says Pu, and we stroke on, coming to the confluence of the Nam Khong and Pai rivers. From here the rapids double in size, to about 1.5-metre waves. So too does the squealing volume of the Bangkok ladies' boat. It's like Beatlemania come to the jungle.

If Pai is a Thai-farang fusion tourist town, then Mae Hong Son, where our whitewater adventure ends, is a living, working Thai town. A place of teak and woodsmoke, of monks and lakes, shophouses and hill folk. And that is the beauty of this north-western border town close to Myanmar's Shan State. Yes, I can find a good cappuccino at the Crossroads Cafe - better than any in hip-hopping Pai - and there is a night market for clothes and hill-tribe crafts, but the majority of shoppers here are Thais, not foreigners.

For sunset I hoof it up a thousand steps or so to the Doi Kong Mu temple that overlooks the town. Mae Hong Son is known as "the City of Three Mists", thanks to its fogs in winter, forest fire haze in summer and rainy mists in wet season. Tonight I can see none, but the next day I find a fourth kind of vapour - the steams rising off the mineral mud baths at Phuklon Mud Spa.

Two attendants paint me from head to toe in black mud (not a pretty sight), the starting point in an hour-long ritual that involves being scrubbed with tamarind paste, immersed in mineral springs and anointed with lanolin. By then I feel like a million bucks but it has cost me only $25.

I don't want to leave lovely Mae Hong Son but when I must, it is by air. The lofty pleasure of leap-frogging those 2073 bends back to Chiang Mai in 25 painless minutes is considerable.

urn:contentItem:4P85-13R0-TXN5-R28R-00000-00STATE ABLAZE: FIRE COUNT HEADS TOWARDS 1501994-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:58:46ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 2STATE ABLAZE: FIRE COUNT HEADS TOWARDS 150THE BUSHFIRE BATTLEReports by: Karin Bishop, Maria Ceresa, Jenny Cooke, Andrea Dixon, Eamonn Fitzpatrick, Sandra Harvey, Jacquelyn Hole, David Killick, Linda Morris, Andrew Perrin, Sonya Sandham, Helen Signy, Nicole Taylor, Asa Wahlquist, James Walker, James Woodford.

CENTRAL COAST: Fires were attacking Wyong, Somersby and the Gosford City suburb of Kariong last night.

A large number of homes were destroyed and residents were evacuated as the entire area was declared highly unstable.

About 200 firefighters and 18 units were brought into the Somersby area and police began evacuating Kariong about 5.30 pm.

The Central Mangrove and Kulnura areas were also severely hit by the fires, with 3,000 people evacuated and heavy property losses.

Hundreds of residents sat through the ordeal parked in cars on the Pacific Highway, which was closed between the Hawkesbury River Bridge and Ourimbah about 3.45 pm.

Possibly hundreds of people were evacuated from Calga, Peats Ridge and parts of Mount White.

The Mill Creek fire - previously called the Gunderman fire - was last night threatening Cowan and Berowra, south of the Hawkesbury River.

NORTH COAST: The entire north-eastern corner of NSW was declared a fire emergency area yesterday as the number of uncontrolled fires jumped to 68.

Every shire council area from Coffs Harbour to Tweeds Heads on the Far North Coast, and inland from Casino to Kyogle, was declared a state of emergency.

A Grafton fire control spokesman, Mr Laurie Orel, said a small amount of overnight rain had done little more than hamper bush firefighters who were backburning through the night.

The Bundjalung National Park fire, which began shortly after Christmas, had joined with another already in the Doubleduke State Forest and destroyed more than 20,000 hectares.

The Banyabba fire was running over 25,000 hectares and Mr Orel said while fire activity was stable, forecast high winds would cause more trouble for firefighters.

By midday the temperature was 35 degrees and Mr Orel said he was expecting similar conditions in the area today.

Police were having difficulty locating "alternative dwellers" living in remote areas of bushland, he said.

NEWCASTLE: Half a dozen major fires are surrounding Newcastle, while a fire at Singleton has burnt thousands of hectares near Williamtown.

The main fires are at Wollombi, Medowie, Williamtown and Nelson Bay, West Wallsend, Barnsley, Martinsville and Belmont North.

A police spokeswoman said there was concern for the areas of Killingworth and Barnsley, where a halfway house with 10 severely disabled persons in Bendigo Street had to be evacuated.

Campers in the Allynbrook and Dungog areas were evacuated, while residents of the Banksia Grove retirement village were evacuated.

Roads surrounding Nelson Bay have been blocked off, while the F3 Freeway has been cut from the Hawkesbury Bridge to the Ourimbah roundabout.

"One of our gravest hindrances has been the number of people calling who still want to go on holidays who don't appreciate the seriousness of the situation.

"The way these fires are we can't tell from one hour to the next which road is going to be closed and where the fires are going."

Two fire fronts near Singleton, north-west of Newcastle, have joined to the south-west of Singleton and become one fire. The fire was burning in an easterly direction towards Wollombi.

A few State Rail Authority sheds at Glendale were burnt.

BLUE MOUNTAINS: The Mount Wilson fire in the Blue Mountains is spreading towards the Grose Valley. It has a half-kilometre front and has passed the town of Mount Tomah.

Thirty fire-fighting units and three aircraft battling the blaze were to have been joined by 10 fire units from Victoria at 6 pm yesterday and another 10 later in the evening.

Unconfirmed reports indicate that some evacuations may have taken place on the southern side of the Grose Valley.

The fire will burn unchecked through the area as the conditions were too dangerous for a direct firefighting effort.

Fanned by 30 to 40 km/h winds from the north-east, the fire moved four kilometres in its first three hours. It was approaching Mount Tomah, population 100.

ROYAL NATIONAL PARK: Most of the Royal National Park south of Sydney was destroyed as fires around Helensburgh burnt out of control and joined up with a wildfire spreading through the park.

Firefighters backburnt from Grays Point and Heathcote to Waterfall along the railway line.

Residents were evacuated from Otford about 6 pm and at least 40 holidaymakers were evacuated by helicopter from Garie Beach

At least 20 houses near Wilsons Park and 100 in North Helensburgh were still under threat last night as fires, with flames up to 40 metres tall, were fanned by strong winds. Little hope was held for more than 100 holiday huts at Garie, Era and Burning Palms beaches, according to Helensburgh firefighters.

Stanton Park lifesavers have evacuated more than 300 holidaymakers by helicopter and boat from these beaches over the past two days.

SOUTH COAST: Tents were on fire last night as the blaze swept through a camping site at Dolphin Point south of Ulladulla. There were no reports of injuries.

The Runnyford fire between Mogo and Batemans Bay has spread claiming 15,000 hectares of the Mogo State Forest. Fire last night continued to threaten the western parts of Batemans Bay through to the south of Surf Beach where property was damaged but losses were not confirmed.

The fire at Tumblebar was stable late last night but brigades were still working to maintain control lines.

CENTRAL WEST: About 150 firefighters battled a blaze which has burnt about 1,000 hectares in the Hervey Ranges of the north-west of the Cabone Shire, north-west of Yeoval.

The fire is virtually contained, a NSW Bush Fire Services spokesman said, but spot fires have been continuing.

Water bombing by helicopters has taken place and earthmoving equipment has been used to contain the fire.

The area is about 90 kilometres north-west of Orange and most of the burnt land was State Forest.
